name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 6 April 2017.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear Colleagues, Tomorrow will be the International Day of Girls in Information and Communication Technologies. It is an initiative that aims to encourage young women to pursue careers in the ever-expanding fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics. In Europe, only 29 women out of every 1 000 graduates have a scientific degree, compared to 95 out of 1 000 men with a degree, and unfortunately only 4 of these actually have a job in this sector. Globally, women occupy only 24% of science and technology jobs and tend to be concentrated in administrative roles. The gender gap then tends to increase as you move up the hierarchy. The gender gap in technology is also about simply accessing an internet connection and a mobile phone. The female population with internet access is 12% less than the male population, and this percentage has unfortunately increased in recent years. I hope that tomorrow will serve as a starting point and inspiration to work together to ensure a better future for young people around the world. We must make ours one of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, the fifth, which aims to achieve gender equality also through information and communication technologies. This is why it is necessary to work to make our education systems inclusive and efficient, as well as to encourage young people and companies to remove gender barriers and to value the contribution of working women. Good luck to the participants in the meeting!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I am also pleased to welcome a delegation of Members of Parliament from Sri Lanka and Myanmar who are on a working visit to the European Parliament to study our control procedures and, in particular, those on budgetary control.We are honored of your presence and we wish you good work!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules, was distributed at the meeting on Thursday 6 April 2017.Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal to amend the final draft agenda: Wednesday: The order of the second and third items is reversed so that the Commission statement on the adopted decisionon the European Pillar of Social Rights and the initiative on reconciliation between work and private life would be the second point after the Commission statement on the situation in Hungary.The agenda was thus amended.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- Not on the point you mentioned, on which we agree, but I would like to propose that, after the discussion that will take place on Hungary, a resolution be envisaged in May.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I was now announcing your request, Hon.Pittella.As the Hon.Pittella, the S & amp; D group requested that the discussion on the Commission statement on the situation in Hungary be concluded with a resolution which will be voted on in the May I part-session. I therefore now give the floor to Hon.Pittella just to formally submit the request.(Mr Pittella does not consider it necessary to intervene again)

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Members of the House!Europe has enough conflicts to conflict with another country that wants to pursue its own cultural policy.If the House wishes, we can discuss it, but adopting resolutions, provoking conflicts against another country is really only deepening the crisis in which Europe finds itself.Many of us are motivated by solidarity towards Hungary, but whatever we think about it, we should not multiply conflicts in Europe.I believe that this resolution is of no use.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Mr President, I would like to add a little clarification to Mr Pittella's request: we had reached an agreement between several groups so that we were asked both for a request for a resolution and a request for a mission to Hungary.I would therefore like our proposals to be voted on jointly, as had been agreed between us.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I received the request from the Hon.Pittella and the Socialists and Democrats group to have a resolution to be voted on in May after the discussion.No request was made to organize any missions.(Parliament accepted the request from the S & amp; D group)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Mister President!On April 9, Palm Sunday, Islamists carried out cowardly terrorist attacks against Christian Copts in Egypt during the mass celebrations, in which 78 believers were killed.It is the terrible climax of the increasing persecution of the Christian minority in Egypt.After 1,400 years of existence, these ten million Copts are threatened with extinction.I request, under Rule 149a, that this item be placed on the agenda.I also ask for your support in putting this to a roll-call vote.I am especially pleased that the Holy Father, Pope Francis, will get an idea of the situation this week and will travel to Egypt to visit the Copts.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, our group is in favor of a debate on Christians throughout the Middle East region, but in May.So we should not just discuss this.Tomorrow, I know that you are hosting the Grand Mufti of Egypt, to whom you will certainly have the opportunity to express our concern about the situation of the Copts.I believe there is a need for a debate on Christians, but in May, because the agenda is very busy.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President!No, I think the situation is very acute.We shouldn't put it off and postpone it again.There are many, many issues that have been decided, just as acutely as today or in this situation, to be put on the agenda.So I stick to it: we should take up the topic and put it on the agenda - it goes well with Pope Francis' visit to Egypt.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - (NL) Mr President, may I now just ask what exactly we are going to do together?Are there two proposals on the table now?Will Mr Preda's proposal now also be put to the vote separately?I think that's just as important to know.I have a lot of sympathy for Mr Obermayr's proposal, but if there is to be a vote on a second proposal now, then of course, as Co-Chair of the Intergroup on Religious Freedom, I also very much sympathize with Mr Preda's proposal.So I just want to know what exactly we are going to vote on.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I fully agree with the idea of discussing the situation, but first, who is to blame? The state, the government and the authorities are doing their very best to prevent terrorist attacks. What we do know is that the terrorists are just terrorists and the victims are just victims, and there is no need to unnecessarily mention the religious dimension. This is why I would rather embrace the idea presented by my colleague, Mr Preda, and not target that group in particular or exaggerate the religious aspect of this tragedy.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The House is sovereign.I put to the vote the request of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group, illustrated by Hon.Obermayr, to add to the agenda of this session, after the discussion on Turkey, a discussion on a statement by the High Representative on the situation of the Copts in Egypt.(Parliament rejected the request)

Preda, supported by the Socialist Group through the mouth of the Hon. Boştinaru. I think it is useless to vote now because then the Conference of Presidents will decide. However, it seems to me that there is a large majority in favor of discussing the issue of persecution of Christians in the world in general in May I. I will take charge, at the request of the Hon. Prey, tomorrow in the meeting with the Grand Mufti, to underline how important tolerance is for the European Parliament and dialogue between religions and coexistence between different religions are important, as in Egypt where the majority is Muslim but there are about 10 million of Christians. Thursday: I also inform you that the Committee on Legal Affairs has adopted the report by Mr Lebreton on a request for waiver of immunity (A8-0163 / 2017). This report will be voted on during the vote on Thursday. The agenda was approved with these changes.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the situation in Hungary.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Prime Minister, recent developments in Hungary have got many people worried in the EU, but also in the outside world. We share those worries and concerns. Questions have been asked about the compatibility of certain actions of the Hungarian authorities with EU law and with our shared values, and also these questions were raised by this Parliament with the Commission. That is why the College decided to discuss the overall situation in Hungary in two recent meetings on 12 April and today. The discussions allowed us to assess all the issues in an objective, fact-based and law-based manner. We also consider that given the wider situation, including the spirit of Article 2 TEU, a broader political dialogue between the Hungarian authorities, other Member States, the European Parliament and the Commission should take place. That is why I welcome the debate in plenary today which is part of that broader political dialogue with the participation of the Hungarian authorities at the highest level. The recently adopted Hungarian Higher Education law is perceived by many as an attempt to close down the Central European University, which I think is a pearl in the crown of post-divided Europe, a Europe free and whole.  (Applause) The Commission’s analysis of the law confirmed our concerns with regard to its compatibility with internal market freedoms and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The college has therefore decided today to launch infringement proceedings against Hungary by sending a letter of formal notice and we await a reaction from the Hungarian authorities within a month.  The draft legislation tabled to the Hungarian Parliament at the beginning of April on the funding of so-called foreign non-governmental organisations is also on our radar screen. If adopted, it could raise concerns as regards the compatibility with the EU’s internal market rules, in particular the free movement of capital and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, including the freedom of assembly. Civil society is the very fabric of democratic societies. We would not be democracies without strong and free civil societies. (Applause) I would therefore deeply regret any action by the Hungarian authorities aimed at shrinking the space of civil society organisations, or any attempt to control or stigmatise their work. Yes, NGOs need to be transparent about their finances, but the Commission will continue to follow the draft legislation closely and will express its concerns on the draft law in the context of this broader political dialogue.  We also discussed asylum and respect for values of human dignity, freedom and human rights, tolerance and solidarity. The Commission has already expressed its concerns about the existing Hungarian law. The new asylum law adopted at the end of March raises serious doubts about compatibility with EU law. Commissioner Avramopoulos has launched discussions on these issues with the Hungarian authorities. If these discussions do not produce timely results, the Commission will not hesitate to take further action. The protection of pregnant working women is another area we have raised formally with the Hungarian authorities and as our concerns remain unanswered the college will shortly decide on the need for further action to ensure full compliance with EU rules on maternity leave and gender equality in employment. Let me here make a more general point. Where the Hungarian authorities engage in a dialogue with the Commission, good progress can be made, and I want to be crystal clear about this. Whenever we ask for a dialogue with the Hungarian authorities, they always oblige and start a dialogue so I want there to be no misunderstanding about this. I want to mention two examples where we have reached good progress. With regard to the transposition of the Framework Decision on Racism and Xenophobia, we are pleased to see that in our discussions with the Hungarian authorities our concerns have been addressed in recently adopted amendments to the Hungarian criminal code. However, of course practical implementation of national legislation is key and hate crime cases need to be investigated in practice. We will continue to monitor the situation on the ground. As regards the values of equality and non-discrimination, the college continues to be attentive to the situation of the Roma in Hungary and in particular to discrimination against Roma children in education. Here we also had a lot of discussion and dialogue, and following our technical discussions with the Hungarian authorities the Commission is awaiting for Hungary to notify the recently proposed legislative amendments in this field. You will all be aware of the Hungarian Government’s ‘Stop Brussels’ consultation. I am pleased to announce that the Commission has decided to make public its own response in order to dispel misunderstandings and perhaps get the facts straight. The European Union is not, and has never been, about Brussels: the European Union is a project driven and designed by its Member States, each of which has decided individually and democratically that this is the path they wish to adopt. This includes Hungary. Each and every one of those Member States, including Hungary, take both the responsibility and the credit for decisions we take collectively. Each and every one of those Member States, including Hungary, under- signed the rules of the club.  Several of the claims and allegations made in the consultation need correction. For instance, and I quote: ‘Brussels wants to force Hungary to abolish the reduction in public utility charges’. The reality, however, is that the Commission shares the Hungarian Government’s objective to have affordable energy for households. The best way to achieve this is to establish competitive energy markets and promote energy efficiency and innovation, and to work together at European level to ensure security of supply. That is at the core of the Energy Union proposals. Another allegation: Brussels wants to force Hungary to let in illegal immigrants. Again, the reality is that the European Union is fighting irregular migration and is actively helping Member States to manage their external borders and return irregular migrants who have no right to stay in the EU, but irregular migration needs to be distinguished from seeking asylum. We have a shared responsibility to live up to our international obligations to protect people fleeing war and persecution and treat them fairly and with dignity.  (Applause)  Now let me be very clear. Hungary in 2015 was under incredible pressure, incredible pressure, which was extremely difficult to manage. Given those exceptional pressures in 2015, in September of that year the Commission proposed to relocate up to 54 000 asylum applicants from Hungary to other Member States, but this proposal was opposed by the Hungarian Government. Hungary is therefore asked to accept a very limited number of asylum seekers – 1 294. These are not illegal immigrants ... from the two most overburdened Member States, Greece and Italy. Asylum seekers can select (for) themselves, it is not shoved down their throats, they can select for themselves.  Another allegation: illegal immigrants heading to Hungary are encouraged to illegal acts not by just human traffickers, but also by some international organisations. Let me be very clear about this: the European Union has zero tolerance for human trafficking and it has taken action for many years to combat this heinous crime. Saving lives at sea and looking after vulnerable people who are in need of international protection is not the same thing as promoting irregular migration. There is no evidence whatsoever of NGOs working with criminal-smuggling networks to help migrants enter the EU.  A fourth claim: more and more organisation supported from abroad operate in Hungary with the aim of interfering in Hungarian internal matters in a non-transparent manner. I have already indicated earlier the Commission’s position. While the conditions under which non-governmental organisations carry out their activities are in principle a matter of national law, those conditions must be in line with EU law and the Union’s values. That is the importance of civil society. The European Union for its part has strict rules on transparency and lobbying of the European institutions.  The fifth allegation is that Brussels is attacking Hungary’s job-creating measures. The opposite is true. The EU is massively supporting job creation in Hungary. The Hungarian authorities themselves have reported that this contributed to creating more than 150 000 jobs. The last issue on the questionnaire is that Brussels is attacking our country because of tax cuts. The fact of the matter is that EU taxation rules must be agreed by all Member States unanimously. The EU has agreed only minimum VAT levels. It is the Hungarian Government that has decided to set the rate at 27% which is the highest in the EU. Honourable Members, on 23 March the leaders of 27 Member States and the EU institutions, including the Prime Minister of Hungary, stated in the Rome Declaration, and I quote: ‘Sixty years ago, recovering from the tragedy of two world wars, we decided to bond together and rebuild our continent from its ashes. We have built a unique Union with common institutions, strong values, a community of peace, freedom, democracy, human rights and the rule of law’. And I have to add to this on a personal note. As a young man I travelled regularly to Hungary and I remember very well the sense of oppression I felt crossing the border from Austria into Hungary: the barbed wire, the watchtowers, the oppressive feeling in Budapest that you had all the time. The biggest single miracle in my lifetime is the fall of the Berlin Wall, the fall of the Iron Curtain and that Hungary became one of the democratic nations of Europe, and that is not something the European Union should claim credit for. This is something that was done by the Hungarian people themselves: striving for freedom, protecting their freedom, however, it is now a common European task and we will have to fight for that. Given this history, given the Rome Declaration, how can one reconcile this with a campaign to stop Brussels? The fact that only one month after this Declaration we are having today’s debate on the situation in Hungary gives us all the more reason to seek clarifications about the intentions of the Hungarian Government. Let me say in conclusion that I strongly thank Parliament for supporting this, but I also want to express my gratitude to Prime Minister Orbán for coming here today and having this debate with us. Dialogue is the European way, dialogue to solve misunderstandings, but also dialogue when we disagree. That is the European way. (Applause)

name: Viktor Orbán
text: Prime Minister of Hungary. - Mr President. Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Ladies and Gentlemen! The European Parliament is once again debating Hungary. I came here to Brussels to take part in this debate. Slowly in my thirty-year-old representation, I always appreciated the debate and the clash of differing views. Democracy is argument-based, and it gives the European Union a moral basis. I am convinced that better decisions are always made if they come from debate and not from unilateral revelations. By participating here, I would also like to help you make an informed decision when Hungary is on their agenda. I remember the previous Parliament's resolutions on Hungary did not stand the test of truth. Just think of the spectacular and embarrassing failure of the Tavares report. You may know that we Hungarians will never give up the fight, and today I am trying to use the power of common sense in this debate as well. Our dispute is partly with you and partly with an American financial speculator. I know that Hungary's strength, size and weight are much smaller than yours, and smaller than that of the American financial speculator George Soros, who attacked Hungary and destroyed the lives of millions of Europeans with financial speculation, who was punished for speculation in Hungary he is also an openly confessed enemy, yet he is so highly esteemed here that he is received by the top leaders of the European Union. But this is no reason to condemn us on the basis of untruths, because fairness is not a function of country size. Dear House! I came to defend my country in the debate. But it’s also important to be able to report on successes. In 2008, we left where Greece was. The then Hungarian government was the first to turn to the IMF and to you, the European Union, for a loan. Since then, this money has been repaid ahead of time and in full. Since then, many hundreds of thousands we have created jobs. Hungary is on its way to the lowest unemployment rate in the Union. Today it is 4 percent. We have created a work-based society, instead of giving aid to everyone who wants to work. Full employment is our goal. Our budget deficit has been exceeding what you demand for years, most recently it was minus 1.8 percent, our public debt is declining, and our economic growth is stable at around 4 percent this year. We still have a number of issues to solve, but we have something to be proud of. I am convinced that Hungary's success is also a European success, and the Union needs success today. It would be foolish if, due to ideological differences, this fact did not receive enough attention. Dear European Parliament! I see there are several issues that may be of interest to you. It is rumored that the Hungarian government closed the law of György Soros, an American financial speculator in Budapest, by law. The rector of this university wrote to the faculty and students of the institution, I quote: "We would like to emphasize that the existence of the Central European University is not endangered by anything, the university will continue to operate in all circumstances." Commission, Parliament, this accusation is therefore unfounded and has no factual basis. The situation is absurd. It’s like when someone is charged with murder and even convicted while the victim of the alleged crime lives and thrives. In fact, he himself points to the convict, shouting at the killer. The reality is that the minor amendments to the law passed by the Hungarian Parliament affect 28, 28 foreign universities operating in Hungary and do nothing more than unify the regulations applicable to them, close the possibility of speculation and abuse, demand transparency and eliminate them vis-à-vis European universities. has enjoyed a privileged position so far. You are European legislators. It is my duty as the Prime Minister of Hungary, the leader of an EU member state to ensure that European and Hungarian universities are not at a disadvantage vis-à-vis their competitors outside the Union. They are the owners of any great and rich man. Dear Parliament! The other item on the agenda is the national consultation announced by my government these days. I would like to inform you that during the last decade it has become customary in Hungary to ask the citizens of the country regularly. We have held national consultations four times in recent years. I wholeheartedly recommend this method to you as well. During the current consultation, the Hungarian government is asking for the support of the Hungarian people in order to form the position to be represented in Brussels on specific issues. Dear Ladies and Gentlemen! I would like to make it clear that the commitment of Hungary and the Hungarian Government to the European Union is unquestionable. Hungarian politics has been built on this foundation for the past thirty years. That is why I signed it, and that is why I fully agree with the recently adopted Rome Declaration and with the program of my party family, the European People's Party, adopted in Malta. At the same time, Mr President, Mr Vice-President, we are dissatisfied with the functioning of the European Union in many respects. We are criticizing because we want to make mistakes and we want to reform the European Union. We are convinced that we can only regain the trust of citizens in the European institutions if we do everything we can to eliminate the causes of poor and inefficient operation. Therapy requires a clear diagnosis, a clear name of the troubles. I personally do, but we Hungarians usually like straight speech. We articulate it clearly and unambiguously so that everyone understands it, even if we know that not everyone likes it. We are irritated by the stubborn political language that makes us unfit to describe things, which has taken a bite in European public life today. But I don't think it's European The same temperament and style of debate would be expected in the 28 countries of the Union. That is why I find it exciting, and that is why I personally like European political culture. If you break down, if you break down the prejudices that are nurtured against us, you will find refreshing, innovative and creative political thinking. This is also true for consultation. I am convinced that this is exactly what Hungary owes its results to. In some of the cases raised in the national consultation questionnaire, the basic position of the Hungarian government, this straightforward speech, is contrary to the Commission's intentions. It is clear that we do not want, and do not consider it compatible with the founding treaties of the EU, for migrants to be resettled in our country. Who we live with can only be decided by Hungarian citizens. Important information is that György Soros and his NGOs want to transport one million migrants to the European Union every year. He personally announced this program publicly and also offered him a financial loan. You could read too. We reject this proposal. Nor do we want to lose the right of the utilities to set the price of public utilities so far, because we fear that this will increase the burden on the population and lead to a sharp rise in prices again, and Hungarian families have already suffered enough from this. Nor do we want the right to impose taxes, which is currently a national competence, to be transferred to the Union, because we believe that this would damage our competitiveness. Nor do we understand that the Commission criticizes the Hungarian public works system every year in its annual report, which is an important element of a developed work-based and non-aid-based society. These are current issues of debate. Our position is that we do not want a change in these, we do not want a reorganization of national and EU competences in these matters, that is, we are defending the status quo that is currently being developed with a common will. Hence the "Stop Brussels!" name as well. Isn't that a sin? We received together we also have the rules that are now in force, which we are defending, the current rules that we want to protect are also common European Union acquis. Therefore, in my opinion, the Hungarian position cannot be, and the Hungarian consultation cannot be described as anti-European. It is also true - and I do not want to deny it - that our vision of Europe is based on a strong Europe of strong member states. In such a Europe, the Member States bear the responsibility and do not shirk their responsibilities. Responsibility for public debt, budget and border protection. Dear Members! We want to shape decision-making here by means of debate, reasoning and persuasion. I suggest that those who do not like the opinion of our country should confront their own arguments, fight our debates, but please do not condemn because Hungary has its own independent opinion. Dear House! The third issue is the regulation of non-governmental organizations. The draft now being discussed, that is, being discussed at home in Hungary, takes over the American model. In several countries of the Union, and as far as I know, in the framework of the Pieper report here in Parliament, you are also addressing the difficult question of how to make the operation of a capital-intensive foreign external lobby that wants to influence democratic decision-making transparent to everyone. Hungarian law is based on the principles of transparency. All we want is to know about NGOs, what money and what interests are behind them. This does not undermine their constitutional right to have their voices heard, to represent their interests and to organize freely. Dear Members! It is also important to note that the behavior of the Hungarian government so far has been a detourless, always consistent behavior, we want to follow the rules of the club, and we have always followed it so far. I am aware that EU membership entails not only rights but also obligations. We have tried to resolve the conflicts of recent years through dialogue and negotiation. I'm happy to report that As a result, we managed to close such issues as possible, such as media regulation, the new Hungarian constitution, the reform of the court system or the development of nuclear energy. These are successfully closed cases. I would like to assure the Vice-President that we will strive for this in the matters that are now on the agenda. Dear House! Hungary is a proud country. Hungarians have always considered themselves an important nation of Europe, committed to the European Christian values, and wanted to be involved in the decisions that affect them. My government in Hungary is working to strengthen Hungary's commitment to the European Union. Our work is successful. The support of the European Union is the highest among the member states in Hungary, over 70 percent, and we are proud of that. Believe me, people support the European Union, but it will only support it if it is based on fair and open debate and is able to admit that it needs reform at times. Mr President, we have always given you the respect. Please, when it comes to Hungary, be critical of prejudice, I ask you to stick to the truth, and I ask you to measure it on an equal footing. Only in this way can we all be worthy of a European name. Thank you for listening!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Dear Mr President, Dear Vice-President, Dear Prime Minister! It's not about Soros today. I don't understand one thing. For 25 years, the Central European University in Budapest has been issuing two diplomas: one American and one Hungarian. This has been good practice for 25 years and it has earned a reputation. Hungarian students benefit from this because they get two degrees in their city - in Budapest. I, and I can say this for my entire group, dear Prime Minister, we simply do not understand why this advantage is now being taken away from this university. (Applause) Our request is clear and simple: the freedom of science is a fundamental value of the European Union, which must be upheld and defended. The university administrators just want to do their job, namely to teach students. That is why I ask Viktor Orbán to accept and implement the specifications, requests and requests for changes that the Commission has now launched. I would like to single out a second point. I don't understand a second thing, which is: yes, you can disagree, you can take different positions in a debate, of course. But what is being practiced in Hungary with this survey is not the gathering of arguments and opinions, but it is propaganda against Europe. (Applause) When we talk about bureaucrats who rule Brussels, I now look into this room and see, dear Viktor Orbán - Prime Minister, don't be angry with me: most of the bureaucrats are behind you, the rest of them are here in this house are all MPs, elected politicians who work here. That is why I would like to make it clear that it is not bureaucrats who decide in Brussels, but elected politicians - ministers, MPs. Elected politicians decide in Brussels. We may not allow us to permanently damage it. I say there are many national politicians who are raising the mood against Europe. But we cannot tolerate that happening. A strong Hungary needs a strong EU in the long run, and we must not damage that. However, I understand one thing a little better, and I would like to make that clear: when the Hungarian government puts an initiative on the table to want to know who finances the NGO and how it is financed, then I wonder why the Green Group is that is attacking now. Here in Brussels, the Green Group is the one that is most in favor of transparency. They want to know how NGOs are financed. I will tell you in all honesty: The fact that we in Hungary will have transparency about what money comes from Russia or America or God knows where to finance this NGO - I would also like a law like this for Europe. I would also like to know who is funding all of this. (Applause) When it comes to the quality of Viktor Orbán's work in Hungary, the balance sheet that he presented today, the work that he is doing for his country and therefore for Europe, then Hungary must not be made Europe's nightmare . Hungary has done an excellent job in many areas, and I would like to say specifically that some conservative politics also belong to my party family, to the European People's Party, and we don't let anyone give us advice on who belongs to the EPP and who doesn't. Last but not least, I would like to thank Frans Timmermans. He pointed out that this is the way we should work in Europe. If there is a problem we sit down and talk to each other. Unfortunately, I have to correct Frans Timmermans on one point: not every party practices this path - it is the EPP path. Viktor Orbán has never avoided the debates and he has always delivered. The deviations were always eliminated, which the Commission asked him to do.However, when we were discussing Romania and the corruption laws there, no Romanian socialist prime minister was present.I hope that Mr Muscat, who is now up to his ankle in the Panama swamp in Malta, will be here next month - in May - to answer the questions.After all, he is the President of the Council.(Applause) Therefore: The socialists speak here with two tongues.The EPP is here and we are talking to each other.Europe is not the right of the strong, but the strength of the law.Viktor Orbán has proven and confirmed this in recent years.That is why we trust that in this case too he will be ready to listen to the European proposals and implement them.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Given the number of subscribers to speak and also given the delicacy of the discussion, also because I would like to grant the "catch-the-eye", I will not grant "carton bleu" questions during the discussion.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Frans Timmermans for his clear and firm words and for the intentions he expressed on the part and on behalf of the European Commission. May the European Commission go all the way, without excluding any instrument and, if the conditions are right, also the instrument of Article 7 of the Treaty. President Orban, you lie knowing that you are lying, because you are well aware that the European Parliament does not defend the interests of a great American financier, but defends the legitimate expectation of young Hungarian students who do not want to be deprived of a great, beautiful and excellent university. We are not only defending the Central European University, but all universities, we are defending science, research, school, culture, everything that is the basis of democracy. And it's not just the question of the university. We have no prejudices towards her and towards other personalities who do not have the same political color. We are used to dialogue and we are used to having respect for our adversaries, whom we never consider enemies. But we don't have ham on our eyes. We cannot fail to see what is happening in Hungary on the issue of media pluralism. We cannot fail to see what is happening in terms of the accessibility of non-governmental organizations. We cannot fail to see, dear President Orban, that you have refused to implement a refugee relocation plan, not the one million requested by Soros, we don't care what Soros is asking! We are interested in what the European Commission, the European Council and the European Parliament have asked for: 1 100, 1 000 and just over refugees! On what grounds did you deny the possibility for people fleeing war, terrorism and violence to enter Hungary? As if Hungary were a state excluded from the European Union. It is right to stay and we are very happy because we love the Hungarian people. It is right that when you are in a family you share the advantages and the burdens and burdens of being together. Then there is a political issue, and I turn to my colleague Weber who has reconfirmed the link between President Orban and the popular group. I have listened to positive voices from popular colleagues attentive to the issue of democracy, attentive to the issue of freedom. But I ask myself and ask my colleague Weber if it is still possible to contemplate Orban's stay in the family that belonged to De Gasperi, that belonged to Kohl, that was of personalities who built European democracy, who have always defended freedom, democracy and pluralism. I think that the presence of President Orban from the Christian-democratic family must now be dissociated immediately. Finally, President Orban, stop playing the game of going to Budapest and saying that it is all our fault, that we are the bad and the ugly ones who impose certain choices, that we are the bad and the ugly ones who impose. It is not we who want to close the universities, it is not we who want to make NGOs fail, it is not we who want to close the media, it is not we who want to reject refugees! Examine your conscience and tell your people the truth!

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Mr President Timmermans! The Lord mentioned his personal experiences, about the trip to Hungary. I would just like to remind everyone that Hungary - just like my country, Poland - was the pioneers of freedom of countries in the Eastern Bloc at the time when Western European countries wanted to deal with the Soviet Union, and at universities - because today we are also talking about a university - Italian or German, Marxism in all its forms reigned. So we Poles, we Hungarians, we Czechs, we Slovaks do not really need lessons about freedom, democracy, but we are willing to share our experiences, our conclusions that come from observing reality also in your countries. You said something about civil society. Yes, civil society is the basis on which the existence of democracy and its functioning are based, but it is civil society that must, of course, have an appropriate structure, as everywhere. It cannot be postcolonial or colonial, as it is unfortunately still common in Central and Eastern Europe. And it seems to me that you would like to consolidate this structure. When it comes to CEU, I personally appreciate this university - contrary to many colleagues present here, I think. I personally collaborated with this university for many years. It has achievements in the field of social sciences, has brought interesting elements to the intellectual life of Central Europe, and interesting scientists work at this university. Of course, it also has a very clear ideological profile, which should not be concealed either. She does not hide it. But, as we know, in addition, its very controversial founder does not hide his political ambitions going so far that he would even like to reverse the result of democratic elections in some countries. I would like to remind you that the Member States have the right to regulate education, in particular to regulate the activities of foreign private universities. And I am convinced that in many Member States criticizing Hungary today the CEU could not be established.There are no institutions founded by George Soros in Germany, as far as I know, no Italy, no France, and that is no coincidence.Therefore, I would say our group is strongly opposed to any attempt to stigmatize Member States for no reason.However, I think that we should perhaps conduct a general debate here on the condition of universities in Europe, which have ceased to be diverse, have ceased to be a place of freedom, have become a place of conformism, repression directed against people who think differently, and the best example of this is the campaign against certain two university professorsin Berlin, which we all know about and whose example is known, and which is not of particular interest to colleagues in this room.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to ask Prime Minister Orban whether he remembers the first time that we met. Mr Orban, it was in a hotel in Budapest in December 1989. I do not remember its name, but I remember our meeting because before it I had a meeting with SDSZ, the old Liberal Party, and then I asked you, as the leader of Fidesz, why you were not with your mother party in the meeting room and you explained why this was. I remember that it was just a few months before the successful participation of Fidesz in the first free elections in Hungary. By the way, at that time you were helped by George Soros – I remember that – and had a programme at that time that was more or less a little bit more progressive, I should say, than the programme of the SDSZ at that time. I would say that it was more social liberal and a little bit like Emmanuel Macron at that time. I would say that you were the Emmanuel Macron of Hungary in 1989. I do not think that Emmanuel Macron will be pleased with what I have said today. I did not say it in French so I hope that not much will be made of it.  But let us be honest: a lot has changed since 1990 and 1989 when we saw each other. You changed. You dumped your democratic principles and, in a certain way, you say openly that you want to create, not a liberal democracy, but that you want to have an illiberal state. At the moment the list of what you have done is a long one: harassing NGOs, chasing critical media away, building walls, your attempt to reinstate the death penalty in your country, even when this is not possible based on our treaties, and now you have decided to close down a university. I would ask you how far will you go? What is the next thing? Burning books on the square in front of the Hungarian Parliament, the so—called Lajos Kossuth Square? Will that be the next thing? Perhaps the books of Kartes or maybe of Konrad, perhaps the books of what is one of my favourite writers in Hungary, Sandor Marai, because Sandor Marai was a Hungarian cosmopolitan who you are attacking at the moment. When I look at you, you seem to be proud of this and to think that it is fantastic that I can say all this here. What I am seeing more and more is not a   proud conservative – because in the meanwhile you have become a proud conservative – but a sort of modern day version of the old communist Hungary – economic protectionism, excessive nationalism, the search for an illiberal state – and you see enemies of the Hungarian State everywhere. You see enemies in the energy sector, in the media, in the NGOs and now also in the academic world. It is like having Stalin or Brezhnev back, but now in Hungary. They also had that time of paranoia. It is not enough to have a majority in a democracy, but you have to chase them and go after them when they have another opinion. So, Mr Orban – and I will conclude with this – Hungary became a member of the European Union in 2004. You and your predecessors signed up to the values of the Union and you know all these principles very well. Even the left or the right in this House respect them. You have in fact violated every single one of these principles in the different cases that Mr Timmermans mentioned. Yet you want to remain a member of the European Union. Well I have in fact got more respect for the decency of Eurosceptics, who will at least say that they do not like the European Union and its values and that they are leaving. You want to continue getting money from the European funds, taking the European Union’s money, but you do not want the European values. They are not for you. What would you call that? Not very courageous, I should say, and certainly not in line with a politician based on principles. So my question to you is to ask whether you think that it is time to make a choice again, as you made that choice when you became, after being a Liberal Democrat, a little bit nationalist and a conservative? Is it not the time to ask yourself in your soul how you wish to be remembered in the future? Do you want to be remembered as somebody who liberated your country, Hungary, from communism – and you did that – or do you want to be commemorated as an eternal enemy of our open European democratic society? That is the choice that you have to make now.  (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! It is normal for people who are involved in politics and who have grown up in different social epochs to change their position - to develop further, to open up. I believe that there are hardly known formative personalities in European history who have not gone through developments. I am thinking, for example, of Georg Lukács, someone I admire very much and who for me actually shapes Hungary - the proud Hungary you spoke of. A Hungary of democracy, freedom, openness and changes in the interests of the people who live there. You spoke of the people - of the Hungarian people who are so proud. I say: What is the people actually in your view? There are people living in Hungary, including migrants, including different ethnic groups, including the Roma. Is Hungary the country where all these people who are in your country want to live and work? Do they all have the same rights? Are they respected equally? Aren't they discriminated against? For me, that is the crucial question I want to ask you here. You speak of Soros. As a leftist, I am absolutely no friend of Soros. I don't have to justify myself there either. I am surprised that you address it that way because - is it true that you yourself were a Soros Fellow at Oxford? Then I am amazed by this combination that you are bringing now, and I think, if it is true, that you are really interested in the fact that the actual higher education law that has been passed is a LexCEU, so that it is primarily against this university, because the conditions that are set in the law apply to this one university, then one must ask oneself the question: What is happening here? Is this about the freedom of science? Is this about access to education, training, study, research and Science? Or is it ultimately about very simple, cheap return carriages? And I think that this cannot be carried out on the backs of students, teachers, people who are in the middle of their training, who have to consider whether they should even register for the next semester. We had the rector of the university here in Parliament yesterday. That doesn't agree with what you're saying. Perhaps by now he has understood what effects this law has on those affected. Two weeks ago 80,000 people took to the streets. It was not we in Hungary who protested there! It was your citizens who protested and said: We are losing something here. It is also about the fact that this university must remain part of academic life! For this we urge you: do your part to ensure that rights are protected! Check the NGO laws! They do not comply with international law, nor do they comply with many other things. Check your dealings with asylum seekers! This is not just about the laws that you pass nationally, it is also about international conventions that must be observed. You are just as obliged to do this as to comply with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I wish to welcome the Prime Minister to the European Parliament. Prime Minister, I really appreciate your presence and indeed, as Manfred said, it is better to debate directly. Mr Orbán, we were actually born in the same year and I no longer recognise the defender of freedom and democracy that became known to me under your name back in 1989. We Greens also have our share of criticism for a number of political orientations of the European Union, but what I do not understand is when you start comparing the EU with the Soviet Union. Come on! If Brussels were Moscow, we would have tanks from the EU in London right now. We do not. On the contrary, I am struck by the fact that a number of the laws that you are passing in your country find their inspiration in Putin’s Moscow, which is hardly anyone’s dream, right? No, I really do not understand you because you have a privilege. Twice you enjoyed an overwhelming majority. Your people trusted you and I just imagine – you might laugh at me – but if my party enjoyed a two-thirds majority in any Member State – well, three times, I agree! – I would not be afraid of an independent press because it would stimulate the public debate in the country and mobilise the collective intelligence we need. I would not be afraid of a strong and independent judiciary, because checks and balances is what we need in democracy. I would not be afraid of a vibrant civil society, because it would help me spot problem areas that I need to solve. I would not be afraid of leading-edge universities because they would nurture talent in my country, and I would say ‘even better if some of the funding comes from abroad because it enriches my country.’ It is not just that I would not be afraid of these things, I would cherish them, because I think they would help to deliver a better society for my citizens. So what are you afraid of? A bit like Guy Verhofstadt said, since Hungary enjoys the financial solidarity of the EU, and rightfully so, it should abide by all the obligations of the EU, but this is not the first reason. The first reason is do these things, be an open society, because it is good for Hungary. Hungary will be stronger. Hungary will be a better place for its people by having a diversified free press, strong democratic checks and balances, a vibrant civil society and leading-edge universities. I would like to conclude with one thing, the refugee issue, and of course you expected me to do that. Mr Orbán, I must say that we are utterly appalled at the way your country has been treating refugees. True enough, Hungary sits in an uncomfortable situation at the outer border of the EU. But instead of directing your anger at refugees themselves, you should direct your energy towards your fellow EU Member States so that they help you in welcoming them. Mr Orbán – and you did it again today – you often refer to Christian values. Well, I must tell you one thing: as a Christian, I find nowhere in the Gospel that the stranger should be locked up and sent back. What I read there is that we should welcome and protect. (Applause)

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Mr Orbán, not for the first time you sit here as the democratically elected leader of a great nation, and you stand up and make a reasoned argument as to how the Hungarians do things and how there are different cultures within Europe. You are prepared again and again to come back here and to be attacked and abused by non-entities who want Hungary to bow to their will, and not to the will of the Hungarian people or its leader. I am beginning to wonder: at what point, sir, do you – as an intelligent man – stop banging your head up against a wall? You spoke today and you behaved today as the leader of a nation, but is it not becoming obvious that, as a member of the European Union, you are actually not a nation? Just as we are seeing in France at the moment, with huge interference in the French presidential election, even with the unelected Commission now coming out and backing this godlike creature called Macron. No, you are not the leader of a nation, and these people will go on interfering in the lives of Hungarian people, and you will never be forgiven. You are a sinner in their eyes, not just because you want to close down George Soros’ propaganda machine that masquerades as a university – nothing to do with that. It is because you will not pay the price for Ms Merkel’s supreme folly and sign up to migrant quotas, and they will never, ever forgive you for it.  Surely, since you yourself have said in the past that we need to get rid of a utopia called supranational Europe, it must become clear to you – as it became clear to eurosceptics in the United Kingdom – that this set of organisations, bound by their Treaties, are not open to reform. Institutions like this are led by fanatics. They are turning this into a state, and the nation state cannot coexist alongside. Now you were bold enough to call a referendum on the migrant quotas, and 88% of those that voted agreed with you. Surely logic says it is time for you to give the Hungarian people a referendum on whether they stay part of the European Union or not. Who knows, you might come and join the Brexit club, and then we could fight for a nation of democratic states working together, trading together and put this nonsense behind us.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that the 500 million Europeans are ruled by puppets and marionettes. While the terrorists are shedding blood in Europe, we are concerned with prosecuting Hungary - Mr. Orban, hold on - we are dealing with the rights of the Roma, the fake refugees, the billions of Soros and not a legitimately elected government. Hungary - I say this to the Italians who follow me and to the Europeans - has a single tax of 16%; in Hungary, companies pay 9%, unemployment has dropped to 4%, youth unemployment is 11%, retire at 62, and the Hungarian people and government have had the strength to defend and control their currency, their central bank and their borders. What do we do? Are we sending them tanks like in 1956? Do we use sanctions instead of missiles? I remember that some Europeanists of today who cheer Europe and cheer Macron, for example Giorgio Napolitano, former President of the Italian Republic, when the Soviet tanks invaded Hungary, proud then as today, spoke of the Hungarians as fascists and thugs and invoked the intervention of Soviet tanks to safeguard world peace. It seems to me that nothing has changed in these sixty years. Instead of tanks you use banks, finance and an invasion of fake refugee immigrants, financed by unscrupulous speculators, like Soros, who maybe even finances someone who is sitting in this Parliament or someone who is sitting in this Commission. Here, instead of putting Hungary and Poland on trial, worry about defending the 20 million unemployed Europeans and defending our borders, dear Commissioner. You, who are part of the party of a gentleman who said that Southern Europe spends money on alcohol and women, should be ashamed to set foot in here, should have respect for the prime minister legitimately elected by the Hungarian citizens and you should, you all, avoid cheering on Macron and respect the free vote of French citizens.So, Mr. Orban, on behalf of the Northern League, on behalf of millions of Italians, thank you for what you do, thank you for what you will do, thank you for resisting the dictates of the European Soviet Union.Long live the freedom!Long live Hungary!

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, as a representative of the Jobbik for Hungary movement, my position in the debates in the European Parliament on the activities of the Hungarian Government has always been determined by the specific case. Thus, I always rejected the mandatory quota and defended the Hungarian migrant policy. I did this here on 2 December 2015 in this Chamber, the only one of all parties, including Fidesz. Jobbik opposes György Soros, rejecting the ideology of an open society. However, the impossibility of making the CEU work is to be achieved by the government with a power arbitrage that would set an unacceptable precedent. We are not expecting a solution from the European Union, but from the Hungarian Constitutional Court, which is why the representatives of Jobbik in Hungary made it possible for the board to decide on the issue. Otherwise, the real solution for them may come from next year's election, as we oppose this cynical, abusive, corrupt system.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Mr President, I understand that you are starting by being strict with me, so I will try very hard. I stand here with pain in my heart in this debate, pain in my heart because I also know the other Hungary and, I have to say, the other Fidesz, the Fidesz that was born in opposition to communism and the Fidesz that participated in the pan-European picnics, showing that it wanted to overcome communism and become part of a Europe that stands united.  Yet we need this debate here in this room today because, not for the first time and yet again, developments in Hungary seem to run counter to our values and to what we stand for, everything we fought for in 1989: freedom of education, non-discrimination, and the principle of sincere cooperation. I would say to Frans Timmermans that it is a good thing that the Commission is working on this. But the real question of course lies with you, Prime Minister. Are you really the kind of man who needs to paint an incorrect and exaggerated picture of Brussels as the enemy, only to look stronger at home? Is your place among the autocratic leaders we see in our neighbourhood, like Putin or Erdogan, or do you belong to a Europe based on the core values that you yourself fought for in 1989? The choice is yours, but so are the consequences.  (Applause)

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, dear Prime Minister Orbán, I am from your neighbouring country, Slovenia, and I have many friends in Hungary. Together we dreamed of being part of an open Europe, and today I share my deep worries with them. The current government’s campaign against NGOs is unacceptable. We cannot just sweep out civil society. In current national consultations, ‘Let’s Stop Brussels’, the name says it all, you portray NGOs as a threat to national interests. With hundreds of NGOs across Europe, we urge you to withdraw the proposed deal and to respect academic freedom and autonomy and suspend the discriminatory changes to higher education legislation.  I also ask my EPP colleagues to understand it is high time the Commission formally triggers its rule of law framework with Hungary. We have to defend the people of Hungary from the corrosion of the fundamental values; and Mr Orbán, I am very sensitive to European migration policy. Do not imprison people fleeing for their lives to Europe in container villages behind razor wire? It is shameful for Europe.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, as Manfred Weber said, this debate is not about George Soros, but is about what happened in Hungary and what you are doing, Mr Orban. However, I will also recall that, in 1989-90, you benefited from a Soros scholarship at an Oxford college where you studied liberal political philosophy. Now let us come back to the present time. Academic freedom has been cancelled in Hungary and we ask to have it back. Your attack against the EU, other foreign universities and civil society is a brutal attack against free—minded education and free—minded people. We cannot tolerate this in the European Union. A month ago, Putin forced the closure of the European University in St Petersburg. Shortly after that you did the same thing inside the European Union. I do not believe this is a coincidence. I believe it is a coordinated plan against the free-minded and democracy. So, Prime Minister Orban, come back to Europe and its values.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I would like to use my minute not to debate with Mr Orbán who is probably not going to be convinced anyway. He once said that his big examples were Putin and Erdoğan, and indeed he is a very good copy of that. However, I would like to address the European Commission. I very much welcome the steps that have been taken by Mr Timmermans. I also recognise the limited instruments available, but I think we should all recognise, and I would also like to ask Mr Weber to recognise that we are not talking about single issues here. We should address this in the systematic nature of the problem: the systematic destruction of the democratic rule of law and fundamental rights. We should also recognise the contagion that is taking place in Poland, so if we fail to recognise that systematic nature then we fail to preserve the integrity of the European Union. Therefore, I think it is high time that we launch the Article 7(1) procedure and I hope that this House is going to vote for it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Mr President, "illiberal democracy", a new Hungarian model, is the gradual but systematic adjustment of checks and balances: media, justice, education, NGOs. The "Stop Brussels" consultation is a caricature and the NGO bill, modeled on Russian law, is not a text of transparency, but of suspicion. Regarding the migration issue, one can wonder whether the right of asylum still exists in Hungary. The Geneva Convention is no longer respected: systematic detention, including minors; building a wall along Serbia - now electrified; right to shoot on sight for "border hunters"; amalgamation, lies are king, multiple scapegoats - we have just heard. The lack of action by the Commission since December 2015, as well as the silence of Mr Avramopoulos upon his return from Hungary, has worried us. I therefore welcome, Mr Timmermans, that the Commission has finally decided to initiate infringement proceedings and that a resolution is put to the vote in the next plenary. Mr. Orbán, we do not play with freedoms, especially in a country whose history is that of Hungary.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: - (NL) Mr President, judges have been fired, newspapers have been closed, gays are back in the cupboard, refugees have been beaten, imprisoned or deported.A regime like yours, Mr Orban, needs enemies to stay in power, so now you go for the scientists, the students, the activists and the European idea.It reminds me of that poem by that German preacher Niemöller from World War II: "When they arrested the communists I kept silent, after all I was not a communist".Well, there is no silence here, but it is not done here either.So, Commissioner Timmermans, I am addressing you.We cannot expect Mr Orban to voluntarily improve his democracy now, but we can expect you not to wait for the Council and start an Article 2 procedure.Yes, you can even start an Article 7 procedure without your consent from the Council.Then do that!

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Dear Mr President, Dear Prime Minister Orbán!Supposedly we're talking about your new higher education law today.But we all know here that's not the point.It is about the Hungarian restlessness, it is about the Hungarian way.Hungary opposes Brussels centralism and wants to maintain national independence.Hungary is resisting Muslim mass migration and protecting itself from the Christian-Western culture.Hungary opposes the left-green zeitgeist and just wants to be Hungary.Hungary doesn't want to be France, which has lived in a state of emergency since November 2015, or Stockholm, the world capital of rape.If I have to choose between the French, the Swedish and the Hungarian route, then I also choose the Hungarian route.Mr. Orbán, please stand firm, you are solid as a rock.Thank you for what you are doing.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, on a point of order, I would like to ask my colleague to explain herself, with facts, when in this House she accuses Sweden, and Stockholm, of being the capital of rape. Deal in facts please. This is an insult to a Member of the European Union.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, we Hungarians are a legendary freedom-loving and autonomous nation, when we hear the word 'freedom', our hearts beat. So it is good to mobilize us for issues such as freedom of education, freedom of science, or even freedom of speech, freedom of the press. What is diabolical, however, is that they want to take advantage of this to sell us mass migration as a kind of tying, which, please, please now acknowledge that we do not want, we reject. And I ask that my compatriots at home also pay attention to this disgraceful trick, in addition to the callers of freedom, for example, in the now planned resolution, forcing migrants - who are called refugees - to accept refugees into Hungary. And watch out at home too, that possibly well-meaning people go out to protest liberties. There’s that educational freedom, our hearts are beating, but right there’s the other sign next to it: “Break down the fence!”. That’s how they want to please guide us nicely, tying it up, and it’s a disgrace. Freedom, human dignity, human rights yes, no mass migration!

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, Member State representatives come here to stand up for their policies. That is their prerogative, but mine is to stand up for the Europe I believe in. The European Union is not a ‘pick and choose’ entity. It is a collection of states that share the same intrinsic value system and that believe in sincere cooperation with each other. When higher education institutes are targeted and vast sums are spent on disingenuous campaigns to stop Brussels, this runs contrary to the values we believe in. Pandering to populists at the very time when the world needs the opposite is not our way. I am a proud member of the EPP. We believe in a Europe of freedom of thought and freedom of speech. We will always defend those values whenever and wherever they are under threat, whether it is the corruption of the Socialist Government in Malta, the watering down of the rule of law in Romania, institutions under pressure in Poland, or what is happening in Hungary. This is what we stand for. Our values have stood the test of time and they are not up for negotiation – not now and not ever.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: "I have to say, I sympathize with you to some degree." It can be hard to live the way you live: in constant fear, seeing enemies everywhere. You are afraid of democracy, of an open society, of debate, of the European Union, of the reception of refugees, of non-governmental organizations, of independent media, of free education, of everything that Europe has built on since the Second World War. And in his fear, he not only systematically downplays liberties, but also betrays and disregards the most basic interests of Hungarian society. You want to make Hungary a second Russia. But protesters waving European flags on the streets of Budapest do not want that. You want to stop Brussels, even though you have to stop. Because your illiberal democracy is based on incitement to hatred and fear, images of enemies, lies, corruption, theft of public money. But by now, you and your politics are at a dead end, no longer supported by your own party members without reservation. And we will never, ever let down European Hungary!

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: - Mr Timmermans and Mr Manfred Weber! We are debating Hungary not for the first time, and I am afraid not for the last time. With the CEU law, the NGO law, the "Stop Brussels!" With the campaign, Viktor Orbán crossed new frontiers following the myriad boundaries he had already crossed in recent years. All this, basically, with the hesitant grumbling of the Commission and the active defense of the European People's Party. You may have thought that more active resistance from the Commission would only exacerbate the situation. And within the People's Party, they can still moderate Viktor Orbán more effectively than outside. However, you are not right, you have a responsibility. The passivity of the Commission only encouraged this man, and the defense of the People's Party did not moderate but legitimize everything he does. In doing so, you have also betrayed Europeans who believe that Europe is not just a single market, but also a community of values, rights and principles that can be expected and enforced. It’s time to prove to them that they stand by them!

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, honorable Member. Prior to my mandate, I worked as a teacher at a Hungarian college in Transcarpathia, a higher education institution that was constantly threatened by restrictions and closure. Yet it didn’t make headlines on the New York Times front page. Therefore, I can clearly see that the publicity around CEU is not about academic freedom, but about a double standard. Where are you when it comes to fighting for minority language educational institutions in Europe, so why not raise your voice that a fundamental right to freedom is being undermined? The amendment of the Hungarian Higher Education Act, as we have emphasized countless times, is not aimed at closing the CEU, but at clarifying the legal background of education, and all Member States have the right to do so. The law has been constantly amended in recent years, and the errors identified by the Office of Education are not protested by the other institutions, only by the CEU. That's why I don't understand why this is. Why the need to arouse mass and media hysteria, why not seek a calm dialogue on the part of the CEU as well? Please do not just be unilaterally informed about the issue, but listen to both parties!

name: Silvia COSTA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Vice-President Timmermans, it is significant that on the 60th anniversary of the Treaties and the 30th of Erasmus our request was finally accepted by the Commission to take, with this initiative, a first step to activate the procedure of infringement against Hungary, considering violated Article 2 of the Treaty on the state of freedom and equality, but also articles 13-14 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights on academic freedom and the right to education. After the petition launched by thousands of students, teachers and citizens, Hungarians and not only Hungarians but also Europeans and internationals, yesterday we met the rector Ignatieff, who confirmed that the law actually puts the existence of foreign universities at risk , including in particular the prestigious CEU, which has been part of the Hungarian academic system for 25 years, has independent and international elected bodies, in fact setting the law halter conditions that will block the activity of the CEU and will no longer make enrollments possible. But this is only the latest in a series of human rights violations, including the refusal to welcome asylum seekers, the erection of the wall, the progressive control of media freedom, the limitation of the work of NGOs and the campaign unacceptable "stop Brussels". I hope that Commissioner Navracsics, responsible for education and culture, will also defend these principles.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, thank you for being here and thank you also for writing to me recently. A couple of years ago we started off with the constitution – media freedom, retirement age for judges. We have witnessed several unspeakably worded national consultations in the meantime. We have witnessed an attempt – or rather a vague idea – to reintroduce the death penalty, and all that coming from a man who is constantly referring to Christian values. It escapes me, Prime Minister, where the death penalty would be on any Christian agenda, and I have rarely found any Christian theologian who would have been able to find anything good about the death penalty. Now it is about a university, it is about NGOs, it is, above all, about the next national consultation. The NGO thing, Prime Minister, is not about transparency as we all know: it is in order to label NGOs that are foreign-funded as ‘foreign’, because they might carry foreign influence in Hungary, and foreign influence is bad. Now the only thing that comes to my mind in this context is if all foreign influence is so bad, why do you accept the payment of EUR 5 billion euros annually as a big net recipient of European structural funds in order to plaster the whole country with the posters in which you called Brussels crap? Somebody who does that, Prime Minister, leaves the Union out of their own accord. (Applause)

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Mr Democrats and Prime Minister Orbán against them! Shame and betrayal! Viktor Orbán, a 1989 Soros Scholar, would hide in shame if he saw today. Because today's Viktor Orbán betrayed all the values, all the young democracy and dreams he represented then. But it is a much bigger problem that it is a shame for the Hungarians to have to stand here for the shame of Europe because of you, because it is treason. This is treason, Prime Minister, whatever you write at home about your funded, publicly funded lying media. For 28 years you have been involved in the dismantling of the Stalinist state party. And now he is building a new nationalist state party of the Putin type, shattering European values. We don't know what happened. For sure, we have to do against it. Dear fellow European citizens, I would like to ask you one thing: they are examining the situation of the Hungarian rule of law, but do not punish Hungary for the time being! Do not punish, because it is not the Hungarian people but Viktor Orbán who deserves punishment. We will replace this government at home and bring Hungary back among European values.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, as we are now talking about Hungary over discussions with a higher education institution, the CEU, I would like to draw attention to the fact that an important higher education institution is operating in Romania, contrary to the laws that have been in force for years. It is the Medical and Pharmaceutical University of Târgu Mureş, which is a multicultural university according to the 2011 Education Act, which means that a separate Hungarian educational unit should be established within its framework. Due to the resistance of the institution, this has not happened so far, in six years. And the situation is not a concern for the Romanian Government, the Council of Europe or the European Union. I myself have spoken on this issue several times, but apparently this university and this country are not of interest to as many people as CEU and Hungary. It would be good if the European institutions were consistent and held accountable in all Member States.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, today's new attack on the Prime Minister and thus on Hungary can be traced back to our clear position in the migration crisis. What we have been saying for two years now is the first and only in Europe. Today, however, all this is included in the main documents of the European People's Party. Both the People's Party's migration strategy and the basic document adopted by the Maltese Congress state that we can only guarantee the security of our citizens by protecting Europe's external borders and deciding who will be admitted to Europe and in what numbers. That we need to separate real refugees from economic migrants, to tackle the migration crisis at its roots and not to attract it here, but to encourage staying in place through European policies. It is these marked positions that are leading us to argue here so unfairly again today. Yet I believe that the Hungarian people, with our Prime Minister at the forefront, want nothing more than all European citizens: to live our everyday lives in security, in a strong, prosperous Europe. Therefore, it is our responsibility and duty to ensure that people feel safe. And I would just add that it is sad and shameful that Verhofstadt’s ugliness and education are even applauded by colleagues.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr Orbán, I would like to ask you, when you recommend a consultation with citizens, whether you have consulted citizens on this draft amendment to the Higher Education Act?Because what you're proposing is simply liquidation.Of course, Hungary can decide on the conditions under which universities will carry out their education, but you know that the six new legal conditions, including the US-Hungary agreement, cannot be met in six months.This means that if you want to improve the conditions, make education more transparent, I agree, it is your right, but give all universities the opportunity to meet these conditions.That is my request to you.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Prime Minister Orbán, if Hungary comes again and again to the examination of this Parliament, it is not because your great country is a victim of the imaginary tanks of the delusional European Soviet Union.No. This Parliament represents ten million Hungarians too.And this Parliament is that of the European Union, to which your country acceded in 2004, and that of the Lisbon Treaty, whose values threaten the harassment of the opposition, the restriction of informational pluralism and freedom of information, the attackto judicial independence and, of course, the restriction of the fundamental rights of all people, including foreigners and immigrants whom you despise so much.The Commission must activate Article 7 to defend the principles, without fear or calculation, because many of us here will support with our vote the action against the 'Putinization' of the Government of Hungary.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - At the beginning of this parliamentary term, in the debate on Hungary, the vice-president of the liberal club said that it was not really about one or another law.It is about the direction Hungary is going.And then she said, as we remember well, that she hopes that with regard to Hungary - and then it turned out that also with regard to other countries - the current European Commission will be bolder and less legalistic.This is the definition of the rule of law: boldly, less legalistically against states whose political direction does not suit.And today we have this courageous and less legalistic Commission, led by Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans.Freedom is indeed increasingly threatened, but freedom will survive in Europe.Freedom will survive thanks to countries like Hungary, like Poland, thanks to politicians like Viktor Orban.Congratulations, Mr. President.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Mister President! Prime Minister Orbán, this is the third time that you have come here to - as you pretend - to have a dialogue with us. The third time I listen to you and only notice: you don't want any dialogue. They don't really want to listen to us either. You are only coming here to convey that we - the EU - are your enemy and your opponent and you want to stop us. Only someone who feels weak, who is afraid, does that.
