Even with the laws that you are making in Hungary - de facto abolish the CEU university, NGO law, this Stop Brussels campaign - only someone who is afraid of democracy, who is afraid of free universities, who is afraid of Civil society, do that. Only those who - in short - are afraid of criticism - criticism that is the salt of democracy. Mr Orbán, I think you should be stopped. That is the message - also from my side - to the Commission, to Vice-President Timmermans, to finally begin Article 7 and to give the Council the alternative of continuing or finally speaking plainly. To you in the EPP, Mr Weber and others: nobody here in your own party is listening to you anymore, and the only ones who applaud are the right-wing extremists here in this House when Mr Orbán speaks - no longer the EPP. I think it's time to shut Orbán and Fidesz out.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, there is a lot of hypocrisy in this Chamber. Most of the leaders of the political groups here are trying to manipulate peoples, states, nations, governments. One must, of course, explain to Hungarian citizens the purpose of the debate on fundamental rights in Hungary and against their elected government. The University of Central Europe is funded and overseen by numerous NGOs by George Soros, who is involved in the internal affairs of states through these organizations. It is an inalienable right and obligation of governments to protect their national interest and the citizens of their countries and the Union must not forbid them to do so. I would like to congratulate Orban, because he decides in the interests of the Hungarian nation, fights against Islamization and the preservation of national identity, and defends Hungary from the efforts of extraterrestrial actors to impose globalization as it does here.

name: Viktor Orbán
text: Prime Minister of Hungary. - Thank you, Mr President. I think it is appropriate for me to answer some important questions. First of all, thank you all for this debate. Thank you for watching Hungary and thank you for your opinion. Those who have supported Hungary, the Hungarian people and the decisions they have made here are also publicly supported, and I would also like to thank those representatives separately. Thank you for your solidarity. There were Hungarian speakers. I do not want to describe the behavior of Hungarians attacking their country here in Brussels, I am convinced that these debates should take place at home. I would like to say to Mr Verhofstadt that I have the impression that you want to tell us what the Hungarians need to do more than once. I ask you to entrust this to the Hungarian voters, who can decide this every four years. I would like to thank Vice-President Timmermans for the speech he has made. Thank you very much for offering an open and substantive dialogue, we are ready to discuss all the issues you have raised, and I see that we will easily find a solution in many of them. Unfortunately, I am also forced to react to my fellow Member, Mr Pittella, because I feel that he has treated me unfairly when he took his post harshly. Honorable Member, allow me to correct one of your thoughts: migrants do not want to go to Hungary. Migrants want to go to Austria, Germany and Sweden via Hungary. We are, in fact, defending Austria, Sweden and Germany. In fact, we are complying with the Schengen Agreement. And I find it strange that you, as a Member of the European Parliament, are attacking Hungary because Hungary is complying with the Schengen Treaty, not primarily for its own sake, but for the sake of the Germans, the Swedes and the Austrians. We Hungarians believe that we deserve recognition rather than an attack. The comments that are trying to resist my party in the European People's Party must tell you that this is one - if I hurt someone, I apologize, we know this well - this is an old communist tactic. You want to salami up the European People's Party. Apparently they want to salami up to make them stronger here afterwards. We know this, so democracy was destroyed in Hungary by the Communists. I advise the European People's Party not to accept this solution. Ladies and gentlemen, our position on migration is absolutely clear. Illegal immigration must be stopped, segregation between refugees and migrants must be carried out outside the territory of the European Union, and help must be taken to help people in distress where there is trouble, and not to bring people in distress into the European Union. Who doesn't make the relocations? My fellow Member, Mr Pittella, less than ten per cent have been relocated. It was not Hungary that did not take part in this, it only affected a thousand people. 10% of the specified frame number has been moved. It is clear that the policy of relocation, based on a mandatory quota, has failed. It is unnecessary to force it, because states that do not oppose it openly to us do not implement it either. That was a bad idea. If a bad political idea turns out to have failed, it should be stopped and another solution is worth looking for. I also have a word about money. Look, the money Hungary receives from the European Union is not a donation. Cohesion policy is good for everyone. Every single Member State of the European Union is doing well. You also earn on it, those who give the money, they also earn on it. Not a little. Let's talk about this openly! Net contributors are beneficiaries of cohesion policy. That is what your Commissioners are talking about openly. They also say numbers, I do not recall how much money is given to us percent goes back to your country. I am convinced that this is cohesion policy, that is the right thing to do. We dismantled tariffs, opened our markets and allowed the free flow of capital while we were as poor after communism, as scarce as capital as the church mouse. I am convinced that there is no fair competition without cohesion policy. You cannot ask us, ladies and gentlemen, to shut up and talk to us as if you were giving us a gift and we are your purchased commitments. We cannot accept this position, Hungary must reject it. As for Hungary being a kind of authoritarian political system, and thanks to me personally, although this is obviously not about me, but about the ten million Hungarians, I would like to inform you that I have spent 16 years in opposition in parliament and am just starting to 12th year of government. And I am one of the few European leaders who, when he lost, did not go into business, did not sit on well-paying boards, did not give guest lectures for huge sums. When we lost, my party and I personally, we stayed in politics and took on opposition debates and fought and regained people’s trust. To blame such a country, and such a governing party, for authoritarian regimes, and to mention authoritarian countries for us / us, I think is quite simply not fair and not fair. Ladies and Gentlemen, I think of many things, I think of many things about György Soros, but not that he has ever given a scholarship to anyone in his life because he thought he would have bought his opinion for life. So I also have to reject the assumptions about that. And finally, I must say a word about illiberal democracy, as you have mentioned. It is that in Central Europe it they believe that if liberals do not win or are not part of the government, there is no democracy.We have had enough of this.The truth is that we think that if the liberals do not win, there can still be democracy.Illiberal democracy is when non-liberals win.Thank you for your kind attention.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, at the conclusion of this debate, let me draw a few conclusions for the Commission. I will be looking forward to the reply by the Hungarian authorities to the notification we have sent on the law on higher education. In our view, this law is clearly in violation of EU law, so I hope we can get a response to that.  I have to say that the only thing the Central European University is asking is to be left alone to do what it does well. I come from a country where, for centuries, Hungarian scholars came to study and also to enrich my country. We live in a European Union where, through the Erasmus programme, the cross-fertilisation of young minds across the European Union is one of the biggest assets of this European Union and one of the biggest success stories.  We should cherish this academic freedom, this exchange of ideas, and this way of promoting a vision of the world that is open to other views.  With regard to other views, I fully respect different visions and opinions about the future of the European Union. Everybody is entitled to his own opinion, but not to his own facts. I know we live in a time when very often, when we have strong opinions and they are not in line with the facts, we assume that the facts must be wrong but, on this specific case, the Commission will stick to the facts. I would be grateful to the Hungarian authorities if, in their procedure on ‘Stop Brussels’, they would take into account the facts we have presented in reaction to the questions put to the Hungarian population. I think we deserve that. That is how we work in the European Union. I look forward to continuing to work with Hungary in this.  Regarding this debate, we are not going to solve these issues only by taking legal steps. The Commission will take legal steps when legal steps are warranted, when the Treaties are violated, but we will only reach a consensus or an idea of where we need to go collectively in the European Union if we have a debate.  If you will allow me, Mr President, I want to make one remark. From the extreme right, because of their lack of arguments, we only get insults. Since nobody reacted, I want to react: I was deeply, deeply aggravated by the vile attack by Ms Von Storch on Stockholm and on Sweden. I think this is completely unacceptable. This is not the way we should have a debate about our common future. We can ask of each other to disagree profoundly, but to have respect for each other.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written. Prime Minister Orban, we are not blind to the situation in Hungary. We know you are facing an aggressive, extremist party. We know that Hungary is on the frontline of the refugee crisis. But other countries, faced with a similar situation, have reacted very differently. No matter how fierce your language is about favorite scapegoat "Brussels", extremist parties always become one step more aggressive, more negative. In your place, I would completely change the tone and emphasize the support - both in money and otherwise - that Hungary receives every year from "Brussels". 25 billion euros for investments in infrastructure, jobs, research and education from now until 2020, about 2,532 euros per Hungarian. Why not emphasize that crucial European solidarity, which benefits every Hungarian citizen and the government budget? It is difficult, even impossible, to understand how someone continues to violently attack the European Union while "Brussels", or rather the other Member States, invest billions in the Hungarian economy and citizens. Solidarity is a two-way street. We are ready to continue constructive cooperation. We count on you to do the same to the European Union and provide a robust solution - no window dressing - for the Central European University.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - In Hungary, after gags to the media, walls, barbed wire and detention camps for refugees and migrants, we register a further attack on fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression and research, with the closure of the Central European University in Budapest, one of the most prestigious university institutions in Europe. It is unacceptable that Hungary, as well as the other countries of the so-called Visegraad quartet, refuse to respect the quotas of refugees and asylum seekers established by the EU while other Member States such as Italy, with generosity, continue to save men and women and children in the Mediterranean. Well, therefore, the decision of the European Commission announced by Vice President Timmerman to initiate drastic measures against Hungary. I listened carefully to President Orban's speech and I must say that he has done nothing but increase my regret for a country with great cultural and European traditions that continues to have difficulty in interpreting the fundamental values ​​of Europe.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The Prime Minister of Hungary has come to us, to the European Parliament, to personally argue in order to answer some of the questions concerning Hungarian democracy that are now on the agenda. On the one hand, its presence is clearly a respectful step for the European Parliament and the European Union, as it takes an active part in debates concerning the EU. I would remind you that there are heads of government in the Member States who, despite Parliament's express request, have not yet appeared before the plenary. Mr Manfred Weber, the leader of the group, also named the leaders of the Member States, who belong to the socialist party family, and who, because of their offshore and corruption scandals, would have to account to the European plenum. On the other hand, the Hungarian Prime Minister did not make an educational or hypocritical speech, but put out specific arguments in his speech and made it clear several times that the Hungarian government was ready for a constructive and fair dialogue with the European Commission and the European Parliament. This is the only democratic way of settling disputes in Europe today. It is therefore unacceptable for some fellow Members, especially the leader of the Socialist and Liberal Groups, to educate anyone, especially a Prime Minister of a Member State, about the rules of democracy. In the European Parliament, the strength of the arguments has always mattered, not the argument of strength. Do this at all times!

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. - On April 25, 1974, after 48 years of dictatorship, Portugal lived the first hours of an expected freedom. Like so many other countries in the European space, that was a much-awaited freedom. Portugal became a member of the EEC in 1986, mainly to anchor, solidly and irreversibly, the democratic process started in 74. Years later, it was Hungary's turn to regain freedom and, in 2004, to access the European Union, subscribing its fundamental principles. It is intolerable and alarming, therefore, that we have been witnessing the erosion of democracy and the rule of law in the European Union for years, starting in Budapest under the leadership of Viktor Orbán, with inexplicable political protection from the European People's Party and complacency from the Commission. and the Council. Prime Minister Viktor Orbán's governmental path, fomenting xenophobia and miserably attacking refugees, and his recent speeches advocating what he calls "illiberal democracy", call into question fundamental principles of the European Union. I therefore support the infringement process initiated by the European Commission in the face of the Hungarian Government's attempt to close the Central European University and interfere with its academic independence. Such an initiative only fails to come late, very late.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up.- Mr Orban, I was surprised by your speech, after you surprised me with the undemocratic actions you are taking in Hungary.I congratulate the Commission for presenting correctly and objectively what you do not respect in the governance of your country.Mr. Orban, I know Hungary well, I live in Timisoara and I have many Hungarian friends.How can we believe you when you came here and offended us, accused us of not understanding?And you lied, Prime Minister, saying that the university will continue its activity.I received many letters from teachers and journalists who actually showed how they will be affected.You said you were proud, but what does pride have to do with respecting values you recognized when you agreed to join the EU?Pride is a quality, but when it exceeds the measure, the Gaussian curve says it is a defect!

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. –  I would like to express my deep concern about recently adopted higher education law that could force the Central European University (CEU) out of Hungary, the so-called ‘Stop Brussels’ national consultation and the law on foreign funded NGOs. I believe the Commission should closely monitor these three proposals, which in reality constitute another attempt by the Hungarian government to strengthen its grip on power and in this manner to disrespect Union’s common values and the treaty on European Union. Unfortunately, recent actions taken by Hungarian Prime Minister Victor Orbán and his government signal that they intentionally continue to damage Hungary’s democracy and its relationship with other EU member states. Therefore, I call on the EU institutions and the Member States to start intensive political talks with the Hungarian authorities in order to ensure that country’s legislation is compatible with Union’s one. Last but not least, I call on Hungarian authorities to listen to the voice of its pro-European orientated citizens who marched against these three proposals and who want their fundamental EU rights as EU citizens to be respected and protected.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing.- Autonomy of universities and freedom of movement of people of science are one of the basic conditions for building a knowledge-based society.Legislative changes in Hungary significantly hinder both the activities of the Central European University in Budapest and the free exchange of employees and students.The question is what action the Commission intends to take to protect the autonomy of universities and is the Commission considering activating the rule of law control mechanism against Hungary?

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: In written form. - I cannot remain indifferent to the alarming processes taking place in Hungary, and especially to the recently adopted law on higher education, which threatens the existence of the Central European University. I fully support the efforts of the rector of CEU, a number of intellectuals and former and current students, some of whom have written to me asking me to defend the principle of academic freedom and the functioning of the university in the European Parliament. I am glad that we are not alone in this battle. Today, the European Commission decided to initiate infringement proceedings against Hungary. The position of the European Commissioner for Education himself - the Hungarian Tibor Navracic, nominated by your government, that the Central European University is one of the most important universities not only in Hungary, but also at European level, is also indicative. Universities are a place of free and critical thinking that must be defended, not attacked. Universities were the place where the battle against communism began for thousands of young people in defense of freedom. Many years ago you were one of them!

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - Mr. Orban, you are a villain. A thief who stole the money and future of the Hungarian people. During his seven-year rule, everything and almost everyone in the country got worse. Four million Hungarians are miserable, and fifty thousand Hungarian children go hungry every day. Half a million people have already fled the country, those who have stayed at home are struggling with deteriorating health care, poverty, and the payment of monthly overheads. Meanwhile, you are at war with everyone who does not tolerate the world of your thief, Putin-friendly. Mr. Orbán! It is not the civilians, not the refugees and not Brussels that are the enemies of the Hungarians, but some of you alone! You are the one who has become fabulously rich in recent years. With the help of state tenders, your stroman, Lőrinc Mészáros, became a gas mechanic and artisan in one of the richest people in the country in a few years. We know that Mészáros' property is actually yours. You stole every forint of this property from the Hungarian people. The thief is imprisoned, and the stolen money is returned to the Hungarians. We can promise you one thing, Mr Orbán, what you would deny your opponents: a fair trial. An impartial and independent court will judge you not so long!

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I would like to draw the attention of EU citizens to one thing about the situation in Hungary.I do not agree that we should choose between national sovereignty and democracy or between independent Member States and the European Union.I do not want to go into either the CEU scandal or the 'Stop Brussels!'campaign.I think the most important thing is not to allow us to stifle, to abolish the civil sphere, the independent media, universities and businesses, citing the protection of sovereignty for political purposes.This applies not only to Hungary, but also to Slovakia and all the other Member States.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The European Union is as strong as each of its members. The European Union needs a strong Hungary and I personally am happy with the success of Hungary as well as every member state. The dedicated work of all of us is a prerequisite for our citizens to live better. When problems arise, it is good that we, as a European family, solve them in a spirit of togetherness and solidarity. It is also important that we respect the competence of the Member States and it is Hungary's right to require all universities to meet the standards in order to resolve a situation in which some non-European universities have better business opportunities than European ones. There are as many as 28 of them in Hungary, including the Georg Soros University in Budapest, which cannot be an exception, and despite the fact that only 10% of Hungarians study there, that university should respect Hungarian laws. NGOs that receive money from abroad should, in the spirit of transparency they advocate, show who is financing their business, as this is the best way to remove doubts that undermine the trust of citizens and the Government in their work.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: in writing. – Those who defend the CEU in this debate in the name of university autonomy should be aware of how this autonomy works in practice. Obviously, autonomy functions within the law. Each Member State has its own legal order governing universities. Second, accreditation, research assessment, teaching quality measurement are all directed by the state and set often stringent limits to university autonomy. Third, the internal administration of universities imposes strict limits on the freedom of what can be taught. The criterion is student numbers. If there aren’t enough, the course will be cut. Fourth, research, especially in the natural sciences, is heavily subsidised by the relevant private sector, again a restriction on autonomy. Finally, if a university is supported by taxpayers’ money – and almost all are – then that too is a limit to autonomy. After all, the duty to be accountable functions as a restriction. So don’t be carried away by romantic ideas of university autonomy. It has never existed.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - The recent attacks on the CEU and civil society and the anti-EU campaign under the auspices of the "national consultation" as a result of which the political situation in Hungary had to be put back on the agenda of this week's plenary session of the European Parliament. Although I did not see much point in the EP before, without concrete measures, to provide a European stage for Orbán's lying demagoguery, this time the outrage reached a quality level with the very wide political spectrum in which MEPs condemned the Fidesz government. Unfortunately, for me, Orbán's current performance predicts that today's plenary debate, like previous occasions, will not achieve its goal, which is otherwise grateful and respectable: to return Hungarian political relations to a democratic, humane, European path. For my part, I once again tried to understand with my colleagues that the sole purpose of the systematic dismantling of democratic fundamental rights in Hungary is to fulfill the unlimited power of the Orbán regime so that no external or internal political or legal factors can limit its pervasive corruption mechanism.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written.- The Hungarian Government's decision to close the respected Central European University is the latest in a long series of violations of EU values.This Parliament represents ten million Hungarians as well.And this Parliament is that of the European Union, to which your country acceded in 2004, and that of the Lisbon Treaty, whose values threaten the harassment of the opposition, the restriction of informational pluralism and freedom of information, the attackto judicial independence and, of course, the restriction of the fundamental rights of all people, including foreigners and immigrants whom you despise so much.The Commission must activate Article 7 to defend the principles, without fear or calculation, because many of us here will support with our vote the action against the illiberal and undemocratic drift of the Government of Hungary.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate based on the Commission Declaration on the Decision adopted in relation to the European Pillar of Social Rights and the initiative on the reconciliation of personal and working life [2016/3020 (RSP)].

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU is not a market or a currency, those are instruments. It is not just about consumers who consume, it is about citizens, real people, who are trying to make a living, getting their kids through school, struggling for a better future. Europe has a role in protecting and strengthening the rights of all our people, and we are not a day too late in doing so. In the wake of the White Paper on the Future of Europe, the first reflection paper on the social dimension has now been published, setting out scenarios on what choices we could make together. We are also here today to speak about the Pillar of Social Rights and the principles that we believe are important to help Member States to reform and together converge upwards. Valdis Dombrovskis will give a detailed presentation on both the Reflection Paper and the Pillar, and Marianne Thyssen will conclude the debate on behalf of the Commission. For now, let me focus on one of the initiatives we are bringing forward to put the principles of the Pillar into action. It is a joint proposal by Marianne Thyssen and Věra Jourová that I wish to attach great importance to and of which I am frankly very proud. The Commission today adopted an ambitious new initiative to support the work-life balance of parents and carers. With this package of legislative and non-legislative action, we want to increase women’s participation and representation in the labour market and ensure they are not obliged anymore to choose between a family or a professional career. And this is not just about women, it is about men as well. Existing policies have not brought equal opportunities that allow fathers and mothers to work in care together for the welfare of their children, elders and society at large. Today, the employment gap between men and women is more than 11%, and in full-time equivalent it goes above 18%, because part-time workers are mainly women. When families have young children, the gap widens hugely. Women also spend five times more time than men on care and household activities. This explains partly the pay gap of 16% and the pension gap of 40%, which increases women’s exposure to poverty and economic dependence. The main drivers of the problem relate to parenthood, the unequal share of care responsibilities, the shortage of childcare and long-term care facilities and financial disincentives in tax benefit systems for the second earner.  The economic loss due to the gender employment gap is estimated to be around EUR 370 billion per year. In the context of demographic aging, we cannot afford to leave this huge talent untapped. This is a social and an economic imperative and of course, above all, a moral imperative.  Our proposal, once adopted, will repeal the Parental Leave Directive to replace it by a directive on work-life balance for parents and carers. We propose maintaining the existing four months’ parental leave entitlement for each parent, but paid at sick pay level and non-transferable. We introduce a paternity leave of 10 days and care leave of five days per year and per dependent relative, also paid at sick pay level, and we also extend and modernise the use of flexible work arrangements. At the same time, we will promote the provision of affordable and quality formal care services across the Union, including by optimising the use of available EU financial support. We will ensure better implementation and effective enforcement of the protection against dismissal, provide guidance to Member States and monitor the development of their work-life balance policies.  Honourable Members, we must stop wasting all that female talent and give fathers a real chance to be with their children as well. We are in times when we see around us a so-called cultural counter-revolution emerging, throwing us back into the past, often to the detriment of women. I am more than convinced that we need this package now. I do not want my daughters to be in the same situation as my grandmothers were. Europe is not telling anyone how to live. There is not one right balance, but I do not accept that our daughters have to fight again the battle that their grandmothers won. Work-life balance is about a real choice for fathers and mothers on how to organise their lives. This is our message: it is great to be a mum, it is cool to be a dad, and it is fantastic to be able to combine both roles with a carer.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today the Commission adopted its first reflection paper as part of five contributions announced in the Commission’s White Paper on the broader debate on the future of Europe. It is fitting that the first reflection paper covers the social dimension as that is something that is close to the heart of every citizen. Since the adoption of the Treaty of Rome, the European social dimension has been the founding principle of European integration. It should bring social progress and real benefits for people and has been the cornerstone of the European Union’s success. Our aim today is no different. We have come a long way in 60 years. We should be proud that our social model is a success. Europe is home to the most equal societies in the world. The reflection paper provides an overview of the social realities in Europe and the challenges awaiting us. Digitalisation, globalisation and demographic transformation are already making their impact felt and will only deepen with time. New working patterns, often based on freelance or self—employment, increasingly also in the collaborative economy and online platforms, all add to the need to revisit our social acquis. The Rome Declaration emphasises the need for a social Europe, based on sustainable growth which promotes economic and social progress, as well as cohesion and convergence. It is time to look ahead at what kind of social Europe we want, what kind of future we want for ourselves, for our children and, more importantly, how we want to achieve this. Who will be taking what responsibility? We propose to look at three options: limiting the social dimension to free movement only, progress in the field of the coalition of the willing Member States – which could be the euro area, but also another grouping of countries – and deepening the social dimension of Europe together with all 27 Member States. All these options are feasible within current treaties and of course mix-and-match is possible. The scope of the reflection paper is to present a wide approach to social issues. It does not reflect the Commission’s preferred option at this point. We look forward to continuing this debate with you and other stakeholders in the coming months. But today’s package is not only about reflection. Today we have presented a European Pillar of Social Rights. This proves that social Europe is not a purely theoretical principle, but an evolving reality on the ground. By delivering on the promise to reinforce the social dimension of the European Union, we are making a difference in the lives of our citizens. The essence of our proposal is the following: investing in people is investing in their future as well as in our economy. The social dimension is needed to create a resilient economy and sustainable growth, and to strengthen our competitiveness. With our initial European Pillar of Social Rights we set out to do just that. More than a year ago we presented the first outline of the European Pillar of Social Rights and, in the course of far—reaching consultations, we listened and took on board the suggestions expressed by governments, national parliaments, stakeholders, social partners and citizens across Europe. All in all, we had more than 16 000 replies. In particular, I would like to thank you for your far—reaching report last January. Today these contributions are crystallised in our proposal with 20 principles and rights. The central objective remains that the Pillar should be a reference framework to drive the process of reforms at national level. More specifically, it will serve as a compass for a new renewal process of both economic and social upward convergence. As was announced from the start, the Pillar is primarily conceived for the euro area, but is open to all EU Member States. Indeed we are proposing to adopt it through a joint proclamation with the Parliament and the Council as EU institutions and we hope that all Member States will be part of it. The Pillar is essentially a joint endeavour. Those of you with long memories will remember that the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU was adopted in 2000 via an interinstitutional proclamation by the Parliament, Council and Commission. We aim to reach a political endorsement at the highest level of this proclamation in the second half of this year. The First Vice-President has already elaborated on one of the specific initiatives accompanying the Social Pillar, but we are bringing forward three other accompanying initiatives to put the principle into action. The Commission is responding to your request for a framework directive on decent working conditions in all forms of employment by consulting social partners on two possible initiatives. Firstly, on ways to better align our social security system with the new forms of work. We want to ensure that as many people as possible, including the self-employed and gig economy workers, are covered and can build up rights against their social contributions. Secondly, by modernising EU rules on what needs to be spelt out in a job contract through the revision of the Written Statement Directive. More specifically, we want to ensure clarity for workers and employers on their contractual relationship irrespective of the type of contract. For both initiatives we would like to give social partners the possibility to look for mutually acceptable solutions before considering any legislative steps. Lastly, we are issuing guidelines to help provide national legislators and employers with a clearer picture on what counts as working time, what happens to untaken paid annual leave with the interpretative communication of the Working Time Directive. We are also responding to your request to ensure better monitoring by issuing a social scoreboard. This will expand the existing scoreboard of key economic and social indicators used in the European Semester to better take into account social considerations. It will also help us show progress towards a triple-A social Europe. Our proposals pave the way for a balanced project that allows all of us –citizens, politicians, entrepreneurs and businesses – to reap the benefits of today’s modern reality. Let me be clear, however: our aim is not to legislate on every aspect of the Pillar. The red thread running through the Pillar is subsidiarity. EU institutions, social partners and all levels of government have joint competence and joint responsibility to make sure competitiveness and social progress go hand in hand. I count on your support to make the European Pillar of Social Rights a reality.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the two Vice-Presidents of the Commission and Commissioner Marianne Thyssen for presenting this ambitious initiative. Finally, we insist on the social dimension of the social market economy, which we have too often forgotten, just as we have often forgotten that the citizen should be at the heart of our priorities. It is true that there is an urgent need to meet the need to protect our fellow citizens in a changing world of work. It is also important to support those whom life makes more vulnerable, as well as to strive for a greater convergence of our social norms in order to fight against the dumpings that fuel Euroscepticism. All of this, of course, while respecting subsidiarity. However, the best social policy is a return to employment, because only growth can bring about lasting social progress. What is the point of talking endlessly about growth if not to redistribute the benefits? Our group is heir to the Christian democracy which gave so many founding fathers to Europe, this Europe which was itself deeply imbued with them. That is why our group is attached to the social dimension of European policy, but all this can only be done with the goodwill of all and the support of the social partners. Each will bear the responsibility.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, dear Commissioner, this is indeed an important day for the European Union because we now have a move towards a stronger social dimension. The European Parliament will certainly be ready to co-sign a proclamation on this European Pillar of Social Rights for all European citizens, because for the European Parliament we cannot have first-class citizens or second-class citizens. But we are willing to move in this direction and that is why we call on all governments also to co-sign such a proclamation and such a commitment. But what really matters is the commitment to deliver on better social standards for our century. We need to make sure that we are really meeting the new conditions of labour markets and welfare systems, to fit them for the future. Our citizens are waiting for this. That is why the Pillar must deliver on best conditions first of all to provide a good future for children in Europe. We cannot have children in poverty. That is why we need to have a Youth Guarantee delivering more and better jobs for the best generation we have in Europe. That is why we need to have these new leave schemes, paid schemes, for both men and women to take care of their children and their relatives, and most of all, that is why we need to make sure that all people in employment, whatever their kind of job, they have a clear set of working conditions and they have access to social protection. This is really to prepare our welfare systems for the future. But in order to deliver this, we need to have real means in order to have a credible social pillar, and real means implies that even of course social partners should be consulted. The European Commission should also be ready to table labour and social law when this is needed. We need European action to create these common standards. Secondly, we need to make sure that the European Semester will bring about real upward economic and social conversions by monitoring standards, economic and social policies. And finally, we need to have the financial instruments to underpin all this convergence. I conclude by saying the European Parliament is ready to move in this direction and we claim that we should have a roadmap to monitor delivery of all these instruments, we need to make the pillar something that works for all European citizens.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Commissioners! In a global comparison, the EU already has very high social standards. That's nice, but also expensive. You also have to be able to afford the social pillar. Given the economic situation in the EU, additional concerns are a risk. They can weaken companies' competitive positions and hinder investment. Problems can arise in the weaker countries of the euro zone and Eastern Europe. Smaller companies will be more affected than big ones. We fear that the social indicators will be used to standardize further areas and to draw more competencies to the European level. After many years of cohesion policy, the competitiveness of the Member States has hardly adjusted and has not improved. While some of the stronger countries could afford additional rules and thus costs, the weaker countries or even smaller companies often cannot. While industrial companies from stronger countries could then benefit because their competition is weakened, the call for more intra-European transfers and a higher burden on the taxpayer, for example with a European unemployment insurance or other stabilization elements for the euro zone, is likely to follow. If the EU weakens the competitive zone of individual states, it must also take responsibility for it. And that's exactly what we don't want. The EU must respect the principle of subsidiarity. The nation states themselves have to take responsibility for their social concerns - for better or for worse. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Madam President, I would like to argue with you a little, because according to all the studies and economic reports, it is not rich countries that can afford high levels of social benefits, but some countries have become rich because they have a high level of social benefits.My question: Did you recognize this connection?

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I come from a country - Germany - that implements parts of these social pillars quite well and does not implement others well.I am not even interested in the fact that some countries can decide for themselves, as is necessary for them.What I am primarily concerned with is that we do not need a European solution for this, but that we respect the principle of subsidiarity here and that each country must remain solely responsible for its social systems.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I hope you do not take advantage of the fact that we are compatriots to cut me off before the others. - Monsieur le Président, très cher Vice-Président, très chère Madame Thyssen, merci beaucoup. You are going to continue in the langue of Cervantès. It is a joy that the starting gun to build more and better Europe that has been chosen is precisely social Europe. If you tell me it is a coincidence, then better the coincidence. It is very important, indeed, that we now understand that we must once again have a critical mass of citizens who believe in the European project as a project that will serve the citizens - because we are in a moment of crisis, nobody it escapes him—, and obviously to work in the social sphere: Europeanizing the social is fundamental. And for that, of course, what is proposed here is to jointly study the creation of a pillar of social rights. In other words, it is essential to know what being a European will mean in terms of social rights, with those twenty questions that the Commission puts on the table where we will work for an interinstitutional agreement. We are going to define a key aspect of European citizenship. Then other things are said, such as respect for subsidiarity. This will be the case, of course, at the time of putting into practice, of course, the rights, which will be universal and above states, regions and whatever. For which we are building society. It will also be necessary to appeal to solidarity. They say here with good reason: all this costs money. Yes, and have a common defense, too. And have a common currency, too. And with the same right, solidarity, the distribution of temporary funds or not, will be necessary to build a social Europe and ensure that everyone enjoys what is minimally required for one of the most prosperous areas of the world; and for this I must propose, from the point of view of the ALDE Group, three more objectives, and with this I finish.Let's not forget to be effective immediately against poverty.That it is intolerable that it exists in Europe.Above all the great poverty.Second, let us always support mobility as a fundamental right of workers.And thirdly, social policy is much more than employment, in my country, for example, employment is so important.Social policy is to be able to enjoy a decent education, a decent home.And all that, which costs money, is done much better when we are all united, and that is why we will work with the Commission in the most inclusive of the three scenarios.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. -  Sir. Chairman! I would like to start by thanking the Commission for addressing the social issues. And there are really many social problems! There is rising poverty, rising inequality, there is too much unemployment, yes there is extremely high youth unemployment somewhere. But the problems have not just emerged out of the blue. Instead, they have become larger due to the EU's austerity policy and the European Semester. The many demands from there that there must be cuts in welfare, that we must have a higher retirement age and a poorer social security, yes it has social consequences. It has made the crisis much worse for our socially disadvantaged citizens. Therefore, I also find it deeply worrying that what has been presented here today consists first and foremost of nice words that have not been followed up by action. There is a need for a clear break with the austerity policy. This means that budgetary frameworks and the constant pursuit of increased labor supply must no longer have priority. Member States must be allowed to invest in welfare and cohesion. If we leave it as it is now, we risk claiming to the citizens that we take their concerns seriously without actually doing anything.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, my Group is of the opinion that the Commission is acting rather faintheartedly in coming up with initiatives on social affairs. You are just looking back at the possible reaction of the Council, and the Social Pillar that Commissioner Dombrovskis presented today proves, to my regret, this discouraging approach once again. There is almost nothing in this document that we could mention as a big step towards Social Europe, which is really needed now. In the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs we are working now on the own-initiative report on minimum income and we will still insist that this fundamental right is to be guaranteed by an EU-level directive. Where the work-life balance initiative is concerned, there are of course very many positive headlines. Then there is paternity leave, five days per year for carers’ leave, four months non-transferable parental leave, and we are very happy that the Commission has finally put forward our proposals in the work-life balance report approved by Parliament last September. We have been fighting for them for a very long time. However, in order to convince European Union citizens that the Commission takes the need to enforce social rights seriously, in our opinion you have to come up with far more ambitions proposals.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, the basis of social rights is centered on the euro zone, which it should be remembered that it is very weakened by high poverty and an unemployment rate two points higher than that of the non-euro zone. It is motivated, in your opinion, by a competitive social market economy and the need to overcome the crisis, but it is above all motivated by the advance of Economic and Monetary Union, to the detriment of national specificities. In certain publications, you therefore go so far as to question the performance of national social systems. You are thus promoting supposedly benevolent tools, such as the harmonization of social security systems and gender equality through the reconciliation of public life and private life, but that does not hide the reality. In France, a still privileged country, two people from the same household must now work to obtain the same income as one person 20 years ago. Your alleged conquest of women's rights is in fact only the recognition of an economic and family obligation, not necessarily a choice or fulfillment. Let us therefore let women choose their professional life, according to their studies and as they see fit; let's not force them.

name: David CASA
text: - Illum għandna dokument quddiemna li se jkompli jgħinna biex nibnu Evropa aktar soċjali. Naqbel illi, sabiex dan l-eżerċizzju però jkun suċċess, għandna bżonn ikollna sforz komuni bejn l-istituzzjonijiet kollha Ewropej, l-Istati Membri, l-imsieħba soċjali u dawk kolldan li qħandom. Il-poplu qiegħed jistenna li aħna naġixxu u naħdmu fuq leġiżlazzjoni li jkollha impatt poţittiv fuq il-ħajja kwotidjana tagħhom, u li nfittxu li nibnu Ewropa aktar ġusta billi nsaħħu d-humenħhaħ illi naġixxu b'din it-tip ta 'politika. Irridu ntejbu u nipproteġu, iva, il-benefiċċji soċjali u l-kompetittività, li kontinwament taddatta għal dinja li qiegħda tinbidel b'rata mgħaġġla - każijiet particulari huma t-tipi ta 'impjiegi li a nona fpaglent f'pajjiżi membri Europe. Irridu fl-aħħarnett nimmiraw għal Triple A rating fil-politika soċjali, u allura dan nistgħu nagħmluh billi ma nħallu lil dadd barra f'dan id-dibattitu importanti li għandna bejnietna, għaliex aktar ma jkun hemm aktar ikollna suċċess f'din il-politika li qegħdin nippruvaw nibnu flimkien.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: - Mister President! To start on a positive note: it's good that social affairs are at the top of the agenda, good that the compatibility of work and family is finally being legislated - for that I thank the Commission. But do you really think that's enough for people? Do you really believe that this is already the “triple A” for a social Europe? We have great, pressing challenges in Europe: increasing inequality, poverty, globalization, digitization and demographic change. And from my point of view, what is now on the table is not enough for that. Europe needs more than a non-binding social etiquette - the twenty principles that the Commission has put down are very good in terms of content, but most of them are already written down somewhere. We Social Democrats expect concrete legislation to improve the social situation in Europe; a framework directive for decent work, a child guarantee to combat child poverty, a binding anchoring of social policy in the European semester - and that must apply to more than the euro zone. Otherwise Europe will drift further apart. Please convince the Member States, Commissioners, that they are going with you, which I support in principle. But we need to do more than talk about it. We have to act concretely, we need concrete legislation to improve the situation of the people in Europe - the workers. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Thomas MANN
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you, Mrs Steinruck!There were just a few messages about what the European Commission should do and what it should not do.But that is not the right approach.The Commission says it wants to take care of occupational health and safety, to ensure that we have contracts that are really humane, to ensure that we have common rules to fulfill what Jean-Claude Juncker meant when he said:European Union needs a social profile.Isn't that exactly the right approach, and isn't it completely wrong to say: Not enough, it doesn't get across at all.We don't need a department store catalog.We need priorities.I mean, the Commission did, didn't it?

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- The Commission has listed what would be good and useful.It calls on the Member States - that is how I understand it - to go along with this.But the most pressing problems of a European labor market with the uncertainties, with the unresolved solutions that a European labor market needs, with minimum standards that apply to everyone, are not on the table yet.I hope they will come.Consultations don't get us anywhere.I expect a timetable for concrete legislation.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! On the surface, the creation of a new pillar seems interesting, but when we look closely, we will notice that the European Union is very diverse, the Member States are at different economic levels, and therefore they struggle with various problems. Therefore, I believe that a harmonized social policy will not be a policy that will actually support those in need. We need changes that will give us effective results. And I would like to give you an example of such good practice. In Poland, we have been implementing the "Family 500+" program for a year, the costs of which in 2017 amounted to 1.5% of GDP and which are definitely a heavy burden on the budget. If we took steps for the European Union to co-finance such pro-natalist activities from the European Social Fund, we would certainly have a very good effect. The result of this program, Mr. Chairman, is this number - 96% of children in Poland have emerged from deep poverty thanks to such a good program. It is worth following us.

name: Maria ARENA
text: question "blue card".- My question will be very simple.You talk about harmonization and indicate that you are opposed to it.I think that here it is not harmonization that is proposed, but a minimum, minimum standards, and the search for convergence.Are you also against convergences in Europe in terms of minimum standards?

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam, I thought that your interest would be directed to inquiring about the details of a very good program, the Family 500+ program, which is a clear, strong support for Polish families.If you really wanted to know the details of this program, you would understand that the European Pillar of Social Affairs could support families, not only in Poland but throughout the European Union.It is worth imitating this and I definitely believe that social policy, family policy should fall within the competence of the Member States.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Given that we are somewhat behind schedule, we will not be able to accept more than one "blue card" question for each speaker.Especially when, in this case, a member who is also from the same political group has asked to intervene.Therefore, it will not be accepted.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the proposals that you bring to us today are a clear example of how the firmness you have left to defend sanctions and political impositions on sovereign countries always lacks when it comes to presenting proposals that serve the interests of workers and peoples. The relentless truth that reality will demonstrate is that the strategies presented, supposedly of a social nature, are nothing more than leveling instruments under the framework of the rights of workers and peoples. In fact, the proposals in the maternity portfolio are an example of this. They throw in this Parliament's proposals to extend license periods and license payments without loss of remuneration, they run like hell from the cross of any reference to public policies or the provision of free services. It is your political options that feed inequalities between men and women and social inequalities, as a guarantee that the mechanisms of exploitation and impoverishment of workers and peoples are perpetuated.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, you said that this Commission proposal is a pretense.Do you consider that it is not necessary to have a social pillar in our strategy, do you consider that it is not good to come now with answers to the Commission's proposal, to connect this social pillar with cohesion policy?Is it good to generate generations of the poor?

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- Poor generations are being created at the expense of policies that the European Commission, the European Union and the majority of this house have been adopting, which in recent years have increased the number of people who are insituation of poverty and social exclusion.It is the policies of the European Union, macroeconomic policies, that impede progressive development policies in the Member States and social development policy, that attack public services and the public service network that advocates, for example, motherhood, that destroypublic services and that lead to the privatization of these services.These are the policies that are also behind impoverishment.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner! You have built a great and powerful house with this European Union, with a solid pillar of the European internal market, with a common European currency on a common foundation of values. But this house lacks a central pillar to build a protective roof on. That is why many people in Europe are in the rain at the moment. And not just in Portugal or Greece, but also in supposedly rich member states like Germany or Great Britain. These people are therefore beginning to question the foundations of our home. And there is only one way to protect this foundation of peace, democracy and human rights: by finally building a roof for this house - on a pillar of social rights. However, what you from the Commission have put to us is not a pillar, but a shaky buttress. This support pillar will collapse with the next shock. I want to live in this European house for many years to come, and that is why I, together with millions of European citizens, depend on a Commission that builds for longer than the next gust of wind.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - Europe must protect. Protect against economic malaise, against terrorism, against tax injustice. Hard measures were necessary, but they also created an image of a cold Europe. However, you are proving today with the proposal that Europe can and must also be warm. I would like to highlight two things. Firstly, in my country Belgium, many of those social principles are actually already largely acquired rights. But in many other countries this is not the case. And I cannot stress enough that better alignment of social rights in Europe, from East to West, is the only guarantee of a strengthened market in the long term. Second, no one is more convinced of the necessary role of the social partners than I am. I expect openness and responsibility from them. Gone are the days of releasing balloons and whining about an antisocial Europe. Now is the time to talk to each other at the table. And a constructive spirit, give and take, is courageous. And you are brave, Commissioner, as this proposal proves. If everyone around the table had half of your persistence, then this pillar becomes a real social home.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - We are asking ourselves, what do our people living in the European Union need? Do they need more social Europe? We will get an unequivocal answer - yes. People need normally paid work, people need social guarantees, people need normal, dignified pensions in old age, people need opportunities to support their children, to put them into education, to help them with a foundation in life. And let’s ask, can we guarantee that today? Yes. Europe is not homogeneous: some countries can do more, others can do less, but that is why we are here to have certain minimum social standards in all the countries of the European Union. They are simply necessary in the name of our common family in the European Union. Commissioner Thyssen, thank you from the bottom of my heart for the proposed legislative proposal on reconciling work and private life. It is truly the result of our long work together. As rapporteur for the own-initiative report to the European Parliament on reconciling work and private life, I thank the Commission for taking into account the European Parliament's proposal that we need nursing leave to care for family members, such as people with disabilities. There are already 5 days a year - not much, but this is the beginning. Thank you very much for the fact that we offer paternity leave, paternity leave - 10 days and partially paid. This is already good, because in some countries of the European Union they exist, in others they do not. This means that we will have a minimum basis in which, in all the countries of the European Union, the birth of a child and the father will have the opportunity to contribute to the child's upbringing. And finally, I am very happy about one more thing, that during parental leave, 4 months will be the responsibility of the father, 4 months - the mother. And it will be partially paid. Thank you, but we will still have a lot to do together.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, you say that you want to incorporate principles and social rights into new realities. But how do you define the new reality? because the German press wrote that for working parents the Commission wants to promote part-time work for up to 12 years. Is that the goal of the pillar? increase underpaid part-time work and undeclared work? If you want to support working parents, take out of the fridge the proposal for a directive on two-week maternity leave, introduce paternity leave, promote unpaid overtime and more structures for the creative employment of children.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: - Mister President! I am addressing the European Commission and, in particular, Commissioner Thyssen. I would like to expressly rate the proposals published today on the European Pillar of Social Rights as positive. Second: social security and social fairness as the basis of social Europe. A starting shot has been given to shape the changes in the economic and working world under demographic change for the benefit of people. Thirdly, I am proud that this political thinking comes from the European People's Party, because we must by no means leave social Europe to the left in this House. Social utopians already made negative statements yesterday - they didn't even know the suggestions. So, my conclusion is: no knee-jerk rejection, constructive cooperation across party lines with maximum determination, involvement of the social partners. I am confident that with determination we can shape a social Europe for the next generations - young and old. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Becker, I would be very much interested if you could explain what the difference is between left-wing maternity and right-wing maternity. I have to say that in Estonia, for example, we have a government where we work together, Social Democrats and Christian Democrats, and together we have developed a maternity package which includes 18 months fully-paid maternity or paternity, with no left-wing or right-wing. Both wings are needed in order to fly!

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I didn't limit myself to the maternity issue.I have generally stated that we can use this line - to shape a social Europe in such a way that we can use a social Europe without violating subsidiarity, i.e. while retaining national responsibility for employment policy in the national labor market and for social policy in the national EU member stateDeveloping Europe further, and these Commission proposals are exactly the same.We will work on this constructively, but also critically, especially with regard to national sovereignty, and very intensively in the Employment and Social Committee, and I am fully prepared to do so.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, social policies are really important and I wish to congratulate and thank Commissioner Thyssen for the 20 principles that you have presented. The focus on gender equality, in particular, is very, very welcome, and also the access to the labour market. On the issue of work and life balance, I also think that it is really important that you have recognised the shared responsibility between men and women in childcare. But I do think that legislation and implementation should be at national level. I welcome that you made it clear that subsidiarity is your guiding principle. Why? Because wages, working time, pensions, parental leave and unemployment benefits are a national competence. Why are they a national competence? Because family law and labour law are better dealt with nationally. It is not that we do not care. It is that we have to do at European level what is best dealt at European level and it is more effective because we have different systems. So I do hope that the Commission will stick to better regulation.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Undoubtedly, the most important and effective element ensuring a high standard of living for EU citizens is the employment policy. Only a well-functioning economy can provide sustainable, good-quality jobs that underpin stability and prosperity for European families. However, the role of social policy should not be completely neglected. These two areas are intertwined and it is the task of the Union to set certain minimum standards in this regard as well. Maternity, paternity and parental leave, long-term care for the elderly, work-free time balance and a number of other issues are important daily issues for millions of our citizens. I am convinced that the Union should commit itself to developing good solutions in this regard. However, attention should be paid to the great diversity of national welfare systems, which depend on many factors and have developed over the years and based on the specificities of individual Member States. For this reason, the principle of subsidiarity should be respected with particular care when developing the European Pillar of Social Rights.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Mr President, there is no doubt that the social dimension should be at the same level as the economic or monetary dimension. The future of the Union is at stake and that is why we must ethically strengthen citizens. This Community framework for social and employment policy is extremely important in creating a solid European project targeting vulnerable sectors. We must defend the principle of equality, the principle of non-discrimination, equality between men and women, the incorporation of people with disabilities into all social sectors, active support for employment for people with disabilities and also support for your families. As I said, we must fight against discrimination against all groups that suffer exclusion, such as LGTBI people and others. Fair working conditions must also be negotiated, with social protection and fair pensions. There is no one-size-fits-all model, but there are principles that unite all Member States. The principle of the Union is at stake and that is why, to the Commissioner, to the Commissioners, all the support for them to regulate this social and political framework, this European social pillar. It is a necessity, it is an opportunity.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: There are many requests to speak, so we are going to limit ourselves to one intervention by each of the political groups.In addition, there are those who have also requested to intervene in this shift, but who have already done so previously through the "blue card", which is why a limitation will have to be imposed based on this criterion.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the structure of our societies is changing before our eyes while trade patterns and technology cause enormous transformations in our work environment. These shifts lead to both opportunities and challenges. Even though the EU accounts for around 40% of global public social expenditure, around one-in-four of its citizens lives at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In my country, for example, income inequality is alarming: the richest 20% of the population has an income more than eight times higher than that of the poorest 20%. This causes a vicious circle of extreme poverty, social exclusion, precarious health and poor education. The European project was from its inception a bedrock for the economic development of our Member States. It is now time that we reinforce the social dimension of our Union and create a sensible impetus towards 21st century reforms, leading to more inclusive economic growth, job creation and social convergence. This is why I am looking forward to working on the Commission proposal.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I wish to congratulate my Socialist and Democrat colleagues, because we have worked together to push the Commission and Member States to move forward on social rights in Europe, and here it is now – back on the agenda. I am proud to be part of the political group that fights for a true, social Europe.  With the snap general election in the UK, the Labour Party is right to insist that it will maintain the EU’s high social standards, and indeed Britain’s standards must be raised up along with the rest of Europe, regardless of Brexit. So, my party, the British Labour Party, must send out a clear message – a message which so many young people are desperate to hear: we will maintain freedom of movement, we will say loud and clear that we reject a hard Tory Brexit, and we will protect our hard—won European social rights.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I want to thank the Commission for coming forward with this proposal on work-life balance for parents and carers. From a personal perspective, I am especially pleased to see the proposal for paid carers’ leave. Back in 2005 I co-founded the European Parliament Interest Group on Carers with former colleague Kathy Sinnott, and since then I have either chaired or co-chaired that group with some of the colleagues, many of whom having spoken in today’s debate. On very many different occasions the Carers Interest Group has called for a carers’ leave directive and indeed that call has been repeatedly supported by Parliament, and today we have a proposal on the table. Also, Commissioner Thyssen, your proposal on flexible working arrangements should help family carers to find the work-life balance that will allow them to continue to care. Today, we are taking a step towards Social Europe and while we still have a long way to go, I for one am pleased that we have made a start and I look forward to working on these proposals in Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, I consider that it is good news that the Commission is committed to including the initiative on reconciling personal and working life in the social pillar. Mr Timmermans has spoken about the proposal for equal paternity and maternity leave of four months for each parent, and it is something that could be great news. However, he has not spoken about what I consider to be the fundamental key in this matter: are we talking about individual permits, that is, non-transferable, mandatory and remunerated permits? Or are we talking about maintaining the transferability and the non-compulsory nature of the permits? Because it is precisely the transferability between parents that causes more than 90% of the leaves to be assumed by women with a double perverse effect: perpetuating the burden of care continuing to fall on women. Perpetuate discrimination in the labor market. It is urgent to reform the outdated maternity and parental leave directives and merge them into one. But let's keep in mind what the key is: the permissions have to be individual so as not to continue making the mistake that has led us to this situation.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I have to tell you that the proposal for a social pillar has disappointed us. It was not what we expected, and I think there is too great a distance between the ambition they put when communicating it and the reality, after, of what they have presented. There is very little ambition in social protection, practically nothing in wages or working conditions. It does not seem to me that it is the social agenda that we were waiting for. Furthermore, I have to tell you that I get the feeling that you are already yielding to the Council even before submitting the proposal. This proposal exudes a fear that the Council will go, that the Council will not approve. And you limit yourself before even holding the debate. No. Make an ambitious proposal and give the Council the responsibility of having to say no. It is what we would expect, and if they did that, they would have us by their side. And also, about the specific proposal on maternity and paternity leave, I have to tell you that in some things we are satisfied with the proposal, but in others it falls short. For example, if we take paternity leave, practically what they propose already exists in most Member States. Therefore, it does not represent any kind of significant advance. Be more ambitious - I think that's what people are asking of you - and don't be afraid to do battle with the Council. If they give it, we will be on their side.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the so-called European Social Pillar is another attempt to deceive workers, accelerating and generalizing the barbaric anti-labor policy of the European Union and governments, which is already being implemented uniformly by the EU institutions and bourgeois governments in all Member States. profits of monopolies. The twenty actions of the pillar pave the way for the harshest forms of exploitation: generalization of flexible employment in the name of the balance of family and working life, work to the grave and poor pensions in the name of active aging, undermining collective bargaining and minimum wage , intensification and unlimited exploitation in the name of innovative forms of work and to pass unhindered submission to the capitalists in the name of social dialogue. There is no life and work with rights in capitalism and within the European Union. For the working people there is a way: a confrontation with capital and its alliances, to become the owner of the wealth it produces, to live the life it deserves and can.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Mister President! I have now learned that there are some who want a social union with transfer mechanisms, with increased social spending, suitable for crisis countries. And the others say: It's the opposite effect, we don't want to do anything. I want us to try to build bridges. How about the following idea - I've already passed it on to Marianne Thyssen: Can't we convene an EU social convention? But not as a body, as an alibi for discussions, not a body that meets behind closed doors. Exactly the opposite of others: to ensure that they go in publicly, to involve parliamentarians, to involve governments, also to ensure that the social partners are involved. But then, above all, invite those affected and regularly: the people who are affected by unemployment, the people who are marginalized, those who are also refugees, people with disabilities - so that we can create a forum for them. To discuss in public for about a year and a half, to give all the documents outside so that people can feel: Yes, Europe has a social face and we are working to make it work. Whether it is occupational safety or the question of social fairness or labor law situations. If we have that as a basis, then we can make it clear: We want this social Europe, and we want to take people with us. Wouldn't that be an opportunity, Commissioner?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you on the fact that you have finally taken on this social pillar and not just equality of opportunity, gender equality. Women are valuable, anthropologically they are endowed with certain qualities and must be valued. But I want to ask you a question: this social pillar will not be able to have positive effects if you do not correlate it with social cohesion policy, because we must understand that there are absolutely major differences between economic development in EU member states and they will generate, as I said, new generations of poor people. Have you thought about correlating the social pillar with cohesion policy and how? And I strongly believe that we must fight against discrimination based on gender, nationality, religion and political affiliation. We do not have to do politics for political parties, but for citizens, and I really want this to be understood, that there is no life of the citizen of the right, left or center. There is only the life of the citizens.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for those useful comments, this rich debate, the support of so many of you for the proclamation of the European Pillar of Social Rights, and for the support also for a broad approach to social policy.  Let me first address some of the key issues in this discussion. The pillar we launched today is just the start of a process. It is indeed a pillar of 20 principles and values and rights. It is something that we will use from day one as a reference framework to screen the employment and social policy in Member States and at European level, and a guidance, a compass, to guide us to more convergence, to upward convergence, towards better employment and social conditions – also working conditions – for our citizens, and it is indeed more than words, words, words. That is the reason why we immediately proposed and launched today some concrete deliverable proposals for legislation or concrete starting first—phase consultations with the social partners.  Regarding the request of the European Parliament for legislation, and also for a framework directive on decent working conditions, we agree that it is important to ensure that all forms of employment enjoy a minimum set of rights and protection. This is perhaps the main outcome from our public consultation: to adapt the social acquis to the new world of work. I want to reassure you that this objective is addressed in the two partner consultations we are launching: the one on the written statement directive, and the other one on access to social protection. If social partners cannot agree – you never know – then the Commission stands ready to table proposals.
