You have seen now, with the proposal on the work-life balance, that we have the courage and we have the determination to do so.  It is important to recognise that the Commission cannot legislate on everything. In fact, the guiding principle of this Commission has been that we do not legislate for the sake of it. For example, we are not reopening the Working Time Directive: we are issuing guidance to improve its implementation. Indeed, we will proceed on a two-prong approach. On the one hand, we will step up our monitoring of the existing acquis, and on the other hand, we will enhance guidance to help Member States to help enterprises to implement it.  On the work-live balance (I will be short on this because time is running), you will see that we go beyond maternity and beyond childcare. I see in this House that there are different opinions. We have put an ambitious proposal on the table, and I hope for quick and constructive consideration by the co—legislators so that we can soon have a good directive.  We are in the midst of an economic and social transition. The social fallout from the crisis remains present, and the resulting political pressure at all political levels is massive. Above all, this demands a clear and a commonly shared idea of what the European Union can and cannot do in this field. There is an economic, social and political urgency to make the European Pillar of Social Rights a success. First, the economic arguments: we need a modern labour market, we need social protection, and we need education systems to drive upward convergence, and we need to get more and better qualified people into the labour force. This is the way to build resilience, and this is the way to make our economies competitive and our welfare systems sustainable in the longer term.  Second, there are the social arguments. The labour market is a vehicle for inclusion, to improve people’s life chances and to help them to fulfil their potential. The best way to make people feel valued is through a high—quality job. We need to make sure that everyone can participate, and that no one is left behind. Third, there is the political imperative of tackling inequalities. Our political resilience – our resilience too – depends on restoring a sense of fairness, of opportunity, and of empowerment. I therefore count on your support to make the European Pillar of Social Rights a reality. On the reflection paper, the debate on the future of Europe, it is open. President Juncker launched the White Paper on this debate, and we are now feeding the debate with concrete reflection documents. The first one, not par hasard, is on social policy. We will have others on the deepening of the Economic and Monetary Union, on defence, on globalisation and on the financing of the European Union. So the debate is open and we will deliver more reflection papers to feed the debate – and of course we hope, Thomas Mann, that as many people as possible participate in this important debate, and in the one on the future of Europe. Thank you very much, and let us continue to work together.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Strengthening Social Europe is the best instrument at our disposal to prevent populism and Euroscepticism. But the package of measures to create a European Pillar of Social Rights presented today by the Commission is not ambitious enough. We Spanish socialists are deeply disappointed by this declaration of good intentions without binding objectives that will not serve to end precariousness, increase wages, or improve social protection in the Member States. Of all the measures presented today, the only binding ones have been those relating to the reconciliation of family and professional life, something that we value very positively, since we have been claiming them for two years. The proposal proposes, among other things, a paid leave of at least four months for fathers and mothers to take care of their children, as well as facilities for the care of sick relatives or dependents. We will be working hard to see that these measures go ahead, but also so that President Juncker lives up to his promise and comes up with truly binding proposals such as a Fair Working Conditions Directive, a Directive on a European Minimum Income Framework or a decided plan against child poverty.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - In the context of the deep crisis of the EU, a new and effective European social pillar is needed, which will go beyond rhetoric and lead to tangible results. It is an urgent need to conclude a new "Social Contract" between the EU and its citizens. This "Social Contract" should aim at strengthening the European social model, strengthening solidarity between Member States, reducing inequalities at both Member State and citizen level, and safeguarding labor rights and collective agreements. Developing a comprehensive European investment program, focusing on infrastructure and social services, combating social inequalities and unemployment, and tackling the structural imbalances of regions (including the demographic problem) could between society, politics and economics. In the light of the best practices of the Member States and the social partners, it would be desirable to adopt a European regulation setting decent wages and promoting effective and broad collective bargaining. In this context, the demands of creditors towards Greece for further restriction of labor rights are not only atypical, but are also outside the European context.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing.- After the commitments made by the leaders of 27 member states in Rome last March, the European institutions are taking the first step towards the constitution of the so-called "Social Europe".This step is represented by the inter-institutional declaration on the European Pillar of Social Rights.The document sets out essential principles and rights for the labor market and welfare in the twenty-first century, which we believe should be more attentive to the needs of the "excluded" from globalization.The pillar stipulates that in the Union there must be equal opportunities for work, study and learning for all, that gender equality and ethnic-religious differences must always be respected and that adequate support for employment, especially for young people, is guaranteed.Much remains to be done, but this declaration is the first concrete step to give citizens the answers they have been waiting for for a long time.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The manifestations of "social concern" on the part of the defenders of European capitalist integration are even poignant. But at no time do they question the policies that brought devastation and social setback to us. The EU's social makeup reaches its peak with the proclaimed “social pillar”. The building has proven to be anti-social and anti-democratic - with pillars such as the Stability Pact, European Semester, Budgetary Treaty, Economic Governance, sanctions, etc. - it would finally become “social” through the work and grace of the wonderful pillar. I could almost laugh if it weren't so serious. The said pillar is nothing more than the siren call of those who, in the face of the insatiable contradictions of exhausted and unanswered integration for the peoples' problems (which, in fact, caused and aggravated), cry out for more of the same. As for the substance of the thing, the said pillar does not fit the increase in wages and rights, the defense of collective contracting or universal and free public services. It is up to the defense of the harmonization of labor and social legislation (read: its leveling below), in a logic of facilitating the circulation of cheap labor in the single market. The legitimacy of precariousness and the “social” principle of the user-pays in accessing public services are up to the task.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. - One of the original principles of European integration is working together to continuously improve the living conditions of citizens. The European Union, thanks to the fact that it combines the potential of 28 economies and human resources from 28 countries, is able to offer its inhabitants economic and social benefits that states would not be able to generate alone. Therefore, I would like to emphasize that I supported the idea of ​​the European Commission from the outset of creating a Pillar of Social Rights as a framework and as a guide for carrying out the necessary reforms at the national level. The proposals and future actions of the European Commission must respect the principle of subsidiarity and the fact that there are still differences in the level of economic and social development in the European Union. We must act extremely carefully, prudently and responsibly when creating the European Pillar of Social Rights. Remember that good-quality jobs and a high level of social security come from economic growth, which needs access to financing, flexible labor markets, well-educated workforce and limited bureaucracy. We must provide these elements first! In this context, I positively evaluate the proposals presented by the Commission on combining work and family life and the public consultation that has been launched. All employees, regardless of the contract for which they are employed, should be provided with adequate social protection and receive written information about the terms of employment. Future solutions must, however, take into account the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - I have a number of reservations about the proposal put forward by the European Commission, despite the fact that the goal to be achieved is very desirable: an inclusive, social Europe. However, the sovereignty of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity itself must be borne in mind in this case in particular: the Member States know best how these objectives can best be achieved. I can illustrate this with a number of measures that have already been implemented in Hungary, which we can be proud of: 90 percent of young children eat for free three times a day, and disadvantaged children also get food for free during school breaks. Significant progress has also been made in raising the minimum wage over the past 25 years. Progress is also made by the fact that Hungary is also at the forefront in terms of institutional placement and long-term care, as in the near future large people living with disabilities (3500-4000 people) placed in large rural institutions will be relocated to smaller housing units. As responsible consideration of Hungary's open economy and competitiveness is essential, only prudent, secure progress can be a precondition for further stable and predictable development - we are sure to be partners in this process.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - Its social pillar is a document of good intentions that does not go beyond current European legislation. This Parliament called for the ratification of the European Social Charter revised by the Member States and the possible accession of the EU itself, as a means to provide itself with a social pillar worthy of the name. On the contrary, his proposal does nothing more than mask the Troika's policies in the euro area and its frontal attack on social rights and collective bargaining. It does not even incorporate any firm proposal on social dumping, a proposal for a Minimum Income Directive, a boost to European social dialogue, the EU's accession to the ECHR (despite being provided for in the Treaties ...). In the end, the only legislative proposal that is announced today is the extension of parental leave, something that we certainly defend against the European employers, without forgetting that it was the Commission itself that eliminated the proposal to extend maternity leave. But Europeans have voiced, vote after vote, their strong criticism of the neoliberalism that permeates European politics. It is time for a change of course that cannot be delayed any longer.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. - The EU leadership is full of bilingualism on social rights in the EU, social rights that are being brutally violated due to policies of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. In fact, the situation in Greece has now exceeded all limits. Thus, in the seven stone mnemonic years, the Greek economy disintegrated and the country was transformed into a vast social cemetery, with a loss of 25% of GDP and absolute numbers of over 47 billion euros, with cuts in salaries, pensions and taxes exceeding the 63 billion euros, with the public debt from 123% of GDP that was before the memorandum to finally skyrocket, since according to the IMF itself will climb in 2017 to 184.7% of GDP !!! Seven stone years in which 40% of the Greek people became impoverished, the unemployed exceeded 1.5 million and thousands of shops were locked, with thousands of our young people leaving abroad, since the unemployment rate of young people is 15-24 today at 45.2%. In addition, the dissolution of labor relations, mass redundancies and the sale of public property are promoted, with particular emphasis on PPC, the country's lignite reserves and hydroelectric power plants.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - Social Europe was abandoned by Brussels. With social and fiscal dumping, the coffin of social gains has been nailed down. The “European Pillar of Social Rights” seems to have the laudable objective of putting social issues back at the heart of European policies. In reality, this vague concept is a statement of principles or good intentions. Commissioner Thyssen confirmed this to us in writing: "The Pillar does not aim to harmonize the situation in the Member States, but rather to express a number of principles." Far from the concerns of citizens, the Commission offers us the pincers and a social cover-up. We do not believe in the unification of social systems in Europe. The differences are too dramatic between the countries: the (gross) minimum wage in Bulgaria is 235 euros against 1,480 euros in France (source Eurostat, February 2017). We reject a race to the bottom. In the name of “fiscal sustainability”, Brussels aims to challenge social gains in each state. We call on the Commission to focus on improving its own performance.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - The proposal on work-life balance creates a number of new minimum standards. Two aspects that I find extremely important are the new standards for raising a child and care leave. This is extremely necessary, especially for countries with endangered populations, such as, unfortunately, mine - Bulgaria. I also strongly support the proposal for a more flexible approach to working conditions for parents of children up to the age of 12. This is an initiative that responds to changing work patterns and will both give workers more flexibility and enable them to achieve better economic results for businesses. Today's more flexible employment agreements provide new job opportunities, especially for young people, but can potentially lead to new insecurity and inequality. In this regard, I sincerely hope that the ongoing consultations with the social partners will help to find the right approach to a good balance between social security and growth potential. I believe that the proposals made today by the European Commission are in the right direction and I support them. I call on the Member States to take adequate measures for legislative initiatives that will contribute to better working conditions for workers.

name: Anne SANDER
text: in writing. - Social Europe has for too long been considered the Arlesian of the European project. Today, the Commission offers us a promising social pillar which must become the glue of our common market. We cannot put our companies and our employees in competition without establishing fair rules, without guaranteeing prospects for improving living conditions for all. Europe is currently seen by the most vulnerable workers as an instrument for lowering wages and working conditions. It is time to redefine a minimum base of rights that preserves our welfare states. These welfare states, born after the war, make the European Union unique in the world and are the basis of peace in our societies. The rise of tensions in Europe and the rise of populism are symptoms of the erosion of our social protection and of the feeling of injustice which arises among those who lose their jobs due to unfair competition and social dumping. This social pillar must therefore become the promise of a Europe which truly protects its citizens and pulls everyone up.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The ongoing thrust to put social concerns at the heart of the European project is welcome if belated. Since 2008, the EU has increasingly focused on the task of reinforcing its economic structures, no matter what the human and social cost. This has fed populist and extremist ideologies. Making the social pillar meaningful is going to be hard. It will need to go beyond collating pan-European policies and setting them up as remote signposts for future implementation. What has happened with the social goals set for 2020 should serve as a warning. Expectations should not be inflated beyond what can be attained. Within set priorities, resources must be mobilised to really implement goals. Then, there is the challenge of facing up to the way by which under EU rules, economies and public budgets react to downturns. Especially in the eurozone, the major policy tool is internal devaluation. As experience has shown, this undermines social cohesion, creates hardship and at best brings about a slow recovery that leaves people with a lower standard of living to what they were used to previously. Will the social pillar be robust enough to counter the effects of internal devaluations in European societies?

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - Social policy is an important element in reducing disparities among citizens. That is why it is so important to support all active forms of cooperation, especially nowadays, full of dynamics and changes in societies, and with the current realities on the labor market. Concern for employment and decent working conditions undoubtedly requires strengthening social dialogue and intensifying cooperation with social partners. In the European Union, we are dealing with a diversified social structure and with different characteristics of the labor market, and thus with different social needs. That is why decisions influencing the raising of social standards should be analyzed and taken primarily at the national level. The exchange of experiences of individual countries in such areas as the protection of workers' rights or the development of family policy will strengthen cooperation and, as a result, will translate into constructive steps at the national level. In areas as sensitive as the lives of citizens, initiatives at EU level in the area of ​​social rights should mainly be based on coordination of cooperation. The full use of employees' potential is possible with a properly balanced private and professional life. However, the EC initiative on guardianship rights still requires careful and comprehensive analysis.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. – I welcome the long-overdue legislative and non-legislative proposals put forward today by the Commission on the European Pillar of Social Rights and the reflection paper on the social dimension of Europe. I sincerely hope that today we are breaking with austerity. The broader debate on #FutureOfEurope should not be about new speed(s), but about a new direction, which should be a social one. Contrary to what the Commission suggests, however, I believe upward social convergence is in the interest of ALL MSs and EU citizens – better standards only for the Eurozone or a coalition of the willing is simply not an option, as it will further fragment the single market and labour conditions throughout the EU. While making the Social Pillar a reality will require the efforts of Member States, EU institutions and social partners alike, the Progressive family will continue to push for our flagship initiatives such as establishing a Child Guarantee, which were not reflected in the present proposal. The urgent need for economic and social reform prompts us to spare no effort towards reducing economic imbalances by promoting investment and actively supporting the creation of growth and decent jobs with strong social rights throughout the EU.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- Thank you to the European Commission for today's presentation.I think this is one of the major projects of this term.I welcome your initiative to reduce the disparities between the Member States in the social field, but I think you have set yourself a rather difficult task.Today, we pay the most attention to family leave at the birth of a child, ie maternity and parental leave.The changes you are proposing are acceptable to me and I therefore welcome them.In Slovenia, childcare leave lasts a total of 260 days, ie more than 8 months.So we have a much higher standard in my country, so these proposals do not bring about significant changes.However, many countries are not enthusiastic because their standards are significantly lower than ours.We need to understand that too.It is necessary to find the right balance and, of course, encourage citizens to decide to start a family.After all, our future and the future of Europe depend on it.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - I support the active forms of cooperation in social matters proposed by the European Commission, aimed at introducing a balance between the work and private life of EU citizens. I also positively evaluate the postulates aimed at strengthening the social dialogue, tightening cooperation with social partners, concern for employment and working conditions. The ambitions of the European Commission to expand the circle of people entitled to guardianship rights to include relatives of dependent persons are also noteworthy, but require careful analysis. I believe that - apart from the European Union - the Member States also have an important role to play in the area of ​​raising social standards. Progress in this area may ensure further deepening of cooperation within the internal market and the effective implementation of the growth agenda. The smooth functioning of the European Pillar of Social Rights will be ensured by the exchange of experiences and good practices in the development of family policy, migration policy and the protection of workers' rights.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the discussion on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Turkey, with particular reference to the constitutional referendum. Today's discussion is of particular importance. I want to remind you that the European Union does not in any way want to close the door to the Turkish people, who remain a friendly people with whom we constantly seek dialogue and openness. At the same time, we cannot turn away from actions that go in the opposite direction to the values ​​that are at the basis of the European construction. Freedom of the press, freedom of expression and separation of powers are essential fundamental rights for those who want to enter the Union, just as the death penalty represents an insurmountable red line. I also want to remind President Erdogan that Europe is not an Islamophobic continent. Millions of Muslim citizens live in Europe, who have full freedom to exercise their faith and who are not discriminated in any way. As sanctioned by article 17 of the treaty, the European Parliament with the other institutions actively promotes interreligious dialogue and the many initiatives in which authoritative leaders of the Muslim community have participated bear witness. Tomorrow I will meet the Grand Mufti of Egypt, the highest Islamic religious authority in his country, in this Parliament. I hope that such a strong and convinced dialogue between different religions will also develop in Turkey and I hope that Istanbul will remain the city of two thousand mosques, two hundred churches and twenty synagogues.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all thank you for your introduction and clarification. Our relations with Turkey unfortunately have still not reached calm waters. You have all seen the news coming from Turkey even today, and many of you have commented on it. We have stressed on many occasions that it is Turkey’s sovereign right to let its citizens vote on whether to have a parliamentary or a presidential system. However, the constitutional reform and the circumstances in which the referendum took place are a matter of concern, for three reasons. First, we share the very serious concerns of the Venice Commission with regard to the proposed constitutional changes. This is something we stated clearly before the vote. Once the constitutional changes are fully implemented, Turkey will move even further away from European standards, especially with regard to the separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary. Second, the Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights of the OSCE has noted that the vote did not take place on a level playing field. The two sides did not have equal opportunities to campaign. Turkish voters were not provided with impartial or balanced information about the amendments they were voting on. Also, the ongoing state of emergency has curtailed fundamental freedoms that are essential to a genuinely democratic process. The final OSCE/ODIHR report will be published in the next few days. It will now be crucial that all allegations of irregularities on Election Day are addressed through transparent investigations. It is always essential that democratic processes are fair and free; but this is even more crucial when deep constitutional changes are at stake. Our constitutions define the common rules of the game: if these rules are not recognised and accepted by everyone, the whole system becomes weaker. Third, the electoral campaign has left Turkey’s population deeply divided. The two sides disagree about the fundamental direction in which they would like to see their country move. The close referendum result makes the need to seek a broad consensus all the more important. I clearly see this as a way forward. Accusations and rhetorical aggressions flourished between the two campaigning sides within Turkey, but also between Turkish representatives and international actors. It is in the interest of Turkey to mend such an internal division, and it is in the interest of everyone to engage more constructively on the international arena. The cooperation between Turkey and the Council of Europe is of paramount importance and has produced some results already. This work needs to be carried on and further deepened. We continue to encourage Turkey to address the Council of Europe’s concerns and recommendations, including with regard to the State of Emergency. Security and fundamental freedoms can go together and must go together, in the interest of all Turkish citizens. The question at stake now is what this means for EU-Turkey relations and their future. The time has come for an open and friendly discussion with Turkey about the future of our relationship. We will have a first opportunity after the referendum to exchange views on the way forward together with the European Union Foreign Ministers at the Gymnich meeting in two days’ time in Malta. We therefore look forward to hearing your views and will be very interested to hear your interventions. I think you will contribute in a very concrete and precise manner in the ongoing debate.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! If we are discussing relations between the European Union and Turkey today, then we have to look back a little further - at least to the coup of almost a year ago, when Erdoğan himself and thousands of Turkish citizens opposed the military, bravely democracy and defended the freedom of the country and thus kept Ataturk's words alive; I quote: “Political power that relies solely on cannons will not be sustained.” Perhaps back then, in the days after the coup, we did not pay enough attention to the developments, to the struggle for freedom and democracy too little appreciated. Already at that time, unfortunately, Erdoğan gave God's impression that he would use this coup and the developments afterwards to maintain his power. The defense of freedom and democracy would actually have been the start to lead Turkey into a new phase of democracy and the rule of law. Unfortunately, we now experience that the opposite is the case. We all know what happened and what happened next: 40,000 people arrested, 100,000 fired from public service, 170 media outlets closed, 100 journalists in prison, and more than 1,000 police officers fired last night - one another massive intervention. Now the referendum. The OECD with clear statements on this: Fairness was not guaranteed. Democracy is not only practiced if you count the numbers, if you properly count the election papers, but democracy also means that fairness already takes place in the media process. In this respect, Erdoğan has now achieved his goal, but the price he is paying is a high one: Turkey is now a divided country, the economy has suffered massive damage, and many friends have been insulted encountered, the external relationships are damaged. Now we have to discuss how to proceed. Dear friends, In view of the situation in Turkey, there is no such thing as “business as usual” for us. Unfortunately, Erdoğan's path closes the door to partnership with the European Union. Turkey is going in the wrong direction. Everyone has to see that who opens their eyes. It's time to reevaluate and clarify the relationship. And I would also like to answer the question that the Commissioner put to us: From the point of view of the EPP Group, full membership in the European Union is no longer realistic. We must now end the lie that prevails in relationships. I even believe that one can even go so far that the promise of enlargement that we made in 2004 caused more damage than it used. On the Turkish side, I have seen many partners in recent years who have told me: Your offer is not really meant to be honest. The EU will never accept us. It's a promise that was never meant to be honest. And that has led to anger and rejection in Turkey. And in Europe? In Europe, I have to tell you that Boris Johnson distributed flyers in the Brexit campaign where he portrayed Turkey, Syria and Iraq as possible future EU member states - it was a lie, but the fear that this Europe would have no borders is unsettling the people in Europe. Therefore, we should end the lie of full membership of Turkey now. The Council needs to have such a policy discussion. Donald Tusk as Council President has to travel to Ankara. We have to talk to each other about how we will shape future relationships, and the basis for the future partnership is honesty - to describe what is possible, but also what is not, and also to clarify our position: We do not want to close the door. The EPP Group wants to make an offer.The customs union, for example, the customs union plus, which the Commission has already proposed - perhaps we can also expand it: more economic cooperation, opening doors for students on visas, improving exchanges for people - yes, we say yes to that.We will also have to work more closely together in the fight against terrorism, against ISIS and so on.In terms of refugee policy, we have shown that sectoral cooperation makes sense - that both sides see the benefits.We want to go this way.We need a restart of relations, of the partnership with Turkey on the basis of honesty, and that means ending the accession talks and opening a new chapter in sectoral cooperation.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the referendum result last week in Turkey shows that democracy is not dead. On the contrary, despite the unfair electoral environment, the intimidation of the No campaigners and the massive control of the media by the government, half of Turkey’s population showed that they are ready to push back for the democratic future of their country. The EU must fiercely support those forces. The international observation mission was clear in its assessment: this was not a fair election. The controversial decision of the electoral council to allow last-minute on-stand ballots to be counted in also raised serious questions about whether these elections were free. I therefore welcome the Commission’s stance that it will insist on an independent investigation into the alleged irregularities. But 16 April was also a sad day for all democrats because it is clear that, with such a Constitution, Turkey cannot become a member of the EU. As I stated in the draft annual report I published today, the EU should officially suspend the accession process if the constitutional changes are implemented unchanged. Having said that, we have to be vigilant that justified criticism of Erdogan’s policies does not turn into anti-Turkish sentiment, as we sometimes, unfortunately, see in this House. There are millions of people in Turkey who do share the same European values and millions who do want the EU to remain the anchor for reforms in their country. I therefore do not agree with those in this Parliament who want to scrap Turkey, once and for all, as an EU candidate country. In Turkey, changes are possible in the future and I continue to believe in a joint future for Turkey and the EU. But I am also realistic and acknowledge that this is unlikely to happen under the current political leadership in Turkey. Even if talks are suspended, Turkey-EU relations remain in our joint interest. Cooperation should therefore continue in several areas. However, that cannot be a value-free transactional relationship only, where human rights and democracy are no longer important. To achieve this, we can use the economic power of the EU as leverage for promoting reforms in Turkey, for instance, by adding clear political benchmarks to the upgrade of the Customs Union.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, let us be honest today. Across this House most – if not all – of us share concerns over the current direction of the Turkish Government under President Erdogan. Maybe some speakers today will try to out-compete each other in their condemnations, or even – as the previous speaker said – their insults. Yes, we all share concerns over press freedom in Turkey. Yes, we all share concerns over the treatment of the opposition and the conduct of the referendum; and we all share concerns over President Erdogan seeking to grab more executive power for what has, up to now, been largely a ceremonial presidency. However, many in this House also realise that, at times, we need to work with Turkey. We need to work with Turkey when it comes to controlling the flows of refugees and migrants and we need to work with Turkey on regional security as an important member of NATO. We need to work with Turkey as we share concerns over issues such as Russian aggression. So, in reality, we are talking about a difficult balancing act and this balancing act needs two things. Firstly, we need to be honest with Turkey that it may never be a member of the EU. There are too many concerns: prejudice against a largely Muslim population; a landmass which lies mostly in Asia; the prospect of freedom of movement for millions of Turks; the prospect of voting weights in the Council and here in this Parliament; and an EU external border which would be with countries such as Iran, Iraq and Syria. Secondly, we need to have a more robust and critical relationship between Turkey and the EU.  But in seeking both, the EU has to ask itself: is the EU ready for the consequences of Turkey possibly opening its borders with Greece and allowing people to transit to the EU, and of President Erdogan seeing himself being pushed into the arms of countries such as Russia or Iran? So, while Turkey is not ready for EU membership – and it is not even ready for visa liberalisation – completely turning our back on Turkey is not an option. This is why the ECR Group welcomes calls for a different kind of relationship with Turkey. It will be a difficult balancing act requiring much diplomacy. It may be a more difficult relationship, but it will be a more honest relationship – more cautious, more critical, focused more on cooperation and no longer on the distant goal of EU membership.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am not going to repeat what has been said on the situation in Turkey; I think that we have a common assessment, Commissioner. What is more important is what you have asked us: what our view is in the light of the Gymnich meeting. Together with Mr Weber, I have published a common op-ed article, you could say, on that in a number of newspapers, because I think it is critical now to go into a new cooperation and to make a new proposal to Turkey. I think that we have to stop accession negotiations. In fact, they are no longer accession negotiations; they are in fact suspended – not formally suspended, but, in fact, suspended. The only thing we are doing is still paying EUR 650 million every year for the pre—accession process, and it does not help these people in Turkey, journalists, or civil society in general. On the contrary, I think that continuing this so-called not formally suspended ‘accession’ is a cover-up that even makes it possible for some people in the Turkish authorities to further clamp down on civil society, on journalists, on the opposition, and so on. Our proposal is to reconsider that and ask: why not do what is in the Treaty? The Treaty says that we can make association agreements with neighbourhood countries. Why not make a new association agreement and propose to Turkey such a new association agreement where you have two chapters: one chapter on economics, trade, Customs Union (we could propose an offer of an upgraded Customs Union, even further than what is on the table now); and at the same time, the second track, if on the Turkish side they open civil society, they agree to restore democracy in a certain sense. I do not want to call it a ‘Helsinki Process’ and to make a comparison to the strategy we followed with the Soviet Union (your remember that), but, in a certain way, that is what it is: a two—track approach. We should then use the EUR 640 or 650 million to help civil society there as a part of such a new strategy. That seems to me the new – even broadly supported – way forward that you could give as a message to the Gymnich meeting on Saturday.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! The referendum result is not a brilliant victory for Erdoğan - it has deeply divided the country. We are now calling for the reorientation of EU relations with Turkey, and it is finally about offensive support for Turkish civil society. Mr Weber, anyone who leaves almost half of Turkey out in the rain by breaking off the accession negotiations is at best acting naively or irresponsibly. In the case of the customs union, where economic interests are at stake, nobody talks about demolition. It is Erdoğan who wants to provoke a break in the accession negotiations and to market them domestically. We do not want to participate in this business. Now let's finally ask for stop signs in the right place. First: Refugee funds instead of dirty refugee deals. Second: no arms exports to Turkey. Third: Troop withdrawal of soldiers from NATO partners, and fourth: Let us now lay a foundation for the dialogue to strengthen democratic forces and let us call for an end to the reprisals against the opposition, the independent media, the Kurds and women.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, right now is really the time for the European Union to send a very clear message to Turkey, to Erdoğan specifically, and we all agree that we cannot continue business as usual. But it is also a very important time right now to talk to the 49% who have voted ‘no’ despite all the threats, despite the very unfair procedure and despite lots of people being put into jail. Our message to them has to be: we will not leave you alone. We will continue to engage with you, we will continue to support you – and by ‘us’ I mean the European Union, but also the political groups, and also us as individual citizens. We are responsible as the European Union to use the tools that we have in our hands to help those people. We do not have so many tools in our hands, but I think there is one very important one, and that is the Customs Union, because that is something that Erdoğan wants, so we really need to use that one tool we have in our hands, and by using it I mean let us not upgrade it right now. We should not upgrade it before there is substantial improvement on human rights. Questioning the accession talks or ending the talks might seem like the easy answer, the rapid answer, but it does not mean that it is right or effective. I think this would only help Erdoğan and it would close the door to the people we want to support. Let us trade the symbolism for real action, the real action is not the Customs Union. So friends in Turkey we will not forget you in these dark times.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a 51% victory, with two and a half million contested ballots and many even validated without stamps. A juridical Frankenstein with an abnormal centralization of executive power in the hands of the president, who will be able to revoke ministers at will, be party leader, declare a state of emergency, as well as dissolve parliament at his discretion, without counterweights. Thanks to censorship, purges and abuse, Erdogan has fulfilled his secret dream of becoming the de facto sultan of Turkey, scoffing at our recommendations and tearing his country in two. Never before is it evident that the door we had kept open so far has been violently slammed in our face. Erdogan smiles thinking that the weak and cowardly Europe, which has signed the illegal agreement on migrants at the price of 6 billion, will close its eyes once again. Will it also take the first death sentences or will you finally have the courage to block the candidacy and pre-accession funds and send real support to Turkish civil society, perhaps using the lever of the customs union? Being a member of NATO is not enough and does not justify. The time for small talk is over.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! At the latest with the outcome of this constitutional referendum, it will be clear: We do not want to negotiate a day longer with Turkey about membership of the European Union. When I say: we don't want to negotiate for a day, it doesn't mean suspending the negotiations, it doesn't mean temporarily freezing them. It means breaking off these negotiations once and for all. After the outcome of this referendum, it is also clear that we will not continue to pay a euro to Turkey. I am talking about hundreds of millions of taxes that are being worked out here in Europe and then used against us in Turkey. We do not want to tolerate a policy in Turkey against a minority, the Kurds, that is absolutely unacceptable. We do not want to accept, Mr. Hahn, Minister of Enlargement, that we in Austria have the problem of dual citizenship, illegal dual citizenships, and that politics in Austria are being made against the interests of the republic. Your Foreign Minister Kurz runs around the boulevard in Austria and says: We are in favor of breaking off the negotiations. You are a party colleague of his in the ÖVP: I expect you to act accordingly and put an end to these negotiations.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Mr President, it is unacceptable that the European Union still considers Turkey a candidate country for membership. Turkey is a state completely foreign to the principles and values ​​of European culture and despises any notion of civil liberties. Especially after the referendum, which turns this country into a modern form of caliphate, it is imperative that not only the negotiations but also any kind of aid to Turkey be stopped and that it be treated as it really is, a state of unrest. with expansionist aspirations against all its neighbors and a factor of instability in the wider region. To confirm what I support, Turkey proceeded yesterday to a total of 71 violations of the Greek FIR. There were four air battles and two vessels of the Turkish Coast Guard violated Greek territorial waters, while at the same time Erdogan threatens to flood the whole of Europe with illegal immigrants. I therefore call on the European Parliament to push for the complete and final cessation of accession negotiations, the cessation of all funding and the imposition of sanctions against the Turkish regime, as the current situation targeted by Erdogan is beyond irrational and hostile to Greece. Europe.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, my colleagues have already expressed many positions and presented elements related to the development of the Turkish regime, which shows how problematic it is.In this regard, we are embarrassed about the definition of relations with Ankara.I would like to express my concern about the dissemination of Mr. Erdoğan's model in Europe because here and there some people have made Mr. Erdoğan a political model.In this regard, I would like to recall that during the Arab Spring he himself tried to pose as a model.These are, for example, countries such as Bosnia and Herzegovina - where Mr. Izetbegović, the leader of the Bosnians, sees Mr. Erdoğan as a model.Among the social democrats, the Romanian Prime Minister, Victor Ponta, has a real admiration for Mr. Erdoğan and presents him as a reference.This spread of "Erdoğanism" as a model worries me a lot.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, the referendum is a significant turning point in modern Turkish political history since Atatürk. This so—called reform and the latest developments in Turkey are downgrading all the many important steps that this country has taken in its modernisation and democratisation process, steps that have contributed to making Turkey stronger, more prosperous, and a highly valuable partner of the Euro-Atlantic family. The months of campaigning before this vote cannot be considered as free or fair, and the Opposition and international observers have pointed out irregularities in the vote itself, which have to be investigated. The outcome of the referendum can only deepen divisions within Turkish society. As I said, I have concerns about the path Turkey is taking today, and I have – and I will – express them without hesitation every single time this is necessary, but the way forward is in the hands of the Turkish people. Europe has made errors with regard to Turkey, and these earlier strategic mistakes have to be acknowledged. There are those in this House who are taking advantage of the errors being made by Erdogan today to give them a good reason to stop the process. This should be recognised. There was high cynicism in this room. But I will just say that, whatever partnership relations we design in the future, we have to consider the strategical nature of our relations. I am referring to security, regional stability, the fight against terrorism, and, most of all, maintaining a mutually beneficial dialogue with Turkey in the future.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Madam President! The reflection that we are hearing here today from the Commission and from colleagues in the European Parliament about the wisdom of including Turkey as a candidate country is unfortunately a little too late and far too little. It is very clear when we look back at the development that Erdogan has brought Turkey into that he has very strategically used the EU accession negotiations to weaken the canalist traditions in Turkey, especially the Supreme Court and the military influence that has held Turkey on a western course for almost a century. That is why it is also deeply worrying when we look ahead, both to the situation in Turkey, where we see judges, lawyers, schoolteachers, universities, the media - all threatened by Erdogan's fundamentalist view of how to run a state, but also here in Europe. The behavior of the Turkish President and his government towards European countries, such as the Netherlands, Belgium and Denmark, was deeply unacceptable to any nation seeking a friendly relationship with Europe. In particular, the indirect threat to the Dutch, where Erdogan listed the number of Turkish inhabitants in the Netherlands and the number of soldiers in the Dutch army, was the closest we come to a shameless direct threat to a European democracy. Therefore, the time has not come for us to reward Turkey. The time has come for us to show Turkey that the behavior they have shown should have a consequence, also on the trade front. That is why I hope that we will take this as an element not only to suspend the accession negotiations, but also to allow consequences of such behavior towards European friendly allied nations.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, Mr Hahn, the question you have raised is very important: 'what should we do?', And the question that arises is what message should the European Union send to Turkey today? Is there a better time to decide what the message is, given the way the referendum was conducted? The statement that talks with Turkey should be stopped and that we should continue the negotiations on the customs union, I think, probably makes President Erdogan laugh, because it is like saying to him: "What bothers me to get into the kitchen?" The European Union's customs relationship with Turkey gives Turkey exactly what it wants and it does not matter if the negotiations are suspended, if at the same time we move to an update of the customs union, which is exactly what it is looking for, given that an existing customs agreement does not serve it in all Member States.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: - Madam President! In my post today, I would like to turn to all those who in Turkey and the diaspora voted no in the referendum. Despite all the difficulties and obstacles, states of emergency, prisons, silenced media, unequal economic conditions, etc., you still managed to reach almost all the way. You were 48.59% of the voters who voted no. You gave a very strong and clear signal to Erdoğan that his attempt to dismantle democracy in Turkey will not be a walking victory. Democracy is not dead in Turkey - not yet. You have shown that, not least young people and people in big cities have done so. However, the changes will not take effect tomorrow. A number of political decisions are needed on the way there and a general election in 2019. We Democrats must stand up for each other, and we will stand by your side during this difficult time. Erdoğan is in itself an elected president, but he has shown more and more clearly with each passing year that he does not share our view of democracy or our core values. We in the EU must be as clear to him as you have been, and that is my message to the Commission.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, the recent constitutional referendum in Turkey signals the end of democracy. The result in itself was highly dubious, given the accusations of electoral fraud. But even so, a large number of Turks voted against democracy and in favour of a form of dictatorship. Now that is bad enough, but what is interesting and highly disturbing are the voting figures for Turkish citizens living in Europe who had an overseas vote. Despite a narrow majority being achieved overall, those Turks voting in Europe voted by large majorities for Mr Erdoğan’s proposals. In France and Germany that was over 60%, and in the Netherlands, Austria and Belgium, that was over 70%. So in Turkey while half the voters chose to vote for democracy, those Turks living in Western liberal democracies voted by a large majority to abolish it. Perhaps those Turkish voters living in Europe might vote for a form of Islamic authoritarianism in Europe, given the chance. The logical conclusion of this vote is that those Turks living in Europe who voted for dictatorship and against democracy should have the courage of their convictions to live by their decision. They should migrate back to Turkey to enjoy the benefits of what they just voted for. And what if Turkey’s bid to join the EU had been successful? That application was supported by the EU, and in the UK by the Conservative, Labour, Liberal Democrat and Green parties. MEPs from those parties always voted in favour of Turkish accession. Needless to say, only UKIP MEPs voted against it. If Turkey had joined the EU, then we would now be faced with an interesting situation. You would have one country, Britain, trying to leave, and you’d have another country, Turkey, that you would want to expel. I just wonder if that would take as long as the Brexit process.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Madam President, I would like to highlight an event that took place yesterday in Turkey - one of many.In the town of Diyarbakir, six churches, including one more than 1,700 years old, were seized under the pretext of urban redevelopment.This seizure is part of a policy where Christians are systematically persecuted or displaced in the Near and Middle East.Mr. Erdoğan, this is Islamist totalitarianism;Mr. Erdoğan, it is the support for terrorism of the group “Islamic State”;Mr Erdoğan is however your privileged partner here in the European Parliament.What are you going to do with this economic deal that you are going to get out of us?What are you going to do with visa liberalization?Commissioner, rather than assaulting you and your friends, Mrs Le Pen, you had better keep your lessons for your friend, Mr Erdoğan.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Madam President, the developments in Turkey after the referendum testify to the continuation of anti-popular policy and authoritarianism. These developments are part of intra-bourgeois, intra-imperialist contradictions and rearrangements in the region with rivalries from the United States, the European Union, Russia, wars in Syria and Iraq, with some capitalist states, imperialist centers and monopoly groups in control gaining control. markets, sources and energy roads. This is also the case with the customs union in question. Whichever sections of the bourgeoisie prevail, the people will pay a heavy price. In addition, the provocative movements of the Turkish bourgeoisie in the region, the disputes of the Greek borders, are a very dangerous development and show that the rivalries of the bourgeoisie of the two countries, starting with the so-called geostrategic upgrade, puts the people in great adventures. The peoples to draw conclusions and intensify their common struggle based on their own interests alone.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, Turkey is experiencing a worrying situation: a polarized and divided society, the extension of the state of emergency after the attempted coup and also, Madam President, an assumption of powers, as the Commissioner has reminded us, very worrying since the point of view also of the Venice Commission. I believe that, in this context, the High Representative and the European Union have reacted in a weighted way, taking note of the results and, as Mr. Kamall said, we have to combine this situation with the fact that we have an important migration agreement for 6 € 000 million and with the fact that Turkey is a member of the Atlantic Alliance and of course also an important actor for regional security. I believe, Madam President, that we have witnessed a very rapid deterioration in relations with Turkey and, therefore, Commissioner, we must carefully monitor the evolution of the situation in the country and the President's intentions to review relations with Turkey. us, as well as the announced consultation on the reinstatement of the death penalty.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Madam President, I actually belong to a political group, the Social Democratic group, which has always offered Turkey a path for its accession to the European Union. We have been great defenders of a Turkey within Europe. And for that reason, it is more difficult for me to express, at this moment, the pain and indignation that Erdogan is insisting on closing this door between Turkey and Europe. For many years in this House, the right wing has opposed Turkey's accession to the European Union in various ways, and we have defended its accession. But Erdogan has gone too far, no doubt. And now it is very difficult to defend what we defended. However, I am reluctant to let us close the door completely. Because - as my colleagues have said - there are 49% of Turks and Turks who, despite the difficulties and with an almost impossible campaign, have said "no" to Erdogan, to a constitutional change that is not a constitutional change , is practically a change of political paradigm in the country. So I want to keep both doors open. On the one hand, that of the very clear message to Erdogan: that he cannot continue on that path. And, on the other, towards the 49% of the Turkish people who have said no to Erdogan, because we are here to continue offering them a possibility in the future of access to the European Union.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: ECR). - Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, it is with great relief that I have heard you today say all that I have been trying to say for eight years in the one minute that I have from time to time with many other colleagues on Turkey. It is really impressive to understand in the European Parliament after so many years what we have been living for so long. Of course, when it comes to upgrading the customs union, the question is what upgrade will we make when the existing agreement is invalid! Turkey has not signed it with the Republic of Cyprus. Will we continue the same mistakes and errors of the past again? At the moment, Turkey is encircling Cyprus with its navy, conducting real-life exercises close to the coast, conducting illegal explorations within the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus, intimidating, pursuing a policy of intimidation and threats, and at the same time demanding four European freedoms for Turkish citizens in the Republic of Cyprus. In other words, it is trying to occupy the Republic of Cyprus with the legal settlement, because the European Parliament is not reacting, the European Union is not reacting.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Madam President!Developments in Turkey with the amended constitution are worrying.Nevertheless, developments in Europe are worrying, as Turkey exerted political pressure through certain domestic Turkish groups to promote the election campaign ahead of this referendum.It follows that it is of the utmost importance that the EU ensures that Turkey can account for the exact amounts that the EU assists Turkey with, so that these funds really go to help the migrants and refugees staying in Turkey.In addition, it is important that the European countries make it clear to Turkey that we can never accept Turkey holding Europe hostage at the expense of migrants and refugees or by mobilizing citizens of our respective countries.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, there has been a phenomenon for many years that I do not hesitate to call 'Euroconformism', ie the obedient approval of all clichés issued by the European political mainstream. This phenomenon is best seen in the relationship with Turkey. The recent referendum, no matter how contested by different groups, was a democratic exercise, we must acknowledge that. The accusations of lack of democracy and human rights violations are, unfortunately, marked by hypocrisy. The truth is that in Turkey the regional and historical context does not allow the application of the same standards as in the West. As a result, Turkey has never really wanted Turkey to join, and the Turks know that. President Erdogan's virulence is not the cause, but the consequence of Europeans' attitudes. On the other hand, it is clear that the European Union has ceased to be an attraction for Turkey. That should make us all think, and now Europeans are the ones who need Turkey the most. If we take our head out of Euroconformism, we will see the reality clearly.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: - Madam President! Let's see how it really is. President Erdoğan has developed from Turkey's former beacon of hope into the gravedigger of democracy, the economy and Turkey's accession to the EU. Now we have to think about how to deal with it further. We actually know, and we can be so honest, that Erdoğan himself has not wanted to join Turkey for a long time. For years he has vehemently forbidden our interference in what he calls "internal Turkish affairs". His goal has always been absolute rule, and he has almost achieved that with the referendum - with his new Frankenstein constitution. I think that's a brilliant term. It doesn't come from me at all, but it's important to me to quote it here. We must therefore put an end to this unworthy theater of accession negotiations. That's perfectly clear; we don't have to wait for the death penalty to be reintroduced. As soon as this new constitution, approved by the referendum, is in force, we must end the accession negotiations. At home, nobody understands why Turkey continues to receive pre-accession aid from the EU, and we can only end that if we end the negotiations as a whole. Of course we need an alternative. We don't want to slam the door. We offer cooperation on a different level.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S & amp; D). Madam President, the result of the referendum has shown that, in the end, President Erdogan does not have complete control over the Turkish political scene, as many different forces opposed the referendum on presidential supremacy and almost half if not more citizens voted no. In order to normalize relations with us, the state of emergency must be lifted, the detained MPs and journalists must be released and the mass persecution must stop. For our part, we must keep open all channels of communication with Turkish society, as you emphasized just yesterday, Commissioner, and in no case abandon the most important tool of institutional intervention in the neighbor's developments, which is its accession process. We owe it to those who in difficult circumstances dared to say no, but also to those who may have voted for a savior leader, but who do not forget their European dream. Also, to keep alive at all costs the refugee agreement, which has stopped the flow of migrants to the Greek islands, especially as most Member States do not keep their relocation promises.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I have three short remarks on Turkey. First, concerning the referendum, I believe that we should respect the result of a popular vote, as we do in other cases. If the Turkish people decided to change their parliamentary system to a presidential one they are perfectly entitled to do so, and there is nothing undemocratic as such in this decision. However – and this is my second remark – we should express some concerns vis-à-vis the state of freedom and democracy in Turkey, regardless of the results of the referendum. Turkey, of course, has been facing tough times, with an attempted coup, the war in Syria, PKK terrorism and parallel structures, but those situations cannot justify restrictions in the field of freedom and democracy, particularly when it comes to oppressing the academic world and state institutions such as the judiciary. Last, but not least, let us be very fair concerning negotiations on EU accession because there are countries that openly express their unwillingness to accept Turkey as a full member of the EU at any time, and Turkey should be told so.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, Turkey has been and is an important ally in NATO and a partner in resolving the migration crisis.The EU-Turkey agreement is valid and I dare say that it works.The strengthening of presidential powers proposed in the referendum won a majority, but a very close one.And President Erdogan should realize that he does not have a strong mandate for such fundamental changes.I would also like to call on the Commissioner to start the European Commission discussing a new form of cooperation, as Manfred Weber, President of the European People's Party, has said here, on sectoral cooperation.I would like to call on President Erdogan to prove that Turkey can be a politically democratic and pluralistic country, and also to work for a fair trial for the two young Czechs who are imprisoned and awaiting trial, so that they are tried fairly andacquitted because they are innocent.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I have been to Turkey four times since the coup last year and, each time, I have seen a deterioration of democracy and civil society, along with a growing culture of fear in cosmopolitan cities such as Istanbul and in the Kurdish communities of Diyarbakir and Nusaybin in the south. The last time I visited, just this past weekend, I spoke with representatives of civil society, artists, the media, opposition parties, trade unions, dismissed educators and public health workers, and minority groups, such as the Armenian community. All were absolutely unequivocal in their belief that the European path is the correct future for their beloved country. It is not the Turkish people with whom we have a disagreement. It is Erdogan and his bloated sense of self—importance and his gross appetite for power. Therefore, we must find a way to support grassroots organisations and particularly the youth who hope for a return to a better democracy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, Mr Hahn, I see that you and many colleagues have realized what Turkey is; what we have been saying here for 2.5 years, that there is no democracy in this country, that this country cannot become a member of the European Union. Union. I see now that you have realized it; that's good! You must also realize that Turkey continues to challenge Greece. It violates the Greek airspace, the Greek territorial waters. Even yesterday and today this work is done. Erdogan is now becoming more and more aggressive with the powers he is gaining. The European Union must send a message of decisive support to both Greece and Cyprus, which are currently being threatened and threatened by the Sultan, who does not even recognize the Treaty of Lausanne. So it is clear - I tell you what I have said other times: It must be made clear to Turkey that the accession negotiations are suspended. End of story!

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, the recent referendum is another step in Turkey's path to authoritarianism. The new constitutional arrangements establish a presidential dictatorship under a perforated constitutional cloak. The press is silenced, prisoners are mysteriously hanged, MPs are imprisoned, invalid ballots are baptized validly and any form of dispute is suppressed. Even more dangerous than the internal developments, however, is Turkey's behavior abroad, with its destabilizing role in the Syrian problem, with the ongoing occupation of Cyprus and with the illegal claims on the Cypriot continental shelf. The latest case is the questioning of the borders recognized by current international treaties with the provocative statement of the Minister of European Affairs that the Greek Agathonisi is supposedly Turkish. The European Union must respond by imposing economic and political sanctions. This is the only language Mr. Erdogan and his henchmen understand.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, after his victory in the referendum, President Erdo .an continues to provoke with greater intensity and frequency. He arrested 803 suspects in the coup yesterday. It seeks to reinstate the death penalty, disputes the sovereign rights of Greece, has sent a research vessel into the Cyprus EEZ, threatens companies that have concluded an investigation agreement with the Republic of Cyprus, has blocked large sea areas in the Aegean and Cyprus for naval threatens to flood Europe and Greece with three million illegal immigrants. Turkey is a country that expresses expansionist aspirations for all its neighbors and is a problem for all of them but also for the European Union. So long as we do not cut the European acquis and the possibility of becoming a member of the European Union, it will continue to provoke, will provoke Germany and the Netherlands by saying that they allegedly apply Nazi methods and will generally show everyone that it is a country that does not can join the European Union.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). - Madam President, Commissioner, it is clear that Turkey does not understand and does not recognize the civilized European language and resolutions. Turkey has proved that the political tolerance of even the European Union, which tolerated for so many years the existence of a European Union member state held by Turkey without imposing any sanctions on Turkey, has intimidated and intimidated Turkey. The only way Turkey realizes that it really applies human rights, principles and values, both inside and outside Turkey, is to impose sanctions. At the moment in the Cyprus issue, Turkey with its uncompromising stance and the unacceptable demands for the implementation of the four basic freedoms, guarantees and occupation troops is essentially undermining and undermining the solution of the Cyprus Problem. At the same time, he sent the oceanographic vessel Barbaros to Cyprus - and it violates European borders - to drill in the Cypriot EEZ. It was essentially given to European companies to do these drillings. I have one thing to say: Turkey's pre-accession process must stop ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, we have a dictator in Turkey and we finally recognize him. As long as they remain in power, dictators do not leave by democratic elections, but when they do leave, humanity, both in Turkey and abroad, will pay a heavy price. So Erdogan refuses to conform to our values ​​and rules, and it is not our fault that Turkey is not being Europeanized. It continues to occupy European territory in Cyprus, to threaten Greece and most recently to threaten the European EEZ of the Republic of Cyprus. Imprisoned journalists, academics and, at the moment we are talking, 100 personalities are in Turkish prisons on hunger strike; 34 are women, 8 are on the verge of death and here I hear hypocritical words. So I end with a question: Will we reach out to Erdogan to save the Turkish economy?

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the result of the constitutional referendum is disappointing for many in this House, while I personally find it liberating.For too long, bilateral relations between the European Union and Turkey have been burdened by the prospect of Turkish membership, and on this basis they have never been fully developed into open cooperation between two equal partners in those fields where there is mutual interest.It does not surprise me that the Turks are tired of fulfilling our conditions and that we are frustrated by the fact that they cannot and to a large extent consciously do not want to fulfill them to the end.It is a country from another cultural and civilizational circle that has no place in the European Union.The Turks know this, and finally after this referendum, those Europeans who pretended to be blind to healthy eyes found out.As much as some may be disappointed, it is not up to us to tailor Turkey, it is the task of its citizens.I hope that we will develop the most fruitful cooperation in the near future.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). - Madam President, we must look at developments in Turkey calmly. Europe wants a Turkey that is a factor of stability in the wider region, firmly oriented towards democratic ideals. After the failed coup, we see another Turkey, with strong anti-European reflexes, with a huge deficit of democracy. Today's Turkey is not a credible Turkey, as the countries of the European Union want it to be. It is not predictable. It is a Turkey that has lost its European vision. Under the responsibility of its leadership, Turkey is moving away from Europe both politically and in terms of values. The referendum turns Turkey into a presidential democracy without the safeguards of modern democracies. The referendum finds Turkey deeply divided. The country needs the widest possible consensus. Its course does not make us optimistic. I hope Mr. Erdogan will surprise us positively.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, indeed, to obtain 51% in a referendum on a constitutional reform in period of emergency, with muzzled media, journalists, professors, magistrates and even deputies in prison - not to mention the frauds electoral campaign - is not an electoral success, to say the least. That will not be enough - this is my point of view anyway - to allow a calm amendment to a constitution and to give almost full powers to a president who would see himself as president for life. Turkey, which occupies a strategic position in the Middle East, must remain an interlocutor of the European Union, but not in defiance of the values ​​which are ours. The European Union must stand up as a defender of the Turkish people and must not cut ties with Turkey but, as Parliament has requested, suspend negotiations, precisely, with Turkey until Mr. Erdoğan has returned. to better feelings. The European Parliament has assumed its responsibilities and the Commission has to take its own.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President! The course and results of the Turkish referendum clearly show the direction in which President Erdogan has gone. Turkey is not ready to become a member of the EU, so it must hear a clear no. That is why I am also drawing attention to the petition of the European Christian Political Movement to stop accession talks with Turkey. President Erdogan's aggressive policies also threaten the restoration of peace in the Middle East. Yesterday's Turkish air and ground attack this morning weakened the position of the Syrian Democratic forces in northern Syria and gives Daesh a strategic advantage. As a member of NATO, does Turkey have a real interest in eliminating Daesh from the political map of the Middle East? But Turkey is also an important and diverse country. Our rejection of the current regime and our rejection of the accession negotiations must be balanced by a clear message in favor of democratic forces. Let us not forget that more than 23.7 million citizens have spoken out against the usurping of power by President Erdogan, and the European Parliament must send a clear signal to these people. We will reject the regime in which you have found yourself wrong, and we will uphold the democratic values ​​that you believe in.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, I very much share the concerns of my colleagues on the results of the referendum as a clear setback in Turkey. Society is split and, more than ever, we have to reach out to the millions of Turkish people who feel let down and abandoned by the European Union. We have to increase, not diminish, dialogue with all levels of society. We should engage with a moderate tone and with less emotion. And, as we continue to condemn torture, mistreatment, the imprisonment of innocent people and journalists and other attacks on free society, it is much too early to jump to conclusions on membership. Why should we punish the people of Turkey? Membership is a long-term process. Of course they are not ready now, but it does not mean that they will not be ready in the future. Which of those Member States of the European Union who joined were ready from day one of the accession negotiations? Please, let us not undermine the civil society and democratic forces of Turkey.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, what we are dealing with, what we are evaluating is not only a constitutional reform in Turkey: it is the transformation of the country's own identity, of the nature of the State. And to do it through a very small - very small - majority, 51%, in a polarized country and after an unbalanced campaign. We have to clearly say to the Turkish Government that this path, the one it is taking, is taking them away from accessing the European Union. And that it is not only distancing them, but also making the path they want to travel impossible, because democratic standards are far from those that the European Union demands. Given this, what to do? Continue the political dialogue in whatever form; if not through the accession process, through other political dialogue tables, and use the great tool we have, which is the renewal of the customs union, to be able to speak politically with Turkey and bring it closer to our standards while supporting the Turkish population.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this debate, for your individual contributions and listening to the very strong, clear and converging points made here in this House today. I am afraid we all concur on one thing: that Turkey is currently moving further away from the European Union, and not closer. That is the reality we have to face. That is ultimately Turkey’s choice. First, it is crucial to help strengthen Turkey’s democracy and the rule of law, to which Turkey must urgently re-commit. Turkey could use the Council of Europe’s decision to reintroduce human rights monitoring as guidance to this end. We wish to help Turkey by remaining engaged with it, by keeping channels open. We must continue to promote the values on which our Union is based, and help those who stand up for them. Concretely, we already do this on a multitude of levels; ranging from high-level political dialogues to our aid to a stronger and independent judiciary, or protection of human rights defenders. We must continue our principled engagement with Turkey and continue doing our part to support the positive currents in Turkish civil society. Second, in the long term, we need to see how we can further build our multifaceted relations and use opportunities together. I take today’s debate as a strong signal from this House that business as usual is not an option at all, but that we must equally not fall into the trap of artificial debates or rash actions either. Yes, Turkey is very important to us, with common interests ranging from geopolitics right down to the many human links. But Turkey needs the EU much, much more – politically, economically and, may I say, security-wise.
