I therefore want us to keep a cool head and together devise a more rational strategy, a format or ‘package’ if you will, that enables us to work with Turkey on the many areas of mutual interest and gives us real leverage to boost democracy, fundamental rights and reforms. Again, we must move away from the status quo, which is only frustrating for both sides. Together, across the European Union, we must send a clear signal that the European Union is committed to continuing an open and constructive dialogue with a democratic, inclusive and stable Turkey, but that we will equally not budge from our red lines. The aim must be to find a future-oriented functioning set-up together, and finally, in close cooperation with Turkey.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- On April 16, the Turkish people, after a very long electoral campaign, spoke out on the Constitutional Referendum.The result obtained, however, highlighted a profound fracture in society.The European Union is now at a crossroads.The continuation of the EU accession talks has become the subject of political bargaining.The EU must move towards an association agreement aimed at improving existing relations and enabling the intensification of political, economic and security cooperation.It takes courage and vision: this is what we are asking today from the Council and the High Representative for the Union's foreign policy.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - The referendum on constitutional reform in Turkey is another and probably the last blow to the republic built by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. The Venice Commission criticized the proposed reforms, saying they contradicted the fundamental principles of separation of powers and did not meet the Copenhagen criteria. Today, Europe is threatened by Erdogan and Putin, who are cooperating and demonstrating closeness with their increasingly frequent meetings. An axis of evil is forming, which is preparing to reshape Syria's borders and also to crush the Kurdish population, which has been fighting for its own state for years. Erdogan encroached on the political representation of the Kurds, ordering the arrests of the two co-chairs and nine other members of the Democratic People's Party. The new sultan fired nearly 28,000 teachers, rectors and students, and recently arrested another 3,000 people who were declared "Gulenists." I believe that the position of the High Representative of the Union and European leaders on the rising neo-Ottomanism is too soft. It is time for Europe to build a strategy to protect our external borders by supporting countries like Bulgaria and Greece, which border hostile Turkey. I also believe that Europe must present a plan to stabilize the region, and not take into account dictator Erdogan and his threats.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. - The result of the referendum in Turkey served to legitimize an authoritarian turn that Erdogan made step by step, implementing a systematic repression of opponents to his government inside and outside the parliament, in the military, against the independent press and the judiciary. The same vote that legitimized the excessive powers of the President, acquired in fact in an undue manner, especially following the attempted coup d'état last July, revealed a victory that cannot be called triumph, but rather is shadowed by well-founded disputes and from the split in the middle of the Turkish people. The direction taken by Turkey, placing it in contrast with the founding values ​​of the European Union, should exhaust all justifications regarding the discourse of its accession to the EU and the disbursement of the European funds it benefits from, were it not for the EU itself it suffers the blackmailing effects of the delegation as controller of migratory flows granted to Turkey. There is no longer any room for the ambiguities of a Europe which invokes fundamental rights, the rule of law and democracy on every occasion but which finances, when it suits it, authoritarian regimes which represent the negation of all this.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- Turkish citizens have chosen a presidential system of government, and Recep Tayyip Erdoğan has thus strengthened his powers.Consolation with the close result of the referendum in Turkey is absolutely useless.According to the behavior and statements of its leader, the country is constantly moving towards a dictatorship.This trend has been noticeable in the actions of the Turkish government, at least since the suppression of the alleged military coup.Religious fundamentalism, widespread political purges, intimidation of the opposition or suppression of freedom of speech cannot be ignored.This must also reflect the attitude of the European Union and its Member States to the situation in the country.No retreat or any defensive approach is in place.Representatives of the Turkish government have long since lost interest in reforms and meeting the requirements for moving closer to the European Union.Instead, they resort only to insults, intimidation and extortion.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - In Turkey, 8,500 police officers raided 81 provinces on Wednesday night. The target was members and police officers suspected of belonging to the Fethullah Gülen movement. 803 people were arrested. Tens of thousands of people have been arrested so far. Journalists, soldiers, police officers, among those arrested are a former MEP elected in Germany as die Linke's candidate, Uca Feleknas. More than 100,000 employees were laid off from the civil service. The alleged organizer of the Gülen coup, requested by the Turkish US prosecutor's office, could be sentenced to life imprisonment and another 1,900 years in prison if convicted. The Turkish air force struck northern Iraq and Syria on the night of April 25. According to the official report, the target was the position of the banned Kurdish Workers' Party of the PKK, which operates in these places. These latest reports suggest that the current regime in Turkey is clearly not a standard democracy. The regime is gradually moving away from Atatürk's legacy in two fundamental respects: it weakens the role of the military, which has always been the guardian of the secular regime, and strengthens the influence of Islam in public life. An analysis of the result of the referendum shows that the strengthening of the president's position was supported by the countryside and backward areas of the country, including Turks living in the second generation in Europe. By contrast, large Turkish cities, developed industrial areas, and the Kurdish diaspora did not support the president.

name: David McALLISTER
text: written. - The approval of a narrow majority of voters in the Turkish referendum was received with great concern in the European Parliament. Changing the constitution would not improve relations between Turkey and the European Union. In its investigation, the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe came to the clear conclusion that this constitutional amendment would give the President a wealth of power that goes beyond the normal extent of a presidential democracy. The Venice Commission is particularly critical of the possible weakening of parliament and the president's authority to appoint twelve of the 15 constitutional judges. Turkey is an important trading partner and ally for us. Politically, it has unfortunately been developing away from our European standards for years. The approval of the referendum further solidified this trend. Despite the current tensions, the dialogue, especially with Turkish civil society, must be continued. Almost 50 percent of the Turks did not vote for the constitutional amendment. We should encourage these people and show them clearly that we want to continue exchanges and cooperation. How the accession negotiations will develop after such a far-reaching constitutional amendment should now be reassessed. In any case, one thing is clear: if Ankara - as currently discussed - introduces the death penalty, this must lead to the negotiations being broken off.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - What is happening in Turkey directly affects the European Union, because as a candidate member, an important trading partner, a regional power and a member of NATO, the country is too important for us to remain indifferent. The adopted constitutional reforms are a threat to democracy in Turkey, one of the Copenhagen accession criteria, and logically a cause for concern among civil society. That is why the European Union must prove to all those who voted against it during the referendum that it will not accept the collapse of democracy in Turkey and will continue to support the promotion of democratic values. At the same time, the EU must continue its dialogue with Turkey on important issues such as migration and the fight against terrorism, but without allowing it to come under pressure from Turkey. Therefore, I hope that the agreement of March 18, 2016 will continue to be respected, because it is in the interest of both parties. I also call on Turkey to adopt the necessary internal changes that will allow the implementation of the readmission agreement in its part for third-country nationals - something that does not depend on the form of government. Last but not least, it is crucial to maintain cooperation and the exchange of information on terrorists in order to prevent future terrorist acts in Europe.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – After a history of clampdown on civil liberties and the freedom of speech and the press, it is unfortunately likely that President Erdoğan will use his slim referendum margin as a tool for even more restrictions of democratic principles and fundamental rights. Already, thousands of civilians and political opponents have been arrested because they questioned the legitimacy of the controversial referendum. In such a situation, our greatest concern should be the fate of the Turkish citizens who still stand up for democratic principles and the rule of law. After having given their lives last year to defend democracy from military dictatorship, Turks find themselves under another autocracy won through electoral foul play. Some of them still look to Europe for help. But we cannot be a credible voice as long as we do not stop deluding Turkey with the prospect of EU membership and be honest towards ourselves on the relationship we foresee with Turkey.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. - I consider the result of the referendum to be just another proof that Turkey does not belong to the EU. President Erdogan concentrates power in his hands and does not respect the basic principles of democracy. It is very difficult to believe that he is the same person who started accession negotiations with the EU a few years ago and started reforms in the country that have brought long-term economic growth. Today, we hear reports of the arrests of journalists and demonstrators, the suppression of freedom of expression and similar authoritarian practices that have no place in the EU. We must find a new form of cooperation with Turkey, based on honesty and a clear statement that the Turks cannot count on membership. We have postponed such a direct statement for years. The result is a single closed chapter in the accession process, frustration in Turkey and an increase in radicalism in Europe. If we honestly tell the Turks that we want to work closely together in trade and security, but don't count on membership, we will get rid of the boulder that pulls our relations down. Finally, we will be able to sit down at a clean table and build our relationships on a new and mutually beneficial basis. I reject the claims of some socialists and idealists that we should give the Turks another chance. They've gotten them in the last decades and have wasted too much.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – When looking at the situation in Turkey, Syria and Kurdistan and the surrounding region, we can see that there are no simple answers. One can be quite sure though, that bombardment of Kurdistan by the Turkish forces, will not benefit anyone in the region. The NATO member, Turkey, should support an independent Kurdistan, as the co-operation between the Turks and Kurds, would be a viable option to de-escalate the situation in Syria and the activities of Daesh. At the moment we face a situation where two NATO members could militarily clash with each other. As the US supports the Syrian Kurdish People’s Protection Units (YPG), and Turkey threatens to keep bombing them, then we obviously have a big problem that has to be urgently dealt with. Independent Kurdistan could serve the global community of states as a great stabilizer and factor for peace in the broader Middle East region.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - The constitutional referendum in Turkey, which took place on April 16, was questioned by the OSCE-ODIHR observation mission as not creating equal opportunities for both sides of the campaign. It is particularly worrying that voters did not receive objective information on key aspects of the reform. On the other hand, the very even result in the referendum shows a deep division in Turkish society. The Venice Commission of the Council of Europe has expressed serious concerns regarding both the content and the implementation of the constitutional amendments. They will be assessed in the light of Turkey's obligations as a member of the Council of Europe and the OSCE and as a candidate country for EU membership, which is therefore bound by the Copenhagen criteria on democracy and the protection of fundamental rights. At the same time, we expect the Turkish government to strive for dialogue with all political and social forces in the country and for the broadest possible consensus in implementing changes. The current challenge for the EU is, first and foremost, to support Turkish citizens in their efforts to maintain democratic standards in their country.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Lambert van Nistelrooij and Constanze Krehl, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the structural reform support program for 2017-2020 (COM (2015) 0701 -C8-0373 / 2015 - 2015/0263 (COD)) (A8-0374 / 2016).

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: reporter. - Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, thank you very much for this opportunity. It was already in November 2015 that the European Commission came with a new and unique European broad support program for structural reforms in the period 2017-2020. I will continue in Dutch, because I prepared my text in Dutch and will read it out carefully. - After the Council and Parliament decided their position and after four productive trilogues between the European Commission, the Council and the European Parliament, we have reached a compromise for the first reading that is now before us. The budget for the program is set at 142 million euros. The budget comes from the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds for technical assistance. During these trilogues, the rapporteurs, Constanze Krehl, and the undersigned, ensured that a number of important principles of practice, cohesion and regional policy are integrated into that new assistance program. Thus, the partnership principle has been incorporated. Not only the Member States have an important role when it comes to structural reforms. Regional authorities - in Spain, Germany, for example - are essential in initiating and implementing structural changes. Therefore, Member States must coordinate with their regions so that support is tailored to those national and regional needs. The spirit of the partnership is clearly captured in the text. In addition, we from Parliament have underlined the importance of transparency. The cooperation and support plan drawn up with the Commission for each Member State concerned should therefore be shared as soon as possible with all, with Parliament and with all interested parties in order to be able to monitor and assess the added value of this support program. Because that's what it's all about. Not yet another separate sectoral program for structural, administrative and institutional reforms. No, a clear link with the support that the Member States already receive and their own responsibility for the European Structural and Investment Funds. Three quarters of the so-called country-specific recommendations are already supported by the regional funds. Consider, for example, the need to continue to improve public procurement in many of our Member States. In the EU, it is therefore about achieving coherence between all these types of instruments and not yet another new fifth wheel. Accelerate together with additional support for broader scope, such as the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering, to set an example. This also increases the effect of the existing instruments and funds. It makes no sense to keep pumping money into regions or countries that don't have their affairs done. Many Member States, regions and cities are still experiencing high unemployment rates and are not absorbing enough of the recovery in economic growth. And those performances in the EU differ so enormously. There are those that are barely developing, there are those that are making rapid progress with reforms. With a helping hand, with this program, member states can quickly give direction to growth and jobs. This support can be provided by means of various instruments, workshops, expanding ICT capacity and the exchange of expertise. I am pleased with the proposal now under way, a unique EU-wide instrument that will give all Member States the opportunity to accelerate the necessary changes in the European Semester. The support program is an impetus for real change and is thus also an example for the fiscal capacity in the euro area in the future. In the execution of the program we find a better balance between the carrot and the stick, so to speak. Not Member States alone punish them if they fail to achieve certain objectives in the Stability and Growth Pact, but also encourage them.Finally, I would like to express my thanks to the representatives of the Maltese Presidency, colleagues, the European Commission and the co-rapporteur of the Committee on Economic Affairs, Costas Mavrides.I also thank Constanze Krehl and all the other rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs.Get started with this new instrument!

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, the more perceptive amongst us will realise that I am not Constanze Krehl. Unfortunately Ms Krehl cannot be here tonight – she sends her apologies and has asked me to speak on her behalf. I am sure that, if Ms Krehl was here, she would want to thank the co—rapporteur, Mr Van Nistelrooij, and all the shadows for their usual cooperation in this important report.  I want to start my contribution by making a general point about structural reforms. I think that too often structural reforms are seen as being only about privatisation, cuts and austerity, but they should not be. Structural reforms should be about positive things and about changing an economy in a positive way. It should be about changing an economy to promote jobs and growth, to promote research and development, and to promote education and training. All these things are important. Those are the type of structural reforms that I think we should be supporting.  That is why structural funds are so important when we talk about structural reforms: structural funds are an investment in all the things I have just mentioned. That is why, in the current programme of structural funds, we have ex-ante conditionalities: to make sure that structural funds are producing results and are achieving jobs and growth. We put in place conditionalities to make sure we promote policies on growth, the environment, gender equality and many other things. These are the type of things we can use structural funds for in order to improve growth across the European Union.  Today, we are talking about using technical assistance to support structural reforms in Member States. This will be on a voluntary basis. Member States can, if they wish, take advantage of this new policy and can, of course, add their own funds to it as well. We should not forget that some of the technical assistance will go towards important areas and important policies, such as education and training. However, we also should not forget that the Commission is proposing EUR 143 million to be redirected, mainly from structural funds, towards technical assistance. Therefore, my group believes it is important that the new reform programmes align with cohesion policy aims, because we are using cohesion policy funds. We also believe it is important that local and regional governments are involved in the reform process so that their needs are met – Mr van Nistelrooij mentioned this in his contribution as well. We also think it is important that Parliament receive the support plans and monitoring reports so that we, as a democratic body, can look at the progress which is being made.  We also believe that it is important, from a budget point of view, that this programme, which redirects structural funds, does not set a precedent for the future. Certainly, we in the S&D Group could not accept the slicing of structural funds to be used for future new programmes and initiatives. If we want new programmes and new initiatives, then we have to find other ways of funding them. We have already seen a cut in the current structural funds programme, and if Brexit happens, the EU budget will be cut in the future as well. There will be less money for all programmes, including structural funds. So those of us who want to protect structural funds have to make this point now. They have to make the point very, very strongly that this cannot be a precedent for the future. We know that structural funds could also be under attack in the future from those who want to reduce the funding of structural funds or want to scrap structural funds altogether.  So I would say, in conclusion, that the S&D Group supports this report. We have been the co—rapporteur, with Mr Van Nistelrooij, on the report. We support it, and we also support the proposal put forward by the Commission and will be voting for it tomorrow, but we would not want to see this as a precedent. The S&D Group believes that structural funds have always been one of the most important policies of the European Union, and should be in the future. We will be fighting to defend them in the future.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. - Mr President, congratulations to the two co-rapporteurs on their hard work and cooperation on this outcome. This proposal is ambitious and aims to serve as a means of technical assistance to the Member States for the design and implementation of their reform agenda if they so wish. Appropriation, ie ownership of structural reforms, is essential for the success of the program. Equally positive in this proposal is that the objectives of the program include ensuring a high level of social welfare, social services, health, education, the fight against poverty, social dialogue and tackling financial illiteracy, among many others. I would like to end with a suggestion, Mr President: a future legislative proposal for an extension of the program will be strongly supported, but it should provide for separate funding and not a transfer of funds from the Structural Funds. implementation of this proposal.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am pleased to be here today ahead of the vote on the Structural Reform Support Programme. It will allow for providing technical support to Member States, upon their request, for the implementation of reforms. These reforms – to modernise economies, strengthen competitiveness, encourage investment, generate jobs and raise living standards – are crucial for cohesion and upward convergence. Such reforms work. We have seen how the countries that embarked on an ambitious reform path, such as Ireland, Spain, the Baltic countries and Portugal, have been able to catch up remarkably ever since and return to growth and job creation. This means less poverty and less social exclusion. Yet, in general, the implementation of structural reforms is not satisfactory. Our assessment shows that Member States have made only between ‘limited’ and ‘some’ progress on last year’s Country-Specific Recommendations. The overall record since the inception of the European Semester in 2011 points to differences in the pace and depth of reforms. We all know that reforms demand political courage. They may impinge on powerful vested interests. Their technical complexity is often a barrier, while others may imply budgetary costs. Some countries face challenges in terms of institutional and administrative capacity. It is not enough to legislate, the reforms need to be implemented in a timely and efficient manner.  This is where the Structural Reform Support Programme can make a real difference. In 2016, technical support provided by the Commission’s Structural Reform Support Service was requested by six Member States: Bulgaria, Croatia, the Czech Republic, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia. We have been able to assist governments with their public finance management, implementation of administrative, judiciary and health-care reforms, development of capital markets and access to finance. In parallel, the Structural Reform Support Service has continued to coordinate comprehensive support for the Greek administration. For example, with the help of technical assistance, in February Greece started to roll out the Guaranteed Minimum Income scheme nationally. This represents a fundamental change of the social welfare system to provide protection to those who have been left outside any safety net. Based on feedback received and numerous expressions of interest, such support is clearly deemed useful, even necessary. But this support cannot and will not replace the role of the authorities, which remain responsible for the reforms, their design and successful implementation. I am happy that thanks to very constructive interinstitutional cooperation, we have succeeded rapidly in accommodating our concerns. I wish to thank the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and all other committees involved for their valuable contributions. I would also like to thank the co-rapporteurs, Mr Van Nistelrooij and Ms Krehl, for their dedicated work, and the REGI chair, Ms Mihaylova, for her constructive and open approach during the trilogues. Together with the outstanding work done by the Dutch, the Slovak and the Maltese Presidencies, we have an improved text that awaits your vote.  The key features of the Programme are as follows. It will have a budget of EUR 142.8 million for years 2017-2020. The scope of its actions is broad in order to enable to support whatever needs are pertinent in Member States. But at the same time, cohesion policy elements are clearly emphasised. The support is to be provided on the request of the Member State. It is to be tailor-made and adapted to the country-specific needs and effected in full cooperation with the government involved. We support the involvement of the social partners and civil society in the preparation and implementation of reforms. Their support is a key success factor. Such involvement should take place in accordance with the legal set-up of each Member State and in compliance with their institutional framework. While underlining the spirit of cooperation and partnership, the administrative procedures remain light, so as to enable delivery of support as swiftly as possible, but always in full respect of the Financial Regulation. We are fully committed to ensuring proper monitoring and evaluation. Transparency is crucial to all of us. Therefore, we will transmit to Parliament without delay the Cooperation and Support Plans agreed with the Member States, and in line with the conditions set out in the Regulation. We will also provide information on the Annual Work Programme, Annual Monitoring Report and independent interim and ex-post evaluation reports. I am confident that the Programme will be a positive instrument to make our economies more resilient. I also believe that the support provided under the new Programme would substantially contribute to the cohesion of the European regions, as strongly advocated by the European Parliament. I count on your support – both now and throughout the implementation of the Programme – to make it a success.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, properly planning and implementing responsible and forward-looking reforms is a difficult task, requires serious analytical, planning and management skills, as well as access to information and adequate human resources, which, as we well know, is unfortunately not available to all countries. . The establishment of a structural reform support program is a very welcome initiative, as all Member States must be given the opportunity to seek and receive support for reforms that contribute to a healthy economic environment, increase growth and employment and improve the living standards of citizens. . I am pleased that, inter alia through the amendments I have adopted in my recommendation on the Employment Committee, the instrument increases its legitimacy and transparency without losing its effectiveness and ease of use.

name: Alain CADEC
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. - Mr President, Commissioner, I was the rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries on the support program for structural reform. Fisheries is concerned through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). This structural reform support program will make it possible to use part of the technical assistance provided for in the EMFF. As such, the Committee on Fisheries is concerned about the possible use of this funding for structural reforms unrelated to fisheries. Indeed, nothing would prevent a Member State from reallocating part of the technical assistance of the EMFF to other themes. The EMFF is a dedicated fisheries fund and it should remain so. The EMFF's contribution to the structural reform support program should therefore be directed towards carrying out reforms linked to the implementation of the common fisheries policy. It will be useful. Indeed, the Member States are encountering great difficulties in implementing the landing obligation introduced by the reform of the common fisheries policy in 2013. They will therefore be able to use the structural reform support program to put in place measures in this area.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, the challenge of this legislature is to bring Europe closer to the citizen and, to achieve this, it is essential to regionalize European policy, to listen more to those who live in our towns and in our cities. And as we go in the right direction, we see that this report certainly does. Thus, with the definition of national authority, we involve municipalities and regions in the European process, because municipalities and regions are the access points to the resources that the European Union makes available to citizens. And we take another successful step by making it even clearer what the mission of the structural programs is and what should always be. This mission is to make effective economic, social and territorial cohesion, and it is also to close gaps, build bridges and bring wills closer together. In Rome we are committed to the European social pillar. A pillar that needs a true European social agenda, an agenda that translates into more and better jobs for all citizens and more and better growth for all regions; In short, an agenda that is a reflection of that Europe that it protects and that is none other than our European Union. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- You started your presentation by saying that you believe that Europe is getting closer to its citizens through this proposal for a regulation.If you could explain how you see this, because I'm afraid, I agree that we need a support program for structural reforms, but I'm afraid we won't take it from one pocket and put it in the other pocket, I'm afraidnot to take from the structural funds and to lead to this program, to which I did not understand how the money will be allocated to the state, according to which criteria, each, if one country asks, given to one country, was not understoodand whether you consider the situation of the Structural Reform Support Program clear.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: "blue card" response.- What I have said, and I maintain, is that European politics must be regionalized.And to regionalize European politics, there are no better actors than the governments of the regions and the governments of the municipalities, of the town halls.This is the idea, because they know better than anyone how to optimize those resources, where to spend that money, when to spend it and how to do it.And this is told by someone who for twenty years has presided over a region, Murcia.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we support this proposal, even if we see all the inherent risks, first of all because it will be the States that will ask for the use of these resources, but above all because we aim to improve reform policy in the context of the European Semester , that of structural reforms on an economic and social level, inspired more by cohesion policy, to reduce the distances in the territories, in the States and above all between the various social components. This is above all the choice we make, also to improve the capacity and recovery of public investments that we absolutely need in Europe. Finally, also in terms of the reform of the public administration, of the state, of the use of human resources, we absolutely need it, we must reform a large part of the administrative machinery to enable it to face the decisive challenges of the coming months and years. to resume the path of development, growth and employment.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club.- Mr President, certain European Union programs are usually make-up of the Community's image in the eyes of citizens, which unfortunately costs taxpayers too much and in turn does not offer any added value.But the structural reform support program is the exact opposite and therefore has my full support.This is a real need because some members of the Union do not have a good institutional framework or administrative capacity to better use European funds and implement key structural reforms that would ensure faster economic growth, strengthening the private sector, new jobs and a sustainable social system.The political will for reforms in individual Member States cannot be unduly influenced by the Commission, but the availability of more money for their implementation will force any responsible government to do something, while exposing those who are irresponsible in the eyes of citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, I must say that I am pleased with this debate because the colleagues with whom I had the opportunity to work in some other political situations while I was the Istrian prefect, Mr. Siso or Mr. van Nistelrooij, who are respectable people from their countries and held important positions at the regional level, or Mrs Bresso, the former President of Piedmont, shows just how much we emphasize the importance of what we are bringing today, that is, what we are talking about today. How important are these structural reforms and the involvement of municipalities, cities, regions in these structural reforms. Because where do citizens live? Yes, they live in the European Union, in our countries, but at the end of the day they live in a region or in a small settlement. And so I think this is a very valuable approach, as we started this debate, and I expect the Commission to recognize all that we are talking about today because this program of support for structural reforms must end somewhere and must end to the last citizen. And that last citizen must feel when we give really concrete help to a country in carrying out structural reform. Croatia has already used the structural reform support program and is a good example. The examples we have with Greece and Cyprus are good examples. This has proven to be good and that is why I am confident that this report will find fertile ground. The amount of 142 million euros may not be excessive, but if nothing else, it can at least start creating some synergistic funds that can be included in this structural reform program. And finally, as a shadow rapporteur, I would like to sincerely thank on behalf of the ALDE Club my colleagues van Nistelrooi and my colleague Krehl, who really did a great job.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, giving support to Member States in the implementation of structural funds and for structural reforms might sound like a very technical matter, but it is in fact deeply political, because, in times of crisis when in some Member States the Structural Funds have become almost the only source of public investment, the way in which this money will be spent becomes absolutely crucial.  Yes, this proposal could have been shaped as a powerful instrument to say to these Member States: you go through difficult times and we will support you. Unfortunately, this chance has been missed. For my Group, this proposal is far too unspecific in the aims it should reach for Member States, and could thus become a tool to impose unwanted structural reforms in the Member States rather than supporting Member States in difficult situations. We would have liked to reach a proposal that would empower Member States in distress, a hope that was unfortunately not met in the trilogues.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are 23 million poor people in Europe, there are entire territories abandoned by the emergency of mass immigration, and what are you doing? Instead of strengthening cohesion policy, rather than strengthening the social pillar, perhaps by investing in citizenship income, what are you doing? You subtract EUR 142 million from cohesion policy to do what? To finance studies and consultancy for your structural reforms. This is not what we need. Your structural policies, with your structural reforms, are those that have reduced Greece, Portugal, Cyprus and Italy into poverty, increasing unemployment and social inequalities. Instead, you have to get your hands off cohesion policy - we therefore do not need studies and advice for your reforms - and you have to get out of the buildings, out of the ivory towers in which you are locked up and listen to the citizens. They will be the ones to tell you what the real reforms this Europe needs.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- The regional hobbies that the ladies and gentlemen perform here are not free.They cost money.They cost a lot of money.And who pays for that?The taxpayer.And Mr President, the Dutch taxpayer is at the forefront, because you know that the Netherlands is still the largest net payer.And Mr President, for that taxpayer I will stand up here, because the average Dutch taxpayer, the average Dutch employee, works until ten past two in the afternoon - you have just returned from your lunch, perhaps I too - he works until ten past two in the afternoon.for the tax.When we talk here about regional funds and what I call these ladies and gentlemen's hobbies, I hope they think of that taxpayer who has to pay all this.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, structural reforms have been around since the beginning of the crisis at the beginning of 2008, so I am happy that we now have that proposal. I would like to congratulate Mr van Nistelrooij for his contribution and for significantly improving this proposal. I am sure it will become a powerful tool in the future, but, at the same time, I have modest expectations because of the limited budget for this proposal. I have several thoughts about the future of this programme. If it is to be prolonged after 2020, it should have a separate budget line and not use cohesion fund sources. It should not replace existing technical assistance programmes that we have under operational programmes, and, in the end, we should use country—specific recommendations to encourage Member States, but not to punish them. Last, but not least, this programme should have an annual evaluation in order to follow its progress.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, Mr van Nistelrooij and Mrs Krehl, on their approach to this report.Europe needs investment to be able to implement policies that reduce unemployment, fight poverty, but also provide adequate social protection and reduce disparities.It is also the reason why the Union has identified a number of structural reforms among its priorities, through which it seeks to give an upward and sustainable trajectory to the process of economic recovery and growth.By their very nature, reforms are complex processes, they must be socially balanced, they must always take into account the needs of the public.Undertaking structural reforms on the ground, especially with the help of local and regional authorities, as well as the social partners, is an essential condition of this program.

name: Sławomir KŁOSOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! The 2017-2020 Structural Reform Support Program in the European Union countries in terms of stimulating economic growth and raising the standard of living is an important document that has a chance to become an instrument for smart growth and improving the use of EU funds. I believe that a necessary condition for the success of the program is its effective coordination with already existing technical assistance programs at the level of the European Union and the beneficiary Member States, and the active participation of regional authorities in this coordination. I would also like to encourage the exchange of good practices between Member States when implementing structural reforms, as there is no one-size-fits-all recipe for the effectiveness of these reforms. Finally, I would like to ask: how does the Commission intend to achieve synergies between the many support programs and what will be the concrete implementation system of the structural reform support program and the issue of voluntary dedication of technical assistance at the initiative of the Member States?

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Let me begin by thanking and congratulating the rapporteurs, Mr Van Nistelrooi and Mrs Krehlova, on this report. Structural reforms are something that improves the situation in the country. It is not enough to receive only cohesion funds, and our key goal is to use these funds so that they do not remain untapped. It is very important how we spend these funds, how we also restructure domestic budgets, so that public spending is as efficient as possible, so that the countries that receive these funds will get out of the development gap as soon as possible. I come from Slovenia, where we also need help to carry out, for example, health care reform, to carry out education reform, so that we do not get staff who are unemployed and have a lack of technical professions. We need public administration reform. And that is what these funds are for. If I say in a parable, it is not enough to have only flour, egg and similar ingredients for good bread, it is also necessary to have yeast. And I consider these funds primarily as yeast, so that the countries will work as well as possible and that the countries will help themselves, without always being dependent on foreign aid.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all thanks to colleagues Krehl and van Nistelrooij for the hard work they have done which, I would say, has allowed us to greatly improve the original text. I believe that Parliament has done a valuable job, giving greater prominence to the social plan and to that of solidarity, strengthening the role of local authorities and regions, which are key players for the success of any type of reform. This program of support for structural reforms can be an important opportunity to help member countries' institutions to be more efficient and effective, but it must be shared with national authorities and territories. Therefore, a voluntary program, activated at the request of the member countries, which is a real help and not a control tool that would go against the principle of subsidiarity. We do not want a kind of mini troika to reproduce in the field of structural reforms. I believe that this program will have positive effects, if used well, and I am satisfied with the work done by colleagues.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). - Mr President, Commissioner, the € 143 million reallocated from the Structural Funds for 2017 to 2020 to support structural change is absolutely necessary to support our countries, and especially for countries like Greece, which is in urgent need of walk the path of reforms. Reforms are, in essence, the adaptation of our countries to the new globalized environment and must be at the heart of the Structural Funds 'design in order to maximize the return on European taxpayers' money. That is why it is so important to explain that technical assistance is provided to the Member States at the request of the government. It is particularly important, on this route, for technical assistance to reach municipalities and especially the regions that manage a large part of the Structural Funds. Finally, it is important to link the provision of technical assistance with performance and efficiency in job creation and not simply with the absorption of funds.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to reduce the gap between the levels of development of the various regions, between the South and the North of Europe, through structural reforms which, by their nature, require a different chain of knowledge and skills, multi-level cooperation and above all a long-term vision. And it is precisely in order to have a long-term vision of the future of Europe that the Mediterranean regions must be placed at the center of the programs to support reforms, because it is where the greatest difficulties are concentrated that action must be taken more effectively. Surely the indications present in the Common Strategic Framework, together with the possibilities of partnership and emergency allocations, go in the right direction, but the experience of recent years teaches us that reforms have a long time of impact, times that some areas of Europe do not they can no longer afford to wait. The Union's efforts need to focus on southern regions, employment, digital and infrastructure. The only way to create a united Europe is to give equal opportunities to all citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, you have talked about reforms, but it seems that you have not assessed the social impact of the reforms, because what we are seeing is that these reforms have a huge adverse effect on the living standards of the citizens themselves. the welfare state, dissolve labor relations. You even mentioned Greece and said about the guaranteed income. Do you know how much it is per month? 230 euros per month, for a family to spend, when Greece was really disintegrated by the reforms of your memorandum, when we have 40% of the population living below the poverty line, when with your memorandum reforms we have 1.5 million unemployed, when we have the poor, when pensions have been cut. These are the reforms you have made! They literally disintegrated the country. And now you tell us about the guaranteed income, which will get 230 euros. How to live? In fact, at the moment when immigrants and especially refugees receive 400 euros a month to be maintained and in fact have housing and heating. This is the Greece that you, as a troika, became with your reforms!

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I greet the Vice President and thank him and his team for a well-prepared regulatory proposal and also to all the rapporteurs for their very high quality work. We have been discussing specific recommendations for Member States for several years now and conclude that they are not being implemented in practice, we are not satisfied with the progress and how many positive developments are actually happening in practice. The reasons for not implementing the recommendations are most often not that the Member States do not know what to do, as it is written in various documents, not only in the recommendations and in-depth analyzes and forecasts and documents at national level, but the problem is how to implement it. what needs to be implemented. There is often a lack of knowledge and ideas and administrative capacity, and that is exactly what we want to help with this program. We want to help to share good experiences and, in addition, to encourage political will based on good experiences for change to really happen.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Instead of revolution, we have evolution, but that's good.It is good that regional funds were kept, good that funds dedicated to local governments were kept.They are best spent there.However, what I want to stand up for today are creative industries, investment projects in education, investments in culture itself.It must be remembered that these investments bring not only splendor, but also a real financial effect.And I would also like to emphasize that in the current perspective, the restrictions on investing in this particular area are particularly painful.First of all, these are restrictions on the amount of financing in individual investments.You have to remember that the area of culture and creative industries is not about investing in highways, which are of course also needed.These are investments that are always different, atypical and require more flexibility.And here I am standing up today.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you much for today’s debate, for your valuable contributions and for your support. As I said earlier, we continue to receive expressions of interest from Member States who count on receiving support as soon as possible. The Commission is ready to activate the Structural Reform Support Programme (SRSP) as soon as it is adopted, and to proceed as swiftly as possible with the following steps: Member States must first submit their requests; the Commission will analyse those requests, ensuring equal treatment; the Commission will conclude the cooperation and support plans with Member States and then prepare the annual work programme, and only afterwards will it finalise all the contracting procedures. On the question which was raised concerning the imposition of unwanted reforms on the Member States, it is very clearly stated in the regulation that this is done at the request of the Member State and not the other way round.  The European Parliament will remain closely involved in the role of the SRSP, and I will be coming back to report on both the first steps and the first results under the programme. With the help of Parliament and the Council, we have an excellent text to seal, so let us continue to work in this spirit of partnership between the three institutions. I therefore call on you to lend your support and adopt the SRSP. This would pave the way for providing the first support measures on the ground already in September/October.
