name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 27 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The program acts as a framework and complement to cohesion policy, but in fact aims to intervene in the internal state structure, giving the interventions (the famous structural reforms) a marked liberal accent.Administrative performance - to improve which, in order to make the structures capable of drawing on European funds, special funds have already been allocated - is in fact combined with support for structural reforms in the labor market, social security, liberalization and privatizationservices, as well as education and training.However, the interventions implemented in this sense in Portugal, Cyprus and Greece have already shown that the effects are not positive at all and, indeed, they have led to an increase in inequality, unemployment and the overall level of poverty of the populations.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. –  I am glad that today we adopted the Structural Reforms Support Programme 2017-2020. This is a great tool to stimulate reforms in the EU countries which in turn is essential for the growth of our economies. Long-term solutions is what Europe needs to provide if it wants to tackle problems such as unemployment and social exclusion. What is key in this process is that the governments who will benefit from this programme understand that their ownership in carrying out structural reforms is irreplaceable if they are to pursue smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The final goal of participation in this programme should be to stimulate investment in the real economy and competitiveness by improving conditions in sectors like taxation, administrative reform, justice, anti-corruption, competition, innovation, education and training. I am glad that the programme gives the opportunity to mobilise expertise across member states and tap on existing good practices. Although this tool uses existing technical assistance resources under the European Structural and Investment Funds it will be an additional incentive for structural reforms in states where national budgets need to be complemented.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - As we all know, cohesion policy is very important for bridging the gap between European regions, supporting job creation, business competitiveness, economic growth, sustainable development and improving the quality of life. This new support program for structural reforms is, in fact, increasing the administrative burden on Member States and taking resources from cohesion policy to use them for some structural reforms imposed by the European Commission, which are not related to economic and social cohesion. I believe that, in this way, by eroding the cohesion policy budget, we are jeopardizing its future after 2020. Let us not forget that sums from the European Structural and Investment Funds to finance migrants have already been reallocated. Moreover, the danger hidden in this initiative is that, in fact, the European Commission is trying to force Member States to implement the structural reforms imposed by the country-specific recommendations, reforms that are not always in the interest of the citizens of those states. And then I ask myself: how can citizens trust the European institutions when they no longer work in their interest?

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I support the program to support structural reforms that we have approved today, because it can provide Member States with an appropriate tool for the necessary economic reforms. I am pleased that Parliament has managed to agree that cohesion policy should be included in the program, which means that it will be possible to support improvements in social, economic and territorial cohesion. It will also be important for the Member States that the program will operate on a voluntary basis - only those countries that request assistance with structural reforms will benefit from it. An important aspect of our efforts is the fact that regional and local authorities will also have to be involved in the reform process. The transparency of the program will be guaranteed by greater scrutiny by the European Parliament, which will be able to assess its added value. As regards specific actions, the Commission provides support under this program for the implementation of (a) reforms in the context of economic governance, (b) reforms related to the implementation of macroeconomic adjustment programs for Member States receiving Union financial assistance, and (c) reforms own initiative to promote sustainable investment, growth and job creation. EUR 142.8 million is earmarked for these activities, which can be used by Member State authorities in the period 2017-2020.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Mircea Diaconu, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Year of Cultural Heritage (COM (2016) 0543 - C8-0352 / 2016 - 2016/0259 (COD)) (A8-0340 / 2016)

name: Mircea DIACONU
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the history of this subject is older, it began in 2011 with a letter sent by several Ministers of Culture from European countries to the European institutions, but they have not reacted for years. The Committee on Culture has had this topic since I have been there, since 2014, on the agenda, and even in one of the previous reports, which I also drafted, and at the suggestion of colleagues in the Committee on Culture, I introduced the need , we talked about the need to introduce this Year of Heritage 2018. And here, at a speed, very recently, the European Council opened this topic and we started to write this report in an emergency procedure. From that moment on, I must tell you, there has been an extraordinary solidarity throughout the Committee on Culture and Education. Not only the shadow rapporteurs, but everyone, I see many of them here in the room now, they are with me, they have been with me, especially in the most delicate point of the development of this subject, namely in the negotiations on which I had with the Commission and the Council. Indeed, they were really with me there, in all the delicate points of the negotiations, and what has been achieved is why I am very pleased today, I am very pleased with what has been achieved in these negotiations, and the cooperation with the European Commission and the Council. it was absolutely remarkable and I want to appreciate it not in the usual Oscar reflexes, but simply it was. That's right, which means that we have the premises, we have on the table the premises of an extremely interesting topic. One more thing to note: in the vote in the Committee on Culture, all the political groups supported this subject, with one exception, which I find really funny, tenderly funny, namely one of the political groups, which usually does this, he opposes everything, he told me that he has nothing against it, but for reasons politicians must vote against. I understand, which probably means that tomorrow's vote will be simple, easy and clear, especially once again that we can understand: culture unites, does not divide, even at this level. From this point of view, what I already love is the fact that, in 2018, we will have the opportunity, and it will happen, to show off, citizens, states, European institutions, associations, structures of all kinds in the field, to we display what we have best in our countries, what represents us as a national identity and the final conclusion of this year, I am very convinced that it will be so, is that the European element will appear in all these national events, which will prove that we are indeed a unitary space, built in many years, even in a thousand years, through a common history, some common experiences, some good, some not very good or unhappy. What is certain is that today we are a common space. This will surely be the conclusion of this Year of Heritage. One extremely important thing I notice, I want to point out, is the fact that it already happened yesterday, it started, even if the report has not yet been voted in the Commission. All European states were invited, they participated, the Commission was extremely prepared and thorough and this topic was practically started. Let's be on time and let's hope that tomorrow's vote won't stop this - let's say - flight!

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me first thank you for your overwhelming support for the European Year of Cultural Heritage which, without the European Parliament, we would not have had this year. Special thanks go to the rapporteur Mr Mircea Diaconu, and to Ms Silvia Costa, for leading Parliament’s negotiating team. Tomorrow, with the vote on the decision to establish the year, we will take a big step towards bringing Europe’s heritage closer to citizens. The year is a perfect opportunity to put Europe’s cultural richness in the spotlight. I am confident that this initiative will help us lead an open dialogue on the shared values that connect us and make us stronger. What is especially important to me is that we use this unique opportunity to reach out to people from all backgrounds, way beyond those who are already interested in and familiar with cultural heritage. In particular, I want to reach out to young people. Cultural heritage is not just about the past. It has a vital role in building the future. Young people therefore have to be at the heart of the year. We will bring this initiative to life through real collaborative work at all levels, from the European, through national, regional and, crucially, local levels. At the national level, national coordinators designated by each Member State will lead the implementation. They had their first meeting just this week on Tuesday. The list of events and activities they are planning is impressive. I am pleased to say that the European Parliament sent two observers to this meeting so you are fully on board and will remain so throughout 2017 and 2018. I will make sure this is the case. We will also implement the year in close dialogue with key civil society organisations which will help us with the expertise and outreach. At the European level we will, for example, launch a specific call for proposals under the Creative Europe programme at the end of this year to fund transnational cooperation projects in the field of cultural heritage dedicated to the year’s objectives; devote resources to organising around 10 flagship initiatives at European level; develop synergies with existing Creative Europe initiatives devoted to cultural heritage, in particular the European Heritage Days, the EU Prize for Cultural Heritage, and the European Heritage label; join forces with other Commission departments which also fund cultural heritage, so that they support the year on top of its dedicated budget and run a communication campaign to give high visibility to our actions. I am particularly pleased that we will be able to give more attention to our flagship initiatives thanks to the extra resources. For example, a project with schools will bring children and young people into contact with cultural heritage, encouraging them to appreciate its relevance and fostering a sense of belonging to a common European space and together with UNESCO, we will promote the European sites awarded the UNESCO label of World Heritage. As actions on cultural heritage receive significant funding from several EU programmes, we estimate that at least a further EUR 100 million will be used to support the objectives of the year in addition to initiatives on budget. These funds will come from the Cohesion Funds, from Horizon 2020 for research projects on cultural heritage, and from other EU programmes supporting the environment, culture, tourism, citizenship and external relations. Honourable Members, the European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018 is a great opportunity to tap into the full potential of cultural heritage. One single year is, of course, not enough to achieve this aim, but it is a good start to pave the way for a long-lasting heritage policy that makes a difference for citizens and helps us build the Europe of the future. I look forward to working with you, with Member States, and of course with our partners from the heritage sector to make this year a success.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Firstly, it is very good that we have this Year of Heritage, that it is.Secondly, it's great that he has financial guarantees - modest, very modest, but they are.Thirdly, it is good that the funds obtained do not come from the Creative Europe program, but are extra funds.We are at the moment when we have achieved half the success.The other half is the implementation itself.Here I would like to appeal not to disperse too much of these funds, secondly, to find a common denominator for these projects, to make this year noticed, and thirdly - I am pleased with the commissioner's declaration that the main recipients of these funds should be the youngestgeneration.In my opinion, it is precisely this that can bring the best investment effect related to the Year of Heritage.I keep my fingers crossed for this project and I am convinced that it pays off to add financial resources to promote the common material and spiritual heritage of Europe.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, honorable rapporteur, I am really happy that the European Year of Cultural Heritage is finally coming to light, for which I also personally fought first as chairman of the Committee on Culture and then with my colleague rapporteur Diaconu and with many colleagues, both shadow and from our committee on culture, also in line with the conclusions of the 2014 report of the Parliament and then with the conclusions of the Italian Presidency, also in December 2014. Thank you very much for your cooperation, of course, the Commission and the Maltese Presidency. We fought in the interest of European citizens, so that through the knowledge and enhancement of cultural heritage - which, I remember, is intangible and digital - the reasons for common values ​​and the concrete possibility of creating bridges and not walls can be found. However, in order for the richness of European cultural diversity to become an opportunity for dialogue and peace, the involvement of the Member States, regions, municipalities and above all citizens, and especially young people in particular, as has been said, is indispensable in building a future of intercultural dialogue and peace. I believe that the opening of the House of European History on 4 May is also at the right time. Already yesterday, for the first time, as mentioned, the Parliament with two of its members participates in the coordination of the European Year together with the national coordinators of the Member States. A message is central to us, that is, the enhancement of the European and transversal dimension of cultural heritage, both through collaboration between the various directorates-general of the Commission and through governance between European institutions, Member States and stakeholders to promote crossborder projects alongside flag initiatives. the Commission and the Member States and the active participation of civil society. IS the result in terms of resources is also significant.We have doubled from 4 to 8 million, of which only half, fortunately, weigh on the budget of "Creative Europe", which this year however has grown, while the other 4 come from other budget chapters.I remember that other programs will participate with calls dedicated to this year.I close by saying that I also share the choice made by the Commission's DG Culture of four axes of activity: involvement, enhancement, protection and innovation.This will finally give a framework to what must finally become a true European policy for cultural heritage that goes beyond 2018.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! Yes it's right. Parliament has been very committed to this European Year of Cultural Heritage. Why? Because we are convinced that it is a great opportunity to bring the tangible and intangible cultural heritage closer to the citizens of Europe. We are showing how great the diversity of cultural heritage is and that culture in Europe never only exists in the singular, but always in the plural. And that it is a great opportunity for many citizens to experience and learn that one has always benefited from cultural exchange and cultural dialogue in European history. There are people who are now questioning that and wanting back to culturally homogeneous societies. I think that's a serious mistake. Therefore, to make it clear how rich European cultural history is, that it is about intercultural dialogue and intercultural understanding, about showing that cultural exchange has brought people together and that they have a richer life as a result, that is the goal of this year of cultural Heritage. The fact that people have the opportunity to really participate in this history of wealth in everyday life changes their everyday life and also their feeling of togetherness in the European Union in a positive way. We show that we have more that we have in common than what separates us.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cultural heritage is a very precious common good and of unique importance. This is why I believe that it should be preserved and valued as much as possible. However, I cannot say that I am satisfied with this agreement, because in the end the agreement that has been reached is reduced to a European advertising spot. This was also confirmed to me by an answer to a written question to the European Commission. Instead, there is nothing concrete. What do I mean by concrete? For example, the possibility of recovering cultural assets that have been damaged by natural disasters. Here, this I'm really sorry. Furthermore, EUR 8 million is too much if we only communicate and too little if we want to do something concrete. However we are helping, with "Creative Europe" which continues to remain underfunded, those who want to do business through culture and creativity. I close by saying that I decided to study archeology when I was eight, the first time I went to Pompeii, and therefore I don't think I'm a person who doesn't want to deal with cultural heritage, but, I'm sorry, this is a downward agreement and I can not support it.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the issue of heritage is essential in our societies, which are today destabilized. The word "heritage" comes from the Latin patrimonium, which means "the heritage of the father". In times of crisis, this is linked to this need for a carnal bond with our ancestors, with this constitutive history of peoples and nations. This is why, a priori, I welcomed with great benevolence the desire of this Parliament to make 2018 the year of cultural heritage. However, I must admit a certain disappointment at the result of this trilogue negotiation. From my point of view, the initial 8 million euros or the 15 million requested by our rapporteur will not change anything if the objectives for this year remain as they are. Indeed, the current structure reminds me more of a vast marketing operation in favor of the European Union than of fully useful actions for the safeguard of cultural property in Europe. I haven't seen anything about protecting religious buildings, for example. In France, more than 10,000 churches are threatened with destruction. To conclude, I would say that perhaps the best way to celebrate this year would be to start by recognizing and valuing the diversity of national cultures… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: - Mr President, esteemed Commissioner, European cultural heritage is one of our greatest riches, which ranges from museums to customs and traditions, to natural sites. But cultural heritage does not consist only of monuments and works of art; It also consists of intangible and intangible assets. Among them is the gastronomic heritage of Europe. Of unparalleled wealth. A heritage that has been transmitted from generation to generation through families. Unfortunately, the hustle and bustle of modern life can put you at risk; and it should be the school that takes over. Our gastronomy is a source of cultural, artistic, tourist and economic wealth and represents more than 300,000 direct jobs and 7 million indirect ones. I would not like to forget another essential element of our intangible heritage: traditional European sports. Many of them do not belong to the federative sphere. You do not earn medals with your practice, but they are part of our cultural wealth. We must know and support them so that they are not lost in the next generations.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Year of Cultural Heritage is an important achievement of the European Parliament and, I think I must say, of the Committee on Culture in particular. Thanks to the tenacity and determination of our colleague Diaconu and the shadow colleagues of the delegation led by my colleague Silvia Costa, we have been able to realize this important initiative for the citizens of the Union. The idea of ​​a year dedicated to the enhancement of European tangible and intangible cultural heritage was born two years ago with the report entitled "Towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe", with which Parliament stressed the importance of European cultural heritage, both tangible and intangible, as a fundamental factor for the conservation of European culture and history and the safeguarding of values ​​linked to European identity. A Year for cultural heritage, therefore, as a shared resource that implies collective responsibility, a factor capable of strengthening the sense of common European belonging, especially in this delicate historical moment, in which too many citizens seem to have lost their sense, pride and the very reason for their being together in our common project. Enhancing the recognized sites that have obtained the European cultural heritage label must therefore become a political priority to support our European awareness, our sense of belonging to a common cultural space, to the European dimension, the result of an intertwined and centuries-old history, and reinforce the ideals and values ​​that led to European integration. Flagship initiatives linked to 2018 will therefore be organized, together with inclusive events, initiatives and awareness campaigns to convey the value of unity in the diversity of the richness of the European cultural heritage and bring its citizens closer to the Union. It is therefore good to have associated, in addition to the institutions of the Member States, civil society, in particular youth associations, in the organization of this event and, for the first time, even if only as observers, also representatives of this Parliament to promote constructive intertwiningand virtuous between institutions and citizens.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, the European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018 will be held in a symbolic year, commemorating 100 years since the end of the First World War, which enabled the emergence of new states in Europe, including Czechoslovakia. Today, Europe is once again experiencing a political crisis of mistrust. And this is a situation where we can rely again on the great cultural heritage: the wealth that unites us. Getting to know history more, making it accessible, especially to young people, also means better understanding today's situation. I would like to tell my colleague Adinolfi that the Year of Cultural Heritage cannot and will not be a campaign. Yesterday, I had the opportunity to attend the very first meeting with representatives of the European Commission, as an observer on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education. I would like to thank the Commissioner and his team, because he is not waiting for him to be able to start after the legislation has been approved, but he is already preparing activities for the Year of Cultural Heritage to meet our expectations and for Europe to live its cultural richness.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - I welcome the European Year of Cultural Heritage first of all as a Slovenian and a citizen of the European Union. Cultural heritage is a witness to our past, part of our common heritage for future generations, cultural heritage is a pillar of our culture and identity. We need strong and deep roots for a successful and common future. In these turbulent and uncertain times, it is more important for us Europeans than ever to know who we are, what we can do and what connects us. Europe's cultural heritage enriches us with its diversity and, at the same time, on the basis of Judeo-Christian values, also connects us closely. Respect for one's own nation, nature and customs is certainly also a step towards strengthening the love for the homeland. However, I am concerned about the Commission's approach to funding the European Year of Cultural Heritage. Instead of asking the Commission for additional funding for these projects, it is taking funding from other programs, thus jeopardizing their implementation. I am therefore pleased that we in the Committee on Budgets for 2017 voted in favor of creating a special budget line.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur Mircea Diaconu, to Mrs Costa, to all the shadow rapporteurs for their work in this report!Europe's identity is related to many aspects: geography, culture, history, freedom, but also to cultural heritage.In this context, the proposal that 2018 be the European Year of Cultural Heritage is welcome, and the events that will take place will allow European and non-European citizens visiting Europe to appreciate Europe's culture, to be aware of our common history and values, but alsoto strengthen the feeling of belonging to the European public space.We can never say that one culture is superior to another, and this program encourages the development of local, regional, cross-border projects, which will allow the whole culture to flourish.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, futurists say that America will be a shopping center, that Asia will be one big production plant, and that Europe will be a museum.The futurists may not be entirely right, but when they speak in this way, they are only showing what Europe means, what European heritage means.Our European heritage is truly intertwined.It is intertwined because we have had various civilizations that have disappeared on European soil, various wars and conquests.We have had many tragedies, but still behind everything are extremely valuable monumental heritage, which we cherish today and which are part of us, part of our civilization.Therefore, unlike some colleagues who attack this program completely unrealistically and even inaccurately, I want to believe that this is a great start for the protection and valorization of the cultural heritage of European countries.That is why I support this and congratulate my dear colleague Diacon on this report.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Commissioner!The Year of Cultural Heritage aims to strengthen the sense of European identity and also bring about tangible economic effects.Promoting cultural heritage can bring economic growth and create jobs, but as a member of the Development Committee, I believe that cultural heritage can also play a key role in the Union's external relations with other countries, particularly in responding to the destruction of cultural heritage in conflict zones.Promotion of culture also contributes to better integration of migrants and to combating extremism and populism in Europe.This was also recognized between them in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, reaffirming the importance of cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue as the overarching principles of sustainable development.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D). - Mr President, our principles and values, the rule of law, are the essence of our intangible culture, which is why we strongly support the establishment of 2018 as the Year of European Cultural Heritage. However, Mr President and ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry that in some places within the European Union the protection of our culture is not possible. In this place in the European Union the monuments of our culture are destroyed, the churches and the chapels became stables and ottoman baths. Icons of centuries, ancient monuments of Greek culture are completely destroyed. This place is not in Palmyra, Syria, it is in Turkish-occupied Cyprus, and here I have two books; one is entitled: "The Destruction of Religious Monuments by the Turkish Army in the Occupied Part of Cyprus" and the other: " Religious Monuments in Turkish-Occupied Cyprus ». Here is the whole truth unfortunately.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to thank the Honourable Members for their contribution and their work in the preparation and preparatory works of the European Year of Cultural Heritage. I will just make one brief remark. The European cultural heritage is a collection and a pool of local cultural heritages. That is why we would like to see a bottom-up structure for the European Year of Cultural Heritage, which means that we would like to put the emphasis on the local level, the involvement of local communities, and helping those local communities to showcase their own cultural richness and cultural heritage. We are going to have flagship events at European level, but, if we want to be successful and to be happy by the end of next year, we have to help – and we should help – those local communities to be successful in showing their treasures and the richness of their cultural heritage, because that is Europe. Europe is a community of communities, and we have to show, and to open up, all the opportunities for local and regional communities to show their own treasures.

name: Mircea DIACONU
text: Rapporteur. - I would like to draw the collegial attention of the two political groups that do not support this report that the topics rightly developed by them are different and can be financed, they have been solved from completely different programs than this, ie to try, so to speak so, at another counter. But coming back after the interventions of Commissioner Navracsics and all his colleagues, especially since most of them are effective participants in this report, and this, in my opinion, success so far, would be nothing to say. And yet, in conclusion, in the end, I would like to point out to you, ladies and gentlemen, a very special opportunity, namely that Parliament remains, according to the final document, an effective collaborator and participant until the end of this project, an unusual and well deserved, I think, especially since the main issue that needs to be addressed, I think and not only me, in Europe, is to re-establish the link between the European institutions, the European Union at its peak and citizens. And who can do it better than Parliament, which is made up of people elected by the people? That is why, on this celebration of all, as the Commissioner rightly said, of communities, of citizens, of associations, of all, we must all, all institutions and all citizens, be like a celebration that comes once and for all. one hundred years. Let's understand this, evaluate it as such and behave as such. I wish this, I hope it is a success.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 27 April 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - The ideals, principles and values ​​embodied in Europe's cultural heritage are a common source of European remembrance, understanding, identity, dialogue, cohesion and creativity. 2007 Following the adoption of the European Agenda for Culture, cultural heritage will continue to be a priority in the Council's subsequent work plans in the field of culture, including the current one in 2015-2018. - work plan. 2014 November The Council conclusions on the management of cultural heritage called on the Commission to launch a European Year of Cultural Heritage. The European Parliament issued a similar call in its resolution calling on the Commission to "declare a European Year of Heritage, preferably 2018". The Commission argues that the contribution of cultural heritage to economic growth and social cohesion in Europe is poorly known and often underestimated. As in any European Year, the main aim is to raise awareness of the challenges and opportunities in a given area and to highlight Europe's role in finding common solutions. The European Year of Cultural Heritage should offer European citizens new opportunities to get to know the present better through a broader common interpretation of the past.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. - We strongly support the decision to declare 2018 the European Year of Cultural Heritage, with the aim of raising the awareness of Europeans about European history and European values, as well as strengthening the common sense of European identity. However, unfortunately I have to remind and complain that the religious and cultural heritage of Cyprus has been destroyed every day since 1974, by a country that is joining the EU, by Turkey. Turkey is destroying invaluable cultural treasures, which are a common cultural heritage of Europe and which the EU must preserve. Sanctions in Turkey for the destruction of European monuments and for the gross violation of the basic principle of respect for religious and cultural heritage are deemed imperative.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to say a few words about the European Year of Cultural Heritage. Today, cultural heritage is becoming more and more valuable as we live in a world where cultural diversity is gaining ground. It not only contributes to preserving our identity, but also increases the performance of the economy, encourages investment and contributes to job creation. This is one of the reasons why the initiative is very important, as it draws attention to the past and values ​​of our continent, thus strengthening the common European identity. The amendments made to the proposal for a decision of the Parliament and of the Council on the European Year of Cultural Heritage are extremely important, as they clarify and supplement the text proposed by the Commission. For example, the involvement of civil society is essential to 'bring' the initiative closer to European citizens. In addition to co-financing by the Member States, a separate article to be created in the general budget is of key importance for adequate funding. Of course, neither the Committee on Budgets' resolution on financial compatibility nor the REGI Committee's proposal can be ignored. The amendments mentioned above have been worded in line with all this. In the light of all this, I believe that it is of paramount importance that 2018 be the European Year of Cultural Heritage, and that this can be done effectively within the framework outlined above. Thank you for listening!

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - Cultural heritage plays a fundamental role for us Europeans of cohesion and development for our communities, especially in such a delicate historical phase of growing complexity and cultural diversity. This is even more true for those areas of our continent affected by social and employment crises or subject to emergencies and natural disasters, for which the presence of a cultural and landscape heritage offers not only an opportunity for economic recovery, but often represents a unique opportunity for productive reinvention and collective revitalization. I find it particularly significant that the EU wanted to dedicate the year 2018 to cultural heritage. With this choice, in fact, we are strengthening the sense of belonging of European citizens to a common cultural space and to a value system open to the world, in the wake of the historical and cultural tradition of Europe. The hope is that from this important occasion of today's debate, constant policies and new concrete measures may arise, aimed at safeguarding and enhancing, precisely in the areas of greatest crisis in our Europe, the many scenic and cultural beauties of which we hold.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: written. - Cultural heritage, in addition to being a symbol of identity and the historical heritage of the different European peoples, is an element that contributes both directly and indirectly to the economic growth and social development of the different European localities and regions. The conservation and restoration of material cultural heritage, especially that existing in rural and sparsely populated areas, will help promote sustainable tourism, create jobs and prevent the deterioration and abandonment suffered not only by these historical assets, but also by towns. and regions in which they are found. To guarantee the success of the process, it is necessary to influence the training and specialization of the workers, as well as the recognition at national and European level of the different restoration and conservation techniques, since these must be adapted to the specificities of the work in question, from the type of materials that make up the work to the reasons that have caused its deterioration.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: in writing. - The scarcity of the funds made available makes the year of cultural heritage an event little more than symbolic. However symbols and actions are important. In this sense, I will work to ensure that due attention is also given to the cultural heritage destroyed by natural disasters, in the meetings planned by the Commission to decide on the organization of the events to be held in 2018. The cultural heritage that surrounds us throughout Europe is an immense privilege, but also a source of duties. Paraphrasing a Native American saying, we inherited it from our parents and we have it on loan for our children to whom we must return it. In Italy the cultural heritage is priceless, but it risks transforming itself from a common good of the people, of all peoples, to a source of enrichment for the few, thanks to cuts imposed on culture and ideologies of privatization. The remedy is the involvement of citizens, especially young people. I therefore hope that 2018 is the next step on this path.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - Cultural heritage is an important part of the history and identity of Europe and its citizens. The designation of 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage is necessary to increase the contribution of cultural heritage to our economy and society and to address the need to protect the world's cultural assets. On the one hand, cultural assets allow us to better understand the past. 2018 marks many important events for us, including the centenary of the end of World War I and the independence of several EU member states, including Estonia. When thinking about cultural heritage, in addition to the past, we must also look to the future: how to protect and preserve cultural assets, what are the opportunities to increase the contribution of cultural heritage to our economy and society, and so on. 2018 will allow us to pay more attention to all this than before. Looking beyond Europe, it is worrying that many of the world's cultural assets are currently under threat and are being deliberately destroyed in conflict zones. Culture must be an integral part of the EU's foreign policy, and the EU, in cooperation with the Council of Europe and UNESCO, has a key role to play in protecting the world's cultural heritage.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The proposal for a European Year of Cultural Heritage is a victory for Parliament, but also for dozens of European organizations and national public authorities, which have supported this idea before the Commission. Although I appreciate the Commission's approach to supporting European culture, I note with disappointment that Parliament's text ignores the contribution of tourism to the promotion of cultural heritage and that the budget allocation is insufficient to achieve the objectives. As Commissioner Tibor Navracsics said, the link between culture and tourism is obvious and indestructible. So I do not want the Year of Cultural Heritage to be a simple image campaign, but I want to see it as an opportunity to highlight how the synergy between tourism and cultural heritage contributes to the promotion of everything that is more precious in Europe. At the same time, we must ensure that the European Year will be marked in all European states, and that the action plan will succeed in identifying and promoting the hidden treasures of our continent. Thus, in order to highlight the bridges that can be created between states, I would like to refer to the great sculptor Constantin Brâncuși, whose work can be found both in Romania and on display in the largest museums in the world.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - The European Parliament's decision on the Commission's proposal to dedicate 2018 to European heritage is welcome. Europe's cultural heritage is a common resource and a good for all, which must be preserved for future generations and whose protection is a common responsibility of all. Created, over time, through the synthesis of the extremely diverse cultural expressions of the civilizations that inhabited Europe, the inherited cultural heritage can play an important role in the cohesion of communities at a time when European societies are going through a period of increasing diversity. The European Year will encourage a better understanding of the need to protect and promote the diversity of cultural expressions. Understanding the vital importance of cultural heritage for our community, UDMR launched five years ago the program "Heritage protectors - adopt a monument" which aims to educate and involve young people in protecting and promoting the built heritage. The program was a real success, during this period, more and more students and high school students understood the importance of protecting the monuments, training enthusiasts in activities dedicated to this purpose. UDMR wants to promote this program at European level as a set of good practices regarding civic involvement, from an early age, in the protection and transmission of cultural heritage to future generations.
