name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen in the Court of Auditors! As every year, Parliament not only has to decide on the budget, but also to vote on the discharge of the Commission and the other European institutions for the past financial years in order to give them discharge. This year we are voting on the discharge for the 2015 financial year. In doing so, we have come to the end of a journey of several months that began with the submission of the annual report of the Court of Auditors for the 2015 financial year and the submission of the annual reports of the directorates-general for the same year - that is now more than seven months ago. This report would not have been possible without close cooperation with the relevant institutions and individuals. I would therefore particularly like to thank the representatives of the Court of Auditors, namely the President Klaus Heiner-Lehne and the responsible auditor, Mr Lazaros Lazarou, and their staff. I would like to thank Commissioner Kristalina Georgieva and, after the change in office, Commissioner Günther Oettinger, as well as all Commissioners and Directors General and their staff for many constructive and open discussions. A special thank you from me personally goes to the staff of the committee secretariat, Mr Godts and Ehlers, Mr Szechy as advisor to my group and my colleague Mr Reichel. Of course, I would also like to thank all my colleagues who worked as shadow rapporteurs on the drafting of the report, and all colleagues from Parliament who added more than 400 amendments to the report. To anticipate it right away: The Committee on Budgetary Control is recommending, following the recommendation of the Court of Auditors, to grant discharge to Parliament and the Commission for 2015. In the accompanying Resolution criticizes the deficits in the management and in the audit of the expenditure of EU funds, names the Member States with the worst results and gives concrete recommendations for measures to remedy the problems. The resolution welcomes the approach of a stronger focus on results, that is to say, in addition to checking the legality and regularity of payments, there is also more research into whether the results of projects and programs meet the original objectives. The whole thing runs under the heading “performance-based budgeting”. Unfortunately, it is not the time here to review the 137 pages that the resolution now comprises and to go into the details that are raised there. I hope that will happen in a follow-up to the report so that it doesn't just disappear in the filing cabinet. I would like to emphasize a few things: We ask for a better coordination of the previous planning cycles. We have faced the seven-year medium-term financial framework with a five-year mandate from the European Parliament and the Commission. The whole thing is then backed up with a strategic ten-year planning cycle, and the budget must not only do justice to the EU 2020 strategy or the Commission's top ten priorities, but also - and increasingly - react to current political and financial crises . In 2020 there is an opportunity to bring these long-term strategies into harmony with the budget cycle - otherwise Parliament and the Commission - otherwise tie them more closely to political goals and financing that they could not decide on in advance, and thus make the budget more flexible he can react better to current challenges. We recommend a rolling budget with a five-year planning horizon.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: protractor. - Mr President, Commissioner, with regard to the EDF discharge we are proposing to grant, allow me to make a few introductory remarks. There is no doubt that the EDF represents one of the largest official development assistance budgets in the world. But given the immensity of the challenges facing Africa, it will soon prove - I fear - insufficient. These challenges, you know them, are poverty, health emergencies, climate emergencies or even population growth. As for demography, allow me to draw your attention to a few figures: in 2100, the population of the African continent will be around 4.5 billion on a planet of 11 billion inhabitants, that is to say say that one in three Terrans will be African. By 2100, Nigeria's population will approach 900 million, roughly equivalent to all people living on the African continent today. Faced with this reality, it is little to say that we will be overwhelmed very quickly. Coming back to the EDF discharge, we have come to the end of a long procedure, and I would of course like to thank all of my colleagues, the European Court of Auditors and the European Commission for their assistance. All the discussions that we have had made it possible to identify certain difficulties and certain blockages - which unfortunately are not new, which we repeat every year and for which the European Parliament demands additional efforts from the Commission. We ask it in particular to reduce the levels of errors which are still too high and to tackle the most frequent errors, to take more account of key information to limit the error rate and, of course, to strengthen ex ante controls. . However, we also congratulate the Commission on the many improvements that we have seen, in particular with regard to the reduction old pre-financing, outstanding commitments and contracts that have expired. We also ask the Commission to provide the European Parliament with more information on certain expenses, in particular those which are the subject of reservations made by the Commission itself, and in particular for the African Peace Facility, for which we are waiting now concrete, immediate and effective responses. We are also making proposals to improve the performance and efficiency of the EDF. I will not go into detail, but it concerns the types, causes, blockages, and also to provide for the suspension of a project when it is classified as red. Then, for us, there is also the problem of the outsourcing of a number of missions, in particular through Trust Funds and international organizations. Ultimately, the requested resolution to grant discharge encourages a necessary balance between effective management and control and sufficient flexibility to enable development goals to be achieved.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Reporter. - I would like to start by thanking many of Parliament's officials for the cooperation I received in writing my report. The information provided was helpful and I got a better idea of ​​the organization and the dedication of many. I also recommend that tomorrow we grant discharge to the President of Parliament. At the same time, I noticed that there are subjects that are sensitive. I saw it as my duty as a rapporteur not to take any notice of taboos or sensitivities. After the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control, a number of sharp edges were removed from the report, but I would like to thank my colleagues that the core has remained intact on almost all subjects. My search began with the way in which the European Court of Auditors audits Parliament's budget expenditure. In my opinion, there is too much the idea that most of the expenditure relates to personnel costs and that not so much can go wrong. Therefore, only 16 transactions were examined. In discussions with the Court of Audit, we found that the checks could be a bit more extensive due to the possible damage to the image. Take the House of European History. The opening has been postponed several times, but next week it will happen and the media has immediately started a discussion whether this should be paid from tax money. In addition, running a museum is a core task of Parliament. And how do you decide on the exhibitions without political bias? In the report we recommend that this museum be at least remote and it would also be fine if the Brussels local authorities were more directly involved in this project. More generally, I noticed frustration at Parliament's Communication Service. Skepticism about the European Union and about Parliament is growing all over Europe. Fewer and fewer people are participating in European elections. Go there, if information service, just turn it on. I think the only solution is to send less and receive more. But that is not an easy task, because many critical citizens have already turned away from politics as a whole. I propose that the Communication department starts working with concrete benchmarks to measure its results. Even more sensitive is the expenditure of the European political parties and foundations of political groups. Parliament provides subsidies, but justification for expenditure is poor. In addition, the media was full of reports of misuse by some especially newly formed parties and foundations. More manpower really needs to be put into this than the two FTEs that Parliament has allocated for this. There is also work for Parliament's internal auditor and, of course, for the newly established authority. Another sensitive point is the voluntary pension fund. I originally heard from the Secretary General that there were no immediate problems. But there is indeed an actuarial deficit of 276 million euros. In a few years, the taxpayer may start coughing up this bit by bit. I find this unacceptable, which is why I am calling on the Secretary-General to come up with a comprehensive action plan in order not to let it get that far. Then there is the general expense allowance. For some colleagues it is in principle not negotiable to be accountable for this. I do not understand that. This is not a salary, but intended for specific expenses. This amounts to more than 50,000 euros per Member of the European Parliament per year. Now let us agree once and for all that we will be accountable for this and that the results can be presented on the personal webpages of MEPs on Parliament's site. There are dozens of other recommendations in the report. I trust that Parliament and in particular the Bureau and the Secretary-General to swiftly implement what we will decide on here in plenary tomorrow.

name: Bart STAES
text: Reporter. - I must say that I am also very pleased with the presence of Mr Borg, who represents the Council today. The Council once excelled in its absence and your presence, Mr Borg, is a very good thing because you will hear comments during the debate, you will hear calls that might lead to better financial management, but for which we also need the Member States. I hope you will pass on the messages we are conveying today to the Council itself. I am rapporteur for the Committee of the Regions, for the discharge of the Committee of the Regions, the Economic and Social Committee and the European Data Protector, as well as for the discharge for the Council itself. As far as the Council is concerned, I actually recommend postponing the discharge and that for the umpteenth time, the seventh time in a row. Postpone until October, and then we can use the period May-October to try to resolve the long-standing conflict between the Council and Parliament. In the Committee on Budgetary Control, Mrs Grässle, our chairman, and I have had a very constructive conversation with the Secretary-General of the Council. We have also set up a group in the Committee on Budgetary Control to examine this issue. In fact, we intend to come up with a text that can then be submitted to Coreper where we hope that the conflict over which access we can have, which documents we can have access to, what information will be provided to us to ensure a proper discharge to the Council to resolve that conflict and then hopefully see to it that this long-standing conflict is swept out the door. I do propose that the three other reports be granted discharge. In all those reports I used the same methodology, asked the same questions. Do we get our money's worth? Are results-oriented budgeting being done within those institutions? What about those settings with transparency? What about the anti-corruption policy? How do those institutions deal with their staff? Is there a good working atmosphere there? What about the male-female ratio in the middle and top positions? Those kinds of questions have been asked. I have also visited those three institutions. I have spoken to the leading figures in those three institutions. They were very constructive conversations and I learned a lot from them. The approach differs from institution to institution, hence the recommendation in my three reports that differ from institution to institution. But we can effectively grant discharge. I would also like to say very explicitly that I really appreciate the work of the Court of Auditors, Mr Lehne. What you are doing is fantastic. We can really get started with your work and from your work we have learned for the umpteenth year in a row that the margin of error of the Commission budget is on average 3.8%. We all know that that is actually still too much. We also all know that this is not necessarily fraud. It certainly is not. But it is money that should not have been paid out or in a different way. In fact, the Court of Auditors has been saying for many years that the Member States, Mr Borg, knew or should have known that some expenditure, that some subsidies, should not have been paid. So there is an important responsibility with those Member States. I call on you to enter into a discussion about this within the Council, to enter into a debate in order to sharpen the responsibility of those finance ministers within the Member States. More alertness is needed. Greater responsibility is needed on the part of Member States. I would like to thank Mr Zeller for taking up the recommendation in his report and also the warning that the share of climate-related expenditure in the European budget is far too low. It now averages 17.6%. If that's not fixed - there we are in the Commission budget control agree - then we will not reach the target of 20%. Then we will not be able to realize the efforts that are necessary and that we have made internationally in the context of the Paris Convention, the climate treaty. I also ask, together with Mr Zeller, for special attention to the whole problem of shadow budgets. There are many financial mechanisms that are used to support Union policy, but which are kept completely outside the European budget. It is very difficult to control and that can lead to a lack of responsibility. This can cause inconsistency in policy and can lead to unnecessary risk taking. There is therefore clearly a need for greater transparency and I am very grateful to Mr Oettinger for his commitment as Commissioner to reintroduce those various shadow budgets back into the Union budget in the long term. I think that's a good thing. As far as the Parliament budget is concerned, I agree fully with what Mr De Jong has just said, especially with regard to the attention paid to the fraudulent practices of European political parties and political foundations - usually very recent phenomena indeed. There is tampering there. We have established that a number of journalists have raised these fraudulent practices within a few weeks. We need to strengthen control within the European Parliament. We cannot leave that to journalistic research.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, let me say thank you to all of the institutions who cooperated during the discharge procedure, including the European External Action Service, the European Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Ombudsman and the agencies. We had very successful cooperation and sometimes we had long discussions on several issues but, in the end, I believe we were able to find good compromises and good explanations for the questions raised. During the procedure, in addition to examining whether expenditure by the institutions was in line with European regulations, we also concentrated on some specific issues, including transparency, openness of the institutions, access to information, public access to documents in the institutions, and also the whistleblower protection rules of the institutions. The second issue we concentrated on was how aligned spending is with the principle of performance-based budgeting, which was already mentioned beforehand. It is not only compliance with the rules, but also whether the outcome of expenditure is efficient and effective. We believe that the institutions are performing better and better regarding this. We also tried to have a look at the gender balance in the institutions and anti-harassment protection. Finally, we believe that it is important to check the EMAS performance of the institutions and, as my colleague Bart Staes already mentioned, how the funds are used for CO2 offsetting and the fight against climate change. Regarding specific institutions, starting with the European External Action Service, I think the most important issue here is to make the distinction between economic diplomacy and simple economic lobbying, and how to provide transparency for the latter. We do not have the answers yet but we had very constructive discussions with Vice-President Mogherini in this sense. Some questions were also raised regarding some building buying by the EEAS in some countries. I believe that finally we have some answers. Not everything was clarified but I hope that, since I regard the discharge procedure as a long procedure, in the long run we can set up a transparent and accountable system for the control of this issue as well. Regarding the European Court of Justice, I have to mention that at the very beginning there were some misunderstandings or conflicts between the Court of Auditors and the Court of Justice as to how the Court of Auditors obtain access to some information within the Court of Justice. I am happy that finally – and I hope that we contributed to this procedure – we could find a compromise and the Court of Auditors and the Court of Justice agreed on how to settle this problem. I agree with Mr Staes that the Court of Auditors is an extremely important institution for the Budgetary Control Committee (CONT). We have very good cooperation and I would like to emphasise the high level of cooperation and the constructive discussions with the Court of Auditors. Finally, regarding the agencies, we Greens continued with the push for greater independence and transparency in the work of the EU agencies and have strongly opposed conflicts of interest of the agencies’ management or external associates to limit the influence of the lobbyists and the corporate sector. We hope that, in the long term, we can improve the performance of some... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: speaker. - Mr. president. Yes, I too would like to welcome, first of all, Commissioner Oettinger, which will be his first discharge procedure, and I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Lehne, in particular for his presence. Also to Mr Lazarou, the - let us say - guardian of the DAS, and also, of course, to Mr Borg, of the Maltese Presidency. First of all, it is not new to highlight the significant influence that European agencies have both in the formulation of policies and in decision-making and in the implementation of programs. And that, more and more. They are important for issues as important to citizens and institutions as health, the environment, human and social rights, migration and refugees, innovation, financial oversight, security and protection. So much diversity and, at the same time, so much responsibility. And, in fact, due to this impact on daily life, it is also possible to demand their autonomy and independence, precisely to protect their criteria and the credibility of all of them. All of them receive funding of a different kind, since there are many - more than thirty, hence their diversity. We have seen that in this last year there has been a slight increase --or a more important increase, depending on the point of view-, but that this increase, and, above all, in terms of its employees, is reflected, above all, in the agencies that deal with migration and the prevention of serious crimes and terrorism, which were especially priorities of the Union in 2015. And we also find that, according to the summary provided by the Court of all its audits, all of them have happened without any reservation, except in the case of Frontex and in the case of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, but that afterwards, in fruitful dialogue with the Court of Auditors, the Commission and the agencies, we have been able to resolve all doubts and the problems, so that at this moment we may be in a position to clearly propose the discharge of all of them. I believe that in this dialogue the fundamental role of the network of agencies must be highlighted, which was created as an autonomous element and which is increasingly being reinforced. We would have right now ―at this moment, I think it is a legitimate demand― to reinforce its personnel, since precisely the activity of this coordination ―a coordination, furthermore, accredited and reinforced― of the agencies has also generated very good results and some products and instruments of bilateral and network cooperation that have made our work much easier and solved many of the problems. Also, there are some issues that need to be improved, of course. And there is my demand, also, both to Commissioner Oettinger and to Mr Lehne, regarding the solution that we should give to the continuous extensions of commitment appropriations that are taking place, which even in 2015 have increased somewhat, and that more and more, and I believe that, with the help of the Court of Auditors - Mr Lehne says yes, and I thank him very much - we could reach a solution, so that they do not all appear the same, but those that are planned, in an easier way, and those that are not, then yes, absolutely, audit. On the other hand, we also run into the problem of audits. Mr Lehne, I am ready to reinforce the resources of the Court of Auditors as much as necessary so that these audits remain public and the Court of Auditors continues to guarantee them. I think that would be progress. We also have some issues in relation to the renewed or double downsizing of staff - 5% + 5% - which could undermine the need for agencies to get to the bottom in their mandates and in their actions, so we are rather cautious there. . And we have also carried out a first indication in relation to the impact of Brexit in some of the agencies that are precisely in the United Kingdom and that we need to be able to clarify.And, finally, there is a group proposal - I thank my colleagues who have supported me for the moment - that I would like us to be able to develop in a more successful way in the future.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, the European Union's Joint Undertakings make a very important contribution to the development of European research and also to its practical application. The share of European Union investment in joint ventures is not negligible: in 2015, companies had a budget of over € 1.3 billion. Last year, this plenary decided to postpone three reports in the first round, namely for ITER, ENIAC and ARTEMIS: I note that ARTEMIS and ENIAC have merged into ECSEL, so that this year only ECSEL is part of the budget discharge. All the postponed budget discharge was subsequently adopted at the September plenary session. I am glad that, unlike last year, this year, in my role as rapporteur, I do not have to propose postponing these discharge for a single joint venture. My position was also confirmed by a majority of the members of the Committee on Budgetary Control. The Council of the European Union also recommended in February that discharge be granted to all Joint Undertakings. The European Court of Auditors, as well as the Committee on Budgetary Control later, noted significant improvements, especially in the areas highlighted by the two institutions in the past in the 2015 discharge process. Horizon 2020 funding was launched in 2015. We cannot disguise that the start-up of projects takes longer than we would like, but in this respect the joint ventures face major challenges. On the other hand, and I do not want to downplay what has just been said, delays are often caused by high demands on the quality of projects. In any case, the 2015 audit reports present separately the results related to FP7 and Horizon 2020, as requested by the European Parliament in the past. Last year, the European Parliament mentioned a number of horizontal comments on the European Court of Auditors and the structure of its reports. It is clear that the European Court of Auditors has tried to incorporate and take our comments into account. I very much appreciate the quality of the European Court of Auditors' reports for the year 2015, as well as very effective cooperation with individual joint ventures during the preparation of reports. As I mentioned, the situation of all the Joint Undertakings has significantly improved and been remedied in a number of areas which have been highlighted by both the European Court of Auditors and the European Parliament in the past. We have probably seen the biggest shift in the Fusion for Energy Joint Undertaking, which represents the European Union in the ITER project. I do not hide the fact that ITER is still the biggest challenge among all the Joint Undertakings, and I will look at it in much more detail in a moment. This year, for the first time, we are deciding on the granting of budget discharge for the new Joint Undertaking for the Biotechnology Industry, BBI. Despite the fact that it operated independently only since October 2015, this company did not experience any major problems in its accounting, nor with its organizational or personnel structure. As last year, this year the ECSEL Joint Undertaking received a qualified opinion. This was only for a reason related to the unfortunate setting of the legislative framework of the Seventh Framework Program, ie the inability of the Court to audit national certification bodies. We drew attention to this in our debates last year and made it clear that the systemic problem is in the Horizon 2020 regulation and that it has been eliminated during this time. In principle, the European Court of Auditors has no choice but to have, until the closure of the financial operations relating to ARTEMIS and ENIAC, to issue a qualified opinion, as this follows from the European Court of Auditors' regulation. This year, ECSEL also secured certificates from all national financial authorities regarding audits of ex-post payments. I would like to remind you that, based on the presentation of these certificates, we have decided to grant this budget discharge this year. In the accounting for 2015, for the first time we encounter in most companies the accounting of two types of in-kind costs, the so-called IKOP, ie standard in-kind costs as we know them, and the so-called IKAA, which are the costs of additional private activities. which are not financed by the budget of the European Union but contribute to the same objectives. There are methodologies for calculating the costs of additional activities, but these vary greatly from sector to sector. The calculation depends on the assessment of external auditors. The European Court of Auditors has no control competence over the costs of these activities, and this raises further problems. I believe that the calculations of additional costs will need to be given much more attention next year. I would also like to point out that joint ventures calculate the in-kind costs of IKOP, ie the costs of operational activities, on the basis of estimates. Experience shows that there is a common problem with billing by partners by the required deadline of 31 January of the following year. However, this problem cannot be solved at the level of the Joint Undertakings, as it depends on the deadline of the Member States' accounts. This is largely a formal problem rather than a risk to European investment, but it is certainly a problem. Finally, a brief look at Fusion for Energy, whose funding is, of course, in the spotlight. Neither the European Court of Justice nor the European Parliament, as the guardian of the budget, can ignore the fact of rising costs for this completely unique project. On the other hand, it is quite clear that a new course was set in 2015 and by then došlo (The President cut him off.)

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, President Lehne, it is a pleasure for us to be here, and thank you for your comments of appreciation. It is my duty. I also believe that the efficient use of EU funds in full respect of the principle of sound financial management is of utmost importance, and the delivery of good results is particularly important also given that it is on this basis that the public forms its perception of actions financed from the EU budget. Yesterday I was chairing the General Affairs Council for Cohesion Ministers in Luxembourg and we were actually discussing, in the presence of the Commission, how to make EU-funded projects more visible to our citizens.  On 28 February 2017, my colleague Minister Scicluna had the honour of presenting the Council’s recommendation to grant discharge to the Commission, to the Committee on Budgetary Control, and I believe tomorrow you will confirm the vote of the Committee on Budgetary Control and grant discharge to the Commission. I am glad that the European Parliament and the Council are able to agree on this important issue. In its recommendation, the Council outlined a number of elements which, from our point of view, should be followed up and implemented by all actors and without delay. All those involved in the management of EU funds need to assume their responsibilities in full, and yes, that includes the Member States.  The Council urged the Commission, and the Member States as well, to strengthen their mutual cooperation and stressed also the importance of avoiding errors in the first place. It also called on Member States to continue cooperating with the Commission and to give priority to increasing the quality of first-level checks in order to prevent or detect errors and correct them prior to declaring expenditure to the Commission. Yes, we must take into considerations that controls entail also a cost. Therefore a balance has to be found between the risk of error and the cost of control and audit, thereby focusing on better controls rather than on more controls.  On the one hand, prevention is always better than correction. Hence preventive measures by the Commission, such as interruption and suspension of payments, should be strictly applied. On the other hand, there is also a need to continue applying financial corrections and recoveries rigorously to protect the EU budget. In this context, the Council regrets that not all actors involved made full use of the available information to prevent, detect and also correct a significant proportion of those errors. This could have substantially reduced the estimated level of error across all chapters of expenditure. Nevertheless, we must also recognise the efforts made and actions already taken by the Commission and also by the Member States. The Council notes with satisfaction that the Court of Auditors finding that non-compliance with public procurement rules decreased, compared with the preceding years. This is also a reflection of the efforts made by the Commission, as well as the Member States, to address weaknesses in this area.  I would also like to point out that the Council considers the simplification of rules to be crucially important in order to achieve a lower level of error. In this regard, the Council also calls on the Commission to identify weaknesses in control systems, to analyse their costs and the benefits of possible corrective measures, to take or propose appropriate actions, such as simplification of the applicable provisions, improvement of the control systems, and also to redesign the relevant programmes. In this discharge procedure, the Council did not only look at the past, but it also looked to the future. It called on the Commission to prepare and publish, on an annual basis, a long-term and transparent forecast covering budgetary ceilings, estimated payment obligations and needs until the end of the current MFF, as well as capacity constraints and potential decommitments. Moreover, the Council also called on the Commission to provide on a regular basis clear, exhaustive and timely information about the needs for the payment appropriations and the availability of the funds in the annual budget.  Achieving results and focusing on performance is of paramount importance, especially in a context of budget discipline and scarce resources. The Council invited the Commission to continue its efforts in providing consistent and coherent measurements of performance at all the levels of management of the programmes in order to enable their meaningful assessment against the objectives set.  Finally, I would also like to say also a few words on the work done by the European Court of Auditors, which is highly appreciated by the Council. We also welcome the Court’s analysis of the errors and of the classification and distribution of corrective measures implemented in the very same year, 2015. We appreciate the Court’s work in assessing the results achieved by the EU budget, and we also consider it an important additional element of the annual evaluation of the sound financial management of EU funds. We therefore encourage the Court to continue increasing the focus on performance in its future annual reports.  It is obvious that we are still far from the overall aim of an unqualified audit opinion from the Court. The Council therefore reiterates its wish to see year-on-year improvements in the financial management systems, and also in the estimated level of errors across all policy areas. It should also be clear that the level of error estimated by the Court – and this was also highlighted by previous speakers – is not a result of fraud, inefficiency or waste of funds per se and the pressure on the European Union and the national finances is still a reality in the current economic scenario. This will require a more careful management of EU funds from all the institutions and stakeholders, as well as better forecasting of long-term funding requirements. I therefore conclude by emphasising that EU money should be used to achieve results that could not be achieved as efficiently or effectively by other means. We have to send a clear signal to the European citizens, to our taxpayers, that the EU funds are being used in a responsible and accountable manner.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the rapporteurs, representatives of the Council Presidency, Mr President Lehne, ladies and gentlemen of the Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen! Budget policy is a continuous process - from the first draft, through the deliberation and approval of the budget, the budget implementation, the cash and accounting clearance to the auditing and control by various democratically legitimized bodies - Parliament, Council and Court of Auditors - to discharge, which is the focus today. I would like to thank you for the very factual, transparent and constructive discussion that I was able to witness in the past few weeks in the bodies of the Council and Parliament. I believe that this budgetary control can convince the citizens that our parliamentary democracy deserves trust and that the result of an economical and largely efficient use of budget funds also has a confidence-building effect. In the discharge report for the 2015 financial year, essential recommendations are made and suggestions for improvement are made. I promise you: We have to learn permanently - primarily we as the Commission, who propose budget priorities and who are essentially responsible for budget implementation. We are currently executing the 2017 budget, preparing the 2018 budget, and your recommendations and the discharge report will usefully be incorporated into the execution and preparation for next year. Six thoughts that I would like to raise here for the Commission. On the one hand: we want to continue doing everything we can with budget figures and programs to implement the European Union's priorities, to keep an eye on the Europe 2020 strategy and to unite for the labor market, infrastructure, quality of life, security and competitiveness of the European Union through budgetary policy to make an important contribution. In your report, you propose that the question be critically examined for seven years / five years. I am expressly ready to do so. Especially in uncertain times - in times when Brexit will trigger a period of transformation - five — plus — five instead of seven years could be a sensible consideration as to how we can move forward into the next decade. I will come back to this with you on the multiannual financial framework over the coming months. The issue of shadow households was mentioned. I take that seriously, because the subject of ancillary budget, shadow budget in addition to the main budget, can affect, endanger, and complicate the royal right of a parliament, including the council. I want to differentiate: On the one hand, shadow households always have the smell of indirect new debt. As a rule, this is not associated with this. I know from national and regional secondary budgets to achieve the goal of indirectly describing debt limits - this has practically nothing to do with it at European level. Secondly, it is important that we, of course, have an interest - we as the Commission and you - that the Community method is at the fore in budgetary policy. That is why we are also considering which secondary budgets can be integrated in the next MFF. You know that we have at least announced this consideration for the development aid fund. On the other hand, I tell you quite frankly: If there is a cap, 1% of the gross national income, in the interests of our citizens in order to carry out our tasks, I would prefer that I have money in secondary households than pure emptiness and no money. That is why the question of how strongly ancillary budgets can be integrated depends heavily on the question of how the Council and Parliament see the overall dimension of the budget in the next decade. In addition to what can be integrated into the main budget based on contract law, there are tasks and Instruments - I mention the EFSF, the ESM and others - which could not be linked to the European budget purely under contract law, which must therefore automatically be in the interests of stabilizing the euro area and in the interests of other tasks without changing the treaty, ancillary budgets and ancillary instruments. We then have to answer the question of which financing instruments are the best. I tell you specifically: for me, cohesion funds, budget programs and cash are still the norm. And the financial instruments like the Juncker Plan are useful and necessary additions, but they cannot replace budgetary resources. We will come back to this question with the next financial framework and with the extension of the Juncker plan and its further development. I want to expressly commit to the goal of a results-oriented EU budget - EU budget focused on results. And here we will continue to examine the question of how one can get closer to the definition of the target - what do we want to achieve with budget programs and how do we measure target achievement or failure to meet targets - with future budgets and with comments on budget figures. I believe that meaningful cooperation with Parliament and the European Court of Auditors can help each other here too. We want the best possible, better, optimal control and not more controls. Another goal to avoid duplication is to achieve a single exam, but that does well with high authority for all those in charge. I promise you that in a few months' time the Commission will implement and evaluate the measures you have proposed and report back to you in view of your discharge report, which you will adopt tomorrow. As I said, budget policy is a permanent event, a round-the-clock event. Therefore, I think today is a good intermediate step, a constructive communication from Parliament.Many thanks to all rapporteurs and the technical committee for an excellent contribution.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the Court of Auditors. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister and President-in-Office of the Council! Thank you for inviting me to take part in the final debate on the discharge procedure for the 2015 financial year. It is a very special honor for me, not only because I can be here again today for the second time since I left this House to speak to colleagues, but also because I believe that it is an honor for the Court of Auditors is to do so and that we are very happy to contribute to this debate here. The discharge procedure is a good opportunity to look back and see what we can do better in the future. The rapporteurs have already mentioned this on many points in their introductory speeches. When I stood in front of you in October, I said that our most important task at the moment is to regain and strengthen the citizens' trust in the European Union project. In principle, nothing has changed about that. What is important here is that citizens must be able to see that the European Union is acting in a trustworthy and transparent manner when it deals with taxpayers' money, that it does so carefully, that it has clear objectives, that the funds are used efficiently and that it is achieving the results it promised will. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Zeller, and his colleagues and the CONT committee, chaired by Mrs Gräßle, on their reports. The discharge resolutions that have been tabled contain important points that support our recommendations as the Court of Auditors and our conclusions. We of course welcome that very much. The Court of Auditors is working hard to help ensure that budget is spent efficiently which is also reflected in our recently published opinions on the financial regulation or the mid-term review of the MFF. Our work shows how important it is to be able to rely on reliable management, monitoring and control systems that are observed by all parties involved: the Commission, the Member States and the external auditors. I would like to expressly agree with what Minister Borg and also the Commissioner said, namely that, when improving controls, we should focus above all on improving the quality and less on the quantitative side of controls. Indeed, it is crucial that we carry out qualitatively effective and efficient controls. In our 2016 annual report, which is not the subject of discussion today, but which is currently in progress and should be published in September, we will take up these points again and make special reference to them. At this point I would like to briefly address a few current priorities for our institution. Our annual report is continuously improved in terms of quality. We will concentrate more - this has already been mentioned - on performance aspects, simply because performance is just as important as compliance and it is precisely - let me put it another way - for the citizen whether what is actually happening is of decisive importance , also really happens correctly and efficiently. In addition, we will of course also try to improve our communication. This includes further developing the close cooperation with Parliament and continuing it at all levels. This applies in particular to cooperation with the Committee on Budgetary Control, of course, but also to cooperation with the other committees here in this House and with the Conference of Committee Chairs. We have been developing ours this year Work program streamlined so that we are able to better reflect the priorities of the various committees of the European Parliament. This year we received a total of 59 proposals from the Conference of Committee Chairs, most of them from budgetary control, of course, with suggestions as to what we should do. We will be deliberating and considering this very, very carefully, and I think that, as in the past, we will end up adopting a work program in which the majority of the proposals that we are going to deal with are from here on out come to the center of parliament. Europe is at a crossroads today. Strong centrifugal forces are pulling our Union from inside and outside and endanger the process of European integration. The idea of ​​Europe must be defended on many fronts. However, the solution cannot just be to deal with one crisis at a time. Fundamental reforms are just as important. Hence my request: let us use the coming spending cycle, as well as the negotiations on the withdrawal of a Member State, as an opportunity to improve the way we collect, spend and manage public money. This is also stated in the resolutions and in the statements, e.g. B. the Commissioner, has already been mentioned. In this context, I also welcome the way in which the role of the Court of Auditors was addressed in two recent decisions by the European Parliament - on institutional adjustments of February 16 and on Brexit of April 10. I can promise that, as the Court of Auditors, we will continue to make our contribution to Europe's success.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr Wieland, let me emphasize this moment, how we manage to simply cooperate. Mr. Chairman! Commissioner! Mr. Lehne! From the beginning of my work in the European Parliament, I have been in the same committee and I am dealing with the graduation processes. Let me emphasize that I appreciate this graduation process, especially when it comes to the European Commission. We didn't really have red field areas. We had a very clear presentation of this attitude to efficiency, effects, and the purposefulness of the costs incurred. We rarely even used the word "expenses", we talked about financing, I want to emphasize once again - about the results achieved, and let us remember that there is an increasingly balanced picture of effectiveness. And for that I would like to thank the Commission and the European Court of Auditors. I am glad that Minister Borg is here on behalf of the Council - this has not happened before. Our reservations, however, are raised by the provisions concerning the Martin Schulz case.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mister President! I would like to thank my colleagues Lehne and Oettinger very warmly for actually getting back to the essentials, that of course we need performance-based budgeting. In the development fund in particular, we have found that an error rate of 5.8% is at the upper limit of the tolerance. We can of course also see that the Court of Auditors has carried out a good audit here. We can be proud of that because there is room for improvement here. Now we are turning to the European Fund for Sustainable Development, which is only a guarantee, quasi a guarantee. For me, one thing is always clear: if you vouch, then you pay. Some of our colleagues believe that in this area too it is money that you can simply spend and that does not have to come back. It is therefore important to look at the return on investment here and to guarantee that the money that is only borrowed here will be repaid to the taxpayer accordingly. So believe that "More for More" is important and that you shouldn't pay into governments that are not democratic.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: draftswoman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, Commissioner, President of the European Court of Auditors, tomorrow we will have to approve the most important documents on the management of common European resources. I would like to add a few considerations on behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. Already as the rapporteur of the main report on the European Commission's discharge for 2014, last year I sought to see the discharge as an effective part of the life cycle of the management of European citizens' funds. That is why I am glad that the discharge becomes a logical and objective document, not a tool for slandering randomly selected culprits. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Zeller, very much for continuing this journey. We must not only look for, describe and correct mistakes, but above all we need to learn from them, identify the cause of failure and find a long-term solution, ideally of a preventive nature. However, the issue of error can never have one universal solution for all member states. I therefore consider it important that we learn from each other, look for examples of good practice and not waste time laboriously looking for existing solutions. Our view on results and performance should be the same, and thank you for mentioning that, Commissioner. The Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe will never compromise on the proper control and audit of projects, on sound financial management, on transparency, on objectivity or on the responsibility of those who manage European funds. But on the other hand, we want to see the concrete results, the added value and the tangible benefits of every euro invested. Our primary interest is the implementation of meaningful projects with high added value increasing the living standards of the citizens of the European Union. All scarce resources, and this is doubly true for financial ones, must be allocated efficiently and economically so as to guarantee the highest possible added value from the provider's point of view and from the recipient's point of view. I thank the European Commission, the European Court of Auditors for their cooperation and all my colleagues in the Committee on Budgetary Control for their ongoing work.Thank you for your attention and up to the next discharge!

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Mr President, Honorable Commissioner, Minister, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, the REGI Committee on Regional Policy discussed and adopted its opinion on the European Commission's 2015 discharge report. We have made a number of findings and recommendations, and I am glad that they have found a place in the final report we are discussing today. First of all, we emphasize that the level of error in cohesion policy is declining, and this is the result of the efforts of both the Member States and the European Commission. The main sources of error are the same, unfortunately: public procurement, eligibility and state aid rules. It is worrying that there is a reduction in payment requests, which reduces both the level of errors and the level of payments, but at the same time puts at risk the implementation of the budget for the whole programming period. I would especially like to thank the Court of Auditors for the way in which it prepared the report and for emphasizing the effect and the results.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Rapporteur for opinion Opinion Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, gender equality is an explicit goal of several sections of the Union's budget. But I want to emphasize that its integration is not a political objective in itself, but an essential instrument that must continue integration actions throughout the budgetary procedure in all European strategies. I also believe that it is vital to accelerate the promotion of the strategic commitment to gender equality for the period 2016-2019, because in the existing policies for the post-2015 period the budgetary resources allocated specifically for gender issues have decreased. Last but not least, I would like to draw attention to the need for a concrete analysis of the achievement of the gender objectives mentioned in the 2020 Strategy, to be included in the Court of Auditors' annual evaluation reports on the implementation of the Union budget.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, this year's final accounts procedure was, in my view, a successful joint effort. We thank the European Court of Auditors, the President and his staff for their excellent report, which has facilitated the work of each of the European Parliament's rapporteurs. I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on their careful and cooperative work. Of course, I don’t think the results, they would be some kind of unnecessary self-praise. Thanks to the successful work, we were able to uncover many errors and many inaccuracies in the final accounts procedure. Still, it is important that perhaps this year will be a year in which all the institutions can be discharged in addition to the Council's discharge. This shows that the work of the European institutions has been responsible for the responsible use of European taxpayers' money. With regard to the European Parliament's final accounts, I consider it particularly important that this is called the clearing of the fact that, unfortunately, there have been clear, unequivocal and serious irregularities in the actions of the former President of the European Parliament. I find it unacceptable that the Socialist Group is initiating the deletion of these findings with a motion for a group amendment. The People's Party is clearly in favor of calling the mistakes made, in accordance with the majority opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, even if the former President of the European Parliament is responsible for these mistakes.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, Minister, dear ex-colleague Lehne, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, dear colleagues! With my contribution - I can agree with Mr Deutsch - I would like to concentrate on the discharge of the European Parliament and talk about the sections that deal with the conduct of the former President of this House, Martin Schulz. What the Committee on Budgetary Control has decided here is, in my opinion, substantially wrong, excessive in its descriptions, redundant in content, goes far beyond the mandate of the Committee on Budgetary Control and thus actually constitutes a violation of the House's rules of procedure, which describe the tasks of the Committee on Budgetary Control: This does not include election campaigns. Why campaign? Because the task of the discharge report should be to deal with the housekeeping of the house and not to settle the accounts with functionaries about whom one has been annoyed. But the chairwoman of the Budgetary Control Committee, the German CDU member Ingeborg Gräßle, and her colleagues never tire of attacking Martin Schulz with strong words, who is now known to be the candidate for chancellor of my party, the SPD. Any decision criticized by the Committee on Budgetary Control has been classified as compliant by the administration of this House. A process not - but then it was not implemented. So, there is no violation of the rules - the Committee on Budgetary Control claims the opposite. That is dishonest and a political maneuver to gain advantages in the German federal election campaign. For example, where is a verifiable error? In the much discussed long-term business trips. The administration has just announced in the past that it will only discontinue continuous business trips for the EP office in Washington. This dissolves an allegation in thin air. But in order to be able to maintain the allegations, it is then cited incorrectly and interpreted incorrectly. At least that's sloppy, but actually manipulative. In the absence of any breach of the rules, OLAF, the European Union's Anti-Fraud Office, also announced today that it will not initiate an investigation. There is no such thing as a Schulz case. But I would like to draw your attention to a connection which, in my opinion, still plays too little role in the deliberations and in the reports on the unjustified allegations. If it is the case that the administration has established the legality of the behavior of the former speaker of parliament, what does that actually say about the parliament administration - the administration which, as secretary general, is headed by the German Christian Democrat Klaus Welle and who is also with us this evening? Because either the administration is right after all, then the allegations against Martin Schulz are unfounded, or the Budgetary Control Committee is right, then the Secretary General must also be made responsible for the behavior of his administration, because it would have covered and implemented alleged misconduct by the President. In any case, my group will ensure that this role of the EP administration and the responsibility of the Secretary-General are discussed. My group is getting the situation right with the amendments that we are putting forward. Save the good reputation of the house and support us!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, speaking generally, I deeply agree that, for the 22nd year in a row, the budget as a whole has not received a positive statement of assurance from the Court of Auditors. Payments are still materially affected by error. Going into detail, I strongly remark that the biggest issue, as far as the discharge procedure is concerned, is the lack of cooperation on the Council’s side. In 2009, the Council refused to cooperate in the discharge procedure as implemented by Parliament, failing to provide the necessary information asked for in written questions, and did not attend debates on the implementation of its own budget. Answers to our questions are essential for the discharge procedure. We need answers about the main weaknesses found by the ECA which, among others, are the high amounts of appropriations being carried over from 2015-2016, particularly those on property, plant and equipment, the delivery delay on the Europa building, and unclear building policy. The question of job tier balance, which should remain an important element of resources management, particularly with respect to the Member States that have acceded to the Union in 2004. Member States which acceded to our Union in 2004, or later, are still under-represented at the higher level of administration, in managerial posts, for which progress is still awaited.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, at the beginning of this debate, you did not limit or say that green cards are forbidden.That is why I want to ask, according to the Rules of Procedure, when I signaled the green card after my colleague Gräßle was attacked, and I wanted to ask Mr Geier what these allegations are based on, why and according to which section of the Rules of Procedure I was not allowed to use the green card.at this meeting?Can you explain that to us?Can you explain why your two co-workers sitting next to you, even though they saw this green card signaling, did not respond?

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr Zdechovský!I did not chair from the beginning and I do not know if Mr Wieland announced it, but I would like to make the following request: it is 22.12, in addition to this item, we have three items on the agenda of this evening's sitting.I would like to ask: we are not using a blue card because we should end our sitting before midnight.Secondly, the reports that we are discussing - both by the Court of Auditors and by the individual rapporteurs - seem clear, unambiguous, and so this is the reason why I propose: we are not using a blue card!

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, since 2007 the European Court of Auditors has been issuing two opinions on the general budget: an audit of the accounts and an audit of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. The only one of those two opinions that matters is the second. So why two sets of audits? It’s a smokescreen.  This is a gloss, a flagrant attempt to disguise the fact that, in the audit that matters, year after year the EU’s general budget accounts fail to meet minimum accounting standards. To quote Mr Zeller’s statement, we deeply regret that, for the 22nd year in a row, payments are materially affected by error because of the fact that the supervisory and control systems are only partially effective. This means that we have ended up with a 3.8% error rate, with thousands of millions of euros not properly accounted for – not just this year, but year after year. I propose that we vote against granting this discharge. It is time we took a stand and forced the Commission to get its house in order. I am actually bemused as to why everyone is so happy about this.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the President of the Court of Auditors for his work on the special reports. I think it is a big step forward and it helps Parliament a lot in the discharge activity and it also achieves those budget principles based on performance and it also analyzes the results of the budget in the territory and it is an extremely important thing. I would just like to refer to the discharge for the Council, again we will vote tomorrow to postpone the discharge and I think that such a decision is not good. This has been happening for years. I think it diminishes the credibility of the budget discharge process and we should do something about it. I hope that now, with this postponement, we will have the time to find a way to reach an agreement. Thus, in the end, all the work done by both Parliament and the Council and the Court of Auditors is jeopardized.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Dear Mr President, dear members of the Court of Auditors! Today I would like to thank you very much for the good and fruitful cooperation and would like to add to much of what was said in advance. One of the repeated points is the error rate in the various areas. But I think that shows that we are working properly here. I would rather be puzzled by a report that no longer shows any errors. I believe that we have learned - and, above all, the Court of Auditors has also learned - where the weak points are, and therefore it is also important to look closely at these reports, because we should be learning organizations and, together with the institutions audited, determine why these errors occur, how we can avoid them together. A second area is the agencies, which I would like to address very consciously today. In the last few weeks and months it seems to me to have become a kind of sport to hack into the various agencies and say: We don't need them. But the reports of the Court of Auditors, the entire work and the examination of the employment agencies have shown that they are very valuable instruments for implementing the demands that we as a European organization have - regardless of whether it is in the environmental or health sector. We have agencies that do a great job. My request also goes to the Commission that, in the course of the budget consolidation that is of course necessary, we should also ensure that the agencies are equipped with the appropriate financial and human resources in order to be able to meet these demands on them in the future and to meet the expectations of them Europeans to meet.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: - Mr President, I had another point ready, but I still think it is important to talk about the credibility of this committee, about the fact that we should, in a very objective way, very coldly follow the way European money is spent, such asprotected the financial interests of the European Union, instead we see how this commission is involved in the electoral struggle in a member state of the European Union, how it is used as an electoral tool against one candidate so that the other candidate has an open corridor.I believe that the involvement of this committee in an electoral struggle destroys the credibility not only of the committee but also of the European Parliament and ultimately undermines all the efforts we have made so far.I believe that a much stronger attitude of the European Parliament leadership should be taken, and I believe that such attitudes should be sanctioned in the future.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to defend myself very strongly against our President Ingeborg Gräßle's accusation that she was the one to settle accounts with her in this Chamber or with a former President of the European Parliament during the campaign. I really consider such an accusation to be stupid, and it is a pity that my colleague is not here to listen to my speech. Next, I would say to the agencies, ladies and gentlemen, after two or three years of hard work and riding around the agencies, I can say that the results of the agencies are simply excellent. We must say that the agencies have made enormous progress. But what not all our agencies can do is that they can't present the work. I am very pleased for the cooperation with Mr Lehn and the European Accounting Officer, because it is thanks to their pressure and their new methods and new approach that these things are wonderful to see. So I wish we all could be able to present this work better. And really let me defend myself against what has been said here. It is completely, utterly undignified and false of Mrs Gräßle.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, first of all let me thank the rapporteurs and everyone involved, the Court of Auditors, and I also welcome Commissioner Oettinger to his first discharge from that Chair. Having one minute on the discharge is like reading out loud a random page of the Bible so I will only choose two things tonight in my short speech. A very valuable observation – not maybe a finding, because we all know this – but it is a fact that the budgetary cycle needs to be changed. This is number one. Number two perhaps is the ever-growing importance of emphasising performance. Those are the two things that I choose to say tonight in one minute. It would be nice sometime to do this in a shorter timespan so that we would be able to react faster to deficiencies and problems.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Mr President-in-Office of the Council! Well, I'm sorry now that colleague Geier left. First tenet in politics: don't lose your nerve. So, dear Jens Geier, you are actually much more intelligent than what you delivered here this evening. I would like to read something that the Secretary-General has told us: the only binding opinion of the administration on this matter is the report from the Secretary-General to the Committee on Budgetary Control. Lies just don't get truer just by repeating them over and over. I would like to pass this on to my colleagues in Social Democracy. I should like to say that the circumstances of these amendments or these passages of text which we have approved by a large majority in the Committee on Budgetary Control are already getting bizarre. If the current President of Parliament is threatened with reprisals, it is really going too far. I can already say: it is our duty to stick to the truth. I am grateful to the committee for presenting these texts in this way and I am grateful to Dennis de Jong. I think we should reject fake news precisely because we are the European Parliament. So please reject the S&D motions because they are simply not correct.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the EIB and the Court of Auditors for their work for European prosperity, and Ms Gräßle for her dedication to better discharge procedure. In the future, I would like to see more analytical information and data – for example, in the EIB Annual Report – rather than just technical data. Numbers are beautiful, but what matters is the results – to make countries richer and people’s lives better. For example, I would like to see more concrete information on how EIB financial instruments make access to SMEs for funding, especially when it comes to higher-risk projects. I would like to see how EIB instruments are making the achievement of Europe 2020 goals better and faster. I am sure more transparency and better evaluation of higher risk projects is crucial. Last, but not least, to call EFSI really good, it should be worked adequately across Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, I leave the intra-German party conflict to the other colleagues. I would like to refer to the European Network and Information Security Agency, ENISA, as I did last year, and say that an insidious attempt is being made by the ENISA leadership to move an organization from Heraklion, Crete to Athens and then outside Greece. . I have followed the issue in 2012 and 2013. It was planned to essentially separate the Organization into an administrative department, which remained in Heraklion, and a scientific department, which came to Athens. While it has free space of 4.5 thousand square meters in Heraklion, in order to stay, nevertheless the organization insists on coming to Athens, and even the report says so; it now refers to the efforts of the Organization to leave Heraklion and come to Athens, because it has, he says, expenses. But he created the expenses, because the leadership of the Organization wanted to come to Athens! To stay in Heraklion! This is the decision. I am not going to vote for the discharge and I will continue to do so, and you in the Court of Auditors and Mr Oettinger can see this. It is very serious.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the Court of Auditors. - Mr President, thank you very much! I would like to thank everyone who spoke here today for the kind words that have been said to us - to the Court of Auditors. Mr Lazarou and I - I should like to draw your particular attention to Mr Lazarou, because he was the person who did most of the work in preparing the Court of Auditors' annual report because he is our Court's main rapporteur - and his colleagues - he himself saw all of this -, but I will also be very, very happy to pass on these good wishes and the many thanks that have been given to his colleagues. I am sure that it will please all of you and encourage you to continue doing good work in the interests of our common cause in the future. I heard a lot today when I could have applauded loudly, but as President of the European Court of Auditors I am no longer entitled to do so in this House. That is why I take the liberty of giving back this thank you and this applause literally, so to speak, without being able to formally express and carry it out. I would like to end by saying something about a number of points. I have a lot of sympathy for the idea of ​​reducing the medium-term financial framework from seven to five years. This is a topic that also played a role in our internal discussions. It would certainly have the great advantage - if I may say that as a personal opinion here - that every parliament, every legislator, would then have the opportunity to contribute to a medium-term financial framework, because the legislative period of the European Parliament and also the scope of activities of European Commission covers this period of five years. That is a very interesting consideration. Another point concerns the question of shadow budgets, which is also various been addressed. It is of course right that certain areas - ESM, ESFS - have been raised - are outside the contractual framework of the Community structure; that won't be possible there. But in the debates that took place in connection with the statements on the MFF, completely different things were also discussed, which are very much outside of the existing structures and which one has to think about - if only from the point of view of transparency - to bring them back into the structure of the budget in the foreseeable future - sometime -. That will not be possible everywhere either, but one should at least have the goal in mind so that in the end - as the chairman of the Committee on Budgets in this House once said - one does not have a galaxy of budgets and transparency and clarity are retained. With all that has been said, perhaps I would like to break a lance for all of us who have been trying for years to improve the situation significantly and to see the whole picture. I myself have been a member of this House for 20 years and have now been a member of the Court of Auditors for more than three years. I think I have some overview of this period. When I look at the situation and the situation from 20 years ago, where there were no functioning internal controls by the Commission, and where we as the Court of Auditors did not yet publish specific error rates because everyone knew that in certain sectors of the budget, double-digit error rates existed, and I compare the situation then with the situation we have today, where we have made tremendous progress, where we have really made significant changes towards significantly better budgetary and financial management, then I believe is Overall, a great deal has been achieved in these 20 years. Not yet enough, it can get better.That is why the criticism is always right - and we have to develop further, but when you look at the picture as a whole, I do believe that these have been huge steps forward.We have to keep working on it.On our part, I can promise Mr. Novakov in particular that we will determine even more analytical, concrete information in the future and make it available to you for your consultations.We are also of the opinion that mere numbers and statistics alone are not enough, but that we need “more” information for qualitative tests.We will do our part to do this.I thank you for the attention.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Parliament, Council, Court of Auditors and the Commission are independent bodies of the European Union. But we are united by the task of budgetary policy and the goal that budget programs want to achieve. That is why I understood today's debate in the sense of coming from different competencies to a common goal. Thank you for the constructive advice. We promise you that we will take up the recommendations in the discharge report, which you will adopt tomorrow, over the next few months. For the first time already in the draft budget for 2018, which the Commission will present in two months - rather earlier, that is, at the end of May. Second, by making it the basis for the next multiannual budget. Third, by giving you a follow-up report later this year. And fourth, by building on the fact that all of this will also be reflected in the mid-term review over the next few weeks. Thank you very much! As a learning body, the commission is ready to take on the suggestions for improvement.

name: Ian Borg
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill. - Grazzi lill-Parlament talli stieden lill-Presidenza sabiex tiparteċipa f'dan id-dibattitu daqstant importanti u, iva, kif għedt, kemm-il darba l-Presidenza Maltija - jien jew sħabi - incunu hawnhekk sabiex nipparteċipaw f'din l democracy Ewropea, u naħseb li d-dibattitu tal-lum kien wieħed importanti u fejn intwera wkoll illi nikkondividu ħafna tħassib però wkoll pożittivi fuq il-futur. We are just looking for a new or very successful company in Europe and the European Union Ewropew - the European continent Ewropew - we are very competitive in the world. Fir-rigward anki taċ-ċirkustanzi li r-riżorsi huma limitati, il-fatt illi naħdmu sabiex ma jintilfix imqar ċenteżmu wieħed jibqa 'punt kruċjali, u allura jiena ngħid, ejja permezz anki ta' dħ idħtu on the other hand, the Council or the Court of Justice may, in the case of taxpayers, accept the tax of the Member States of the European Parliament and of the Council of the European Parliament, qed jikkontribwixxu qed immorru lura għandhom permezz tal-ġid komuni li jinħoloq.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I would like to thank President Lehne, Commissioner Oettinger and many colleagues for addressing things that I could not mention earlier due to the passage of time, but which are also very important to me. That is the treatment of the issue of shadow budgets and secondary budgets, in which there is a lot of European money from the budget, but which contain problems with parliamentary control and risks in the control and coordination of EU strategies. I would like to point out that at the end of 2015 there were more than 1,000 financial instruments, but where the outflow of funds to the beneficiaries was very different. There have been countries where not even 40 of these funds have been passed on to the beneficiaries. I think the Commission should be bolder here and recover funds that have not been used. In addition, the question for the future is: do we always reach the right people? If I have to state that 80% of the agricultural funds that are paid out only go to 20% of the beneficiaries, I believe there is a disproportion that we should face, especially since agriculture can now also make good money, as evidenced by constantly rising land prices for agricultural land. 2015 was also the year of the payment overhang for the previous funding period, although we were already in the second year of the start of the new funding period. In the Member States, not even 20% of the administrative bodies had yet been designated and certified, which means there is a risk of further delay in the implementation of the structural funds, which we should and must now face in our mid-term review. At the same time, there is a second report that I would like to refer to, namely the summary of all the special and special reports by the Court of Auditors, for which I am very grateful because they provide valuable information and which, unfortunately, from God in the Technical committees, for which they are actually intended, have not yet received the appreciation and discussion that they are worth.Thank you very much, and I hope that both reports will now not only disappear into files, but that what has been said by everyone will form the basis for our further work.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: protractor. - Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Oettinger, Mr Borg and Mr Lehne for their comments. As for the EDF, the Council's presence is all the more interesting, since you know that it is outside the EU budget and results from the contribution of the Member States. Many questions were raised: that of error rates - I will not come back to this, the room for improvement for the EDF is important - such as those of performance and efficiency. Regarding performance and efficiency, these are difficult questions for the EDF since you know that the objectives can be weakened by crises, both climatic and political, and wars. We must also take into account, however, that we are at a time when the peoples of Europe tend to retreat to continental borders, at a time when there is also a sense of despair in Europe. In this context, we must provide proof that aid vis-à-vis third countries, vis-à-vis ACP countries, reaches its destination, that it can achieve performance and, above all, that it is controlled .
