That is why we have carried out this control with the utmost seriousness, because I believe that it is the very guarantee of the sustainability of this absolutely necessary development aid policy.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Reporter. - First of all, I have to make amends, because I had not yet explicitly thanked the Court of Auditors, including for cooperation in the area of ​​Parliament's budget. I did comment on the fact that in the future they can probably draw and hopefully receive more attention for this with a possibly special report. What I really only want to comment on is the discussion that has just arisen about what the previous President of Parliament may or may not have done. I must say, as rapporteur, I do not like it when a colleague, including from the Committee on Budgetary Control, is being blamed. I know the chairman as an extremely hard-working chairman of this committee, with whom I have done many things together. I do not think it does justice to anyone, but certainly not the chairman, to detract from that. Having said that, the whole procedure around the paragraphs at issue here has been tricky because we raised this issue in the discharge last year. Then there were clear paragraphs about the President's behavior. These have suddenly disappeared in plenary, at least with the consent of the large groups. This year it suddenly returns at a very late stage in the procedure. That is difficult, annoying for me as a rapporteur, and I can only say that I am concentrating on the facts and will support those texts that show very clearly what is actually going on. For the rest, I really hope that the other 30 pages of the resolution will become more central, because they contain the recommendations that we really have to continue with next year. I once again appeal to the Bureau and the Secretary-General to send us a quick progress report, including on how those recommendations will be implemented.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: performer. - Mr President, at the end of the debate, I too would just like to thank you once again for the arguments you have made in the debate and for the comments that may have escaped my attention as an rapporteur on an institution. Let me just make a comment on the European Parliament's discharge. There has been a lot of talk about President Schulz's case, but from a different point of view, I would like to draw attention to certain areas of this parliamentary discharge. This is an important thing, not only for the President of Parliament, but also for the transparency of Members and the correctness of their spending, and I think it has been a recurring debate for years about how transparent Members' general expenses are as public, how transparent. to the public. And in the same way, a recurring problem for years has been the issue of Members' side posts, second posts and paid mandates. I think that Parliament should set an example in this matter and that Members should create the fullest possible transparency about their own spending and their own paid jobs. We would then be in a position to rightly point to other institutions and demand that they genuinely credibly adhere to and implement the same principles of transparency.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: speaker. - Mr President, in conclusion I would like to refer precisely to the sections that were approved in the discharge of Parliament in the Committee on Budgetary Control by 15 votes in favor, 7 against and 7 abstentions. In other words, 15 members were in favor and 14 had either some reservations or of course they were against. I would also like to refer to the misfortune that the motivation is purely political, when historically and traditionally the Committee on Budgetary Control tends to have institutional respect precisely for the electoral procedures of the Member States. In fact, we do not travel, we do not do missions, precisely respecting that situation scrupulously. Despite this, as early as 2014, despite the fact that President Martin Schulz had been in the Presidency for two years, precisely that year, in which he became the Spitzenkandidat of the Socialists, he was attacked for the first time. Not before. This year. And precisely by whom? By your German colleagues from the PPE. Last year we returned to the fray. But last year we were finally able to negotiate, precisely after both the president, Martin Schulz, and the general secretary, representing the administration, gave us answers to all the questions that had been raised in the previous questionnaire. And I regret that, in paragraph 38 of this text of the Resolution, the democratic procedure is regretted, which was won by 480 votes in favor and 190 against. I believe that democracy, of course, must be recognized and, being able, to be rebuilt as it was done, the truth. And this year it is painful to see that, again, and in this case we are talking about an absolutely legitimate procedure in a country such as Germany, a candidate to be German Chancellor is being attacked from this House with half truths or rather half lies. to such an extent that we have the National Front supporting more and more. I would certainly be concerned if I were the author of such texts or the author of such texts, because it has even gone so far that in some cases it has been claimed that a majority group supported these National Front texts by attacking President Schulz, we all know for what reasons.It certainly saddens me enormously that this House is being used for those reasons.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.Let me make the following observation: we are already positive overall and have a high level of agreement in terms of numbers, facts, error rate.As I understand it, there is some discrepancy in the political judgments, but that is always Parliament's charm.The vote will take place on Thursday 27 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- The discharge for the implementation of the European Parliament's budget for the financial year 2015 enables, in the first instance, the smooth operation of this institution.Accounting documentation and financial statements indicate that there were no major problems and errors in budget execution.However, I believe that financial and budgetary management procedures need to be improved.Transparency in the work of the European Parliament and its internal procedures is crucial in order to raise citizens' confidence in Parliament's legitimacy and facilitate access to information.In this context, I welcome the fact that a list of all suppliers with whom a contract worth more than EUR 15,000 has been concluded has been published on Parliament's website.I believe that monitoring the implementation of the budget of the European institutions is necessary to ensure that the political leadership and administration are accountable to the citizens of the Union.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Ulrika Rodust, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the management of fishing fleets in the outermost regions (2016/2016 (INI)) (A8-0340 / 2016).

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: Rapporteur. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! With an own-initiative report, the European Parliament would like to focus on a matter, a question or a region. I think that was achieved in the own-initiative report on the management of the fishing fleets in the outermost regions. The report calls for better data programs to be developed, particularly with regard to the state of the stocks. In order to reduce illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, better controls are needed. The report therefore calls for active measures such as monitoring and negotiations to be launched with neighboring countries with which fisheries partnership agreements have not yet been concluded. These agreements are also intended to take account of the interests of the outermost regions by landing catches in these areas and giving preference to locals when placing jobs on the fishing vessels. The Commission has asked to review the development of a financial instrument based on the POSEI for fisheries in the outermost regions. It is also proposed to increase the aid intensity for new engines. Here I would like, I have to mention, that the EMFF already provides for compensation for additional costs, which are 100% subsidized by the fisheries fund, for these areas and have been increased compared to the previous fund. In addition, the aid intensity for other measures in these areas has been increased by 35%. The Member States and the outermost regions are encouraged to make the best possible use of the de minimis or block exemption regime. Synergies between the various European structural and investment funds should be better represented. The report therefore makes a number of proposals for better exploiting the fishing potential in the areas outermost. Some proposals imply an exemption for these outermost regions. These are to be seen as an addition to the existing ones. I would now like to comment on the amendment that was the only one tabled that calls for public funding for new ships. A corresponding amendment - I shall call it the previous amendment - was rejected in the Fisheries Committee. I acknowledge that the amendment tabled for plenary now states that the capacity limits of the common fisheries policy must be respected and that funding can only be provided in exchange for an old ship. In addition, it must be possible to achieve the desired maximum possible long-term yield. I would like to say, however, that the exchange of old and new is already possible today, but without public funding, mind you. The authors of the amendment refer to Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Yes, Article 349 can be the basis for specific measures in the outermost regions. However, these specific measures must be designed in such a way that they do not undermine the coherence and integrity of a common policy. The common fisheries policy and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund do not allow public financing of new buildings. All of this can be found in Article 23 of the Basic Regulation and Article 11 of the EMFF. According to the amendment, fishing boats should be made safer and more environmentally friendly. There is already money in the EMFF for this. Article 32 should be mentioned here, for example. In addition, the demand for public support for ships does not seem to me to be coherent with the EU initiative launched within the framework of the WTO to force a ban on subsidies in the fishing sector. I am going to vote against this amendment because it is against them GFP and opens Pandora's box.This is where fishing is going on for future subsidies for fisheries in other regions, and other fishermen in the EU would then rightly request public funds for new buildings.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! On behalf of the Commission, I should like to thank Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Mrs Rodust, and her team, for producing this extremely knowledgeable report. Personally, I am not a specialist, but I read the report and learned a lot in the process. It is well-balanced, presents the difficulties of the fishing industry in the outermost regions in a very specific way, and it also proposes very specific measures on how to tackle the problems and stabilize the sector. We accept, and are also acting as the Commission ourselves, that the special conditions in these outermost regions call for tailor-made solutions. With the redesign of the common fisheries policy and our common financing instrument, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, we have also taken important future-oriented steps. With the next budget, and even more so with the next budget and program period, we will try to further improve these measures on the basis of your proposals. The measures are exclusive access conditions, the regionalization of conservation measures, the special advisory board proposed here, measures for small fleets, a greater intensity of financial aid, a system to compensate for additional costs, to name just a few essential ones. In addition, we also support the work of national and regional levels and authorities and provide suggestions here. The whole thing is a joint task of the European level, but also of the national authorities and the regional authorities. Just examples where regional and national authorities are important: The new framework for scientific fisheries data proposed by the Commission contains specific requirements for the areas in outermost location.However, the responsibility for implementing the requirements lies largely with the Member States and the research institutes, which are supported by the Member States, and in part also with the entrepreneurs in the fishing industry themselves. All in all, I believe the report is a good basis.We are happy to take him in.The competent authorities in the Commission and my colleagues would be happy to enter into a deeper dialogue with you, Mrs Rodust, and your colleagues.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development.- Mr. President, of what overfishing would the overseas be guilty?In the Indian Ocean, where I come from, the Reunionese catch 0.16% of the total that is caught, or no more than 2,500 tonnes of the 1,600,000 tonnes caught in our waters by international and European fleets.This is injustice and this is what our amendment seeks to correct!What we are asking for is reasonable because, as you know, it is conditioned on scrupulous respect for the principles of sustainability laid down by the CFP.Moreover, the report of the Committee on Regional Development made the same proposal.Dear colleagues, tomorrow, far from the false campaigns and in peace, let us bring our support to the outermost regions so that fishing can contribute to the development of these disaster-stricken regions.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, today we emphasize, once again, the relevance of the blue economy, of maritime affairs, but, more specifically, the importance of fisheries for the economic and social development of the outermost regions. We clearly need the commitment of all, political actors, regional and local authorities, to define the future common fisheries policy. Today, we reinforce the need for the European financing instrument dedicated to fisheries, similar to what happens in agriculture. We strive for a more solidary Union, for a more social Europe, for a Europe that respects and complies with its Treaties. We will have it, if we do not fail with the outermost fishermen, who are also European citizens. Supporting the renewal of the outermost fishing vessels does not jeopardize the common fisheries policy or the EMFF. They are vessels with specific characteristics and constraints. To renew them is to guarantee the safety of those who work at sea, it is to improve the quality of the fish, it is to protect the marine ecosystem. Count on the approval of this cause by all the political parties, certain that they will not disappoint the citizens who elected us to defend them here.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, I would also like to welcome the effort and dedication of rapporteur Ulrike Rodust. The outermost regions are differentiated areas and, for that reason, are the subject of a specific article in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Based on this legal context, the own-initiative report that we are discussing here rightly calls for the creation of a financing instrument that differentiates these regions. In order to grant public aid for the replacement of vessels, tomorrow an amendment will be voted that calls for the opening of this possibility. It is important that public aid can be granted to fishermen in these remote areas and that does not hurt the common fisheries policy, it only requires the amendment of a recommendation from the European Commission. In addition, public aid for the replacement of vessels is inhibited by a recommendation from the Commission, not by the basic regulation of the CFP. A recommendation that has not even passed through the European Parliament or the European Council.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club.- Mr President, we must pay special attention to the outermost regions when adopting all European policies, because they are at a disadvantage from the rest of the Union due to traffic and any other isolation.However, I would like to draw attention to similar problems that islands have, especially in less developed member states such as Croatia.The fate of the inhabitants of the Croatian islands is not much different from that of the inhabitants of the most remote regions.That is why I hereby call on the Commission to amend the Mediterranean Regulation in order to enable the inhabitants of the Mediterranean islands to be able to fish for their own needs again with their traditional tools.Parliament supported my report on small-scale coastal fishing by a large majority last year, and the Commission should be guided by the opinion of this House.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, this report on the regime of the fishing fleet in the outermost regions is one of those extraordinary occasions to go from words to deeds and to ask for coherence, empathy and understanding from the organizations that traditionally and mistakenly associate any fishing activity with the attack on marine ecosystems. I believe that the first interested in the sustainability of the fishing activity are the fishermen themselves. And I have verified it, for example, in the Canary Islands, listening to the people in charge of brotherhoods and professionals speak with love and respect of the sea and its life. For this reason, I will fully support their right to intensive European aid to renew their fleets. We are talking about improving your safety and working conditions in an environment that needs more and better jobs. We are talking about operating with more energy efficient, less polluting and more modern ships, which will undoubtedly facilitate the control of your activity. So we do not intend to increase fishing capacity. The improvement of the fleet is not done at the cost of damaging the balance between extractive activity and conservation. Finally, I want to insist and encourage a serious study to be carried out on the impact of recreational fishing in these areas, an insistent claim from the sector, especially where tourism is growing the most. Professionals want and have the right to more information and control over these recreational activities that, due to their current size and growth, put pressure on fishing stocks.

name: João FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, this report recognizes that the common fisheries policy does not respond to the specificities and needs of the outermost regions. It is a positive step, but it now requires, at the very least, legislative changes to correct what is wrong. We value the proposal to create a new POSEI-Fisheries, which we have been fighting for a long time and which we consider essential to combat permanent disadvantages and constraints that these regions face. As regards the needs for modernization and renewal of the fishing fleet in these regions, it is necessary to go further and, therefore, we support the proposal for an amendment that goes in this direction, which seems extremely thoughtful and moderate. We will continue to fight for the expansion of the reserve area of ​​exclusive access for the fleets of each region up to the limit of the Exclusive Economic Zone, that is, from the current 100 to 200 miles. As well as we will continue to support measures that positively discriminate against small-scale fishing segments, in view of environmental, social and economic sustainability objectives.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the overseas fishing fleet is aging; the boats are between thirty and forty years old on average. Therefore, for safety reasons, these vessels fish near the coasts, where the resource is dwindling while, offshore, it is literally plundered by illegal fishing, which is booming, particularly in the French overseas territories. It is therefore time for the European Union to agree to finance, via the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and by the Member States, the renewal of the small-scale fishing fleet, which it has not allowed since the 1990s. so as not to increase fishing capacity. Mrs Rodust's report notes, but does not call into question, this ban. That is why I will support with my group the amendment allowing this funding. I would remind you that, overseas, the youth unemployment rate is sometimes over 50%, especially in Guyana, and fishing can create many jobs. It is therefore fundamental to take common-sense measures to develop economic activity in these forgotten territories, while promoting sustainable fishing.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, Commissioners, you can assume that it is a satisfaction for me as a Canary that we are debating the report on the management of fishing fleets in the ORs. In it we ask for a single instrument dedicated to supporting fisheries in these regions: a POSEI program for fisheries. Also a better exploitation of the potential that aquaculture has in these regions and, of course, better incentives to implement and encourage young people to work in the fishing sector and, of course, always taking into account the specific characteristics of the ORs . But we miss something: an element that is the possibility of allowing under very strict conditions, really strict, and in line with the objective of sustainable fishing, financing for the renovation of artisanal and traditional fishing vessels in the ORs. It is not true what is being said. More fishing is not intended. It is about fishermen from the outermost regions being able to go fishing where others go, who also deplete the seas. It's about not protecting the hundred miles for the local fleet. How can the local fleet go a hundred miles with obsolete boats over twenty years old, without safety conditions, without hygienic conditions, without insurance because the insurance companies themselves do not insure that fleet? It makes no sense at all. We are not talking about opening the field to give more money to renew fleets without any type of limit. We are talking about renewing, with all the limitations, the artisanal fleets of the outermost regions, which will also land in those regions. I advise you to read the amendment, not to do more demagogy, not to use the organizations as they are using them to go against the fishermen of the outermost regions. Please read the amendment and you will see that what they are saying is absolutely untrue.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the outermost regions of the Union are in crisis and face great poverty. All over the world, the Union buys fishing rights and in some of these regions, it is European resources that are sold to third countries. Article 349 of the Treaty considers the outermost regions to be exceptions, due to their geographic remoteness, additional costs and large areas of poverty. Today, this article has not been applied to fishing, which is why the exception for the renewal of the fleet is justified. We are talking about artisanal fishing and small, dilapidated and unsuitable vessels. Today, chlordecone, for example in the West Indies, prohibits fishermen from living off their work in the coastal strip or forces them to take disproportionate risks. All environmental and ecological precautions have been taken in the amendment that many of us bring to the plenary. In no case are there any plans to increase the capacity - we also respect the maximum sustainable yield. It is about replacing old boats with new ones. Dear colleagues, I ask you: let us show European solidarity and do not give in to disinformation.

name: Werner KUHN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I can only support what previous speakers have said. In all debates, regardless of the subject area that has been addressed here: when we talk about fisheries, the song of praise for aid to small-scale and artisanal fisheries is raised, and now we have a situation where we can really take action without that one great effort will be. In the EMFF, it is possible that we can tackle such subsidies, so to speak, also for maintenance and refurbishing, i.e. a basic overhaul of fishing vessels. But in parts these are just small beach boats that don't even have their own drive. But how are they supposed to go fishing from the coastal area to where they can then have better yields? That is not possible at all. It has already been said: in Guadeloupe, in Réunion, in regions which, in principle, would not create any distortion of competition with fisheries in continental Europe, and the fact that such a huge aid problem is being made out of it, I cannot at all understand. The application states that the Commission should examine possibilities and ensure that it is possible to finance the construction of such small fishing vessels. In this area, this also means that national funds can be used, not just European ones. I can only say simply: if we want to give a signal to small-scale and artisanal fisheries in Europe, then we should approve this motion.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, I am speaking to support the work of our rapporteur, Ulrike Rodust, but also as a Canarian, born and living in an outermost region. Because the outermost regions are the only ones that are mentioned by name in the primary law of the European Union, in article 349 of the TFEU, which allows arbitration of singular exceptions both in primary law and in secondary law. And this is exactly what should be done to protect the traditional and artisanal Canarian fishing, to allow the Commission to channel special aid for the renewal of a fleet that is obsolete, to improve its conditions not only hygienic and safety but also efficiency environmental, to dispense with more polluting fuels and to give, therefore, an opportunity for the future to a fishery that will not increase fishing capacity, much less the depletion of species, but, on the contrary, will give a horizon looking forward to fishing done with great dedication, done with great passion, by people of flesh and blood, making a better Europe where it is most needed: in the less favored regions, in the most remote regions, in the outermost regions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the outermost regions must indeed receive the attention of our Parliament and the European Union. This of course gives us the opportunity to turn to the Mediterranean, because there are many problems there, and in fact the terms of Article 349 of the Treaty are related to the small islands in the Mediterranean, especially the small Greek islands, because there is again small area, difficult soil morphology, economic dependence on a small number of products and distance. So for the Mediterranean and especially for Greece we must have regulations in relation to the directive on coastal fisheries and have changes, so that we can finally support the modernization of the fleet to have positive measures in favor of fishermen, to have a special regime, in essence, under the common fisheries policy with state interventions but also with aid from the European Union. I would like the Commissioner, Mr Oettinger, to see this in the future as well.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, one of the key features of the management of fishing fleets in the outermost regions.This characteristic is the specificity of these regions.The peculiarity of these regions, which speaks in favor of the need to be sensitive and to respect these specifics.Are we talking about the Atlantic Islands or, as a colleague says, the Indian Ocean?Well, they are already different from each other.And they are different from everything else that exists in the European Union.Of course we can talk about our Mediterranean islands which are also specific, but at this moment we really need to insist on those who live in a far different European Union than we live here on the continent and that is why I call for the report to be accepted.policies, but above all to take into account the specificity of these regions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the report we are going to vote on tomorrow, this Parliament stresses the need for the outermost regions to renew and modernize their fleets, especially in order to increase safety. For example, in these regions there is an objective impossibility for some fishermen to access credit and insurance for their vessels. It is therefore necessary to provide for measures to authorize public, national and European subsidies for the renewal of the small-scale fishing fleet of the outermost regions, within the limits of permitted fishing capacity, in order to increase not only the safety of vessels, but also environmental efficiency. and the fight against illegal fishing. The same goes for modernization. It is necessary to provide support, as part of a potential future CFP, for tools to counteract climate impacts with a proven negative effect on vessels. All the tools that will be suggested in the future should ensure sustainable fishing and healthy fish stocks. It is essential to make every effort to ensure that the fishing sectors in the outermost regions are not disadvantaged.

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I am aware that some of the outermost regions are poor. This is and was the reason why I initiated this report. Yes, the outermost regions and fishing conditions are not comparable to those in continental Europe. That is why the Common Fisheries Policy and the EMFF contain exceptions for these areas, that is, with these exceptions, the special features are taken into account or I have added further special features and improvements in the report. Here it is argued that new buildings are necessary in order to be able to reach distant stocks because the stocks within the 100 nautical miles have been fished out or there is environmental pollution. When I was on Reunion Island, I was told that the pollution was caused by pesticides from banana plantations, for example. Maybe the national government should do something about that. The fish stocks in the outermost regions are plentiful - I would like to believe that. But how do I deal with the 2016 report from STECF which failed to assess the balance between fishing capacity and fishing opportunities for all fleets in the outermost regions. This was mainly due to the fact that the biological data were insufficient. The data situation must therefore be improved. This is what it says in the report now. In the meantime, however, I have to ask myself what public financing of new buildings means against this background. I would now like to close with a question - it is probably a rhetorical question. Would the undersigned Members, who are not from the outermost regions, explain to fishermen in their regions that they are demanding public funding for new construction in remote areas? But not for them, for their fishermen since they are not that special.For me, this takes Pandora's box very strongly - since then, of course, other fishermen in the EU can rightly claim public funds for new buildings.They too have ships that are 30 to 40 years old and would be happy to get public funding.That is why I am going to reject this amendment tomorrow.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 27 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. –  I would like to extend my support towards those who are addressing the biggest challenges for outermost regions. The remoteness, insularity, small size, difficult topography and climate, economic dependence on a few products are permanent features that severely restrain outermost regions’ development. Those are problems that we in Europe do not fully understand because they don’t exist in here. The common fisheries policy is designed for the particular needs of the continental Europe. The reality in outermost regions is completely different. But we have tools that can be used to provide for the adoption of specific measures in their regard. Solution that is needed now is to allow local fishermen communities to renew and modernise their fleets. Safety or rather the lack of safety on board is a predominant problem now. I therefore support an amendment aiming at allowing, (obviously) under strict conditions and in line with the objective of sustainable fishing, public funding for modernisation of these regions' artisanal and traditional fishing vessels. The need for restructuring and development is pressing therefore, modernisation of the fleet is necessary, most importantly, for safety reasons.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Lola Sánchez Caldentey, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the EU flagship initiative on the garment industry (2016/2140 (INI)) (A8-0138 / 2017)

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: speaker. - Mr President, this week marks the fourth anniversary of one of the greatest industrial crimes in history: the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh, where pieces of clothing were manufactured for European firms. It cost the lives of more than 1,100 people and injured more than 2,500. The difficulty in establishing legal responsibilities for this crime showed that production chains as complex as that of textiles require control standards in accordance with it. But it also fostered awareness about the origin of the clothes we wear: people do not want to continue dressing at the cost of the slavery of others. And what is the European Union doing to ensure the dignity of women workers in the textile sector? It is true that initiatives have been launched by public and private actors to try to respond to citizen pressure; but all of them are voluntary, many of them are simple image washes that have not prevented the continued exploitation in the factories. Furthermore, many of these initiatives overlap and do not cover the entire supply chain. Therefore, the problem continues, and it is deregulation. In 2015, the European Commission promised an initiative on the sustainability of the sector at a global level, which it also called "emblematic". Two years later, it can be said that they have done practically nothing, because the working document, which they happen to present this week, is not going to end the abuses. Seventy-five million people live their particular Rana Plaza every day around the world: it is urgent that we take a step forward. This report aims to put an end to this situation, invisible in the Western world, but of which consumers involuntarily take advantage every time we get dressed. The most important dimensions of the report are, in the first place, that relating to working conditions and social standards under which they are produced our clothes, because too many times they are abusive, exploitative conditions, without collective rights or even using child labor. Endless working days that sometimes last up to 24 hours; unattainable production goals, like sewing one T-shirt per minute; constant sexual harassment as a weapon against female workers; facilities that would scare us away due to their hygiene and safety conditions, and a long list that forces us to get down to business. The second dimension is related to transparency and traceability. The textile sector chain is especially complex, as demonstrated by the impossibility of establishing legal responsibilities after the Rana Plaza. We can find a cotton shirt collected by children in Uzbekistan, dyed in Morocco, made in Sri Lanka and with buttons sewn by exploited women in Honduras. This industrial model makes the traceability of each garment especially difficult. For this reason, clear and concrete criteria are necessary to ensure transparency effectively. We have the right to know what we wear. Finally, there is the normative dimension. If we have seen something in recent years, it is that voluntary initiatives do not work. Our societies are based on a social contract. A universal and inalienable contract by means of which we organize and regulate relationships with our peers. Volunteering is legitimate when it comes to choosing our friends or our haircut, but it is not when the fundamental rights of people and their dignity are at stake. Therefore, it is imperative that we renew the basis of our contract, that of our companies, with the people who make our clothes. Tomorrow, with the adoption of this report, this Parliament will be giving a firm and clear mandate to the Commission. We demand that you propose binding legislation on due diligence obligations that protects human rights of those who work in the entire chain of this sector.Finally, I want to thank the shadow rapporteurs from all the groups, and especially Arne Lietz for his work and his support for this report to go forward.And I don't want to forget to name Tamara, Kasia, Joana, Carlos, Jorge and Jacob, because without them this success would not have been possible.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Commission, my colleague Mimica, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs involved, in particular Mrs Sánchez Caldentey, for an excellent job, especially on this special day. We think back to 2013 and 1100 people and many more injuries that were recorded back then. We had a commemoration today under the auspices of Mrs McAvan, who chairs her technical committee, and you, Mrs Sánchez Caldentey, and Arne Lietz, and my colleague Mimica, were also there. You discussed the question of the entire value chain in the textile industry and how it can be made more sustainable and fairer. Like Parliament, the Commission is pursuing two goals: We want to do everything we can to prevent a similar tragedy in the future. And secondly: we want to approach the partner countries together with the Member States, to work with them so that their fellow citizens - the people there - receive decent and sustainable jobs with which they can increasingly earn a living for themselves and their families. My colleague Mimica also presented the working document on sustainable value creation in the clothing industry today. In terms of development policy in particular, the report from your technical committee is in line with our considerations and the ongoing work of the commission, which is also shown in writing in this working document. Promoting sustainable value creation is a contribution, but an essential contribution to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. It is and will remain our declared goal to work towards sustainable value chains in the textile industry. This assumes that we include all relevant internal as well as external policy areas and on the Pay attention to the economic, social and ecological consequences. Our activities are part of a more comprehensive strategy that we are undertaking together with the G20, G7, the OECD and other global institutions. From your draft report and also from our working document it emerges that the value chains in the textile industry are characterized by particularly complex purchasing models, ranging from fibers and fabrics to fabric finishing, clothing to wholesalers and retailers and end consumers. The textile industry worldwide, but also in Europe, is often affected by particular economic, social and ecological challenges such as low wages and long working hours, such as forced labor, as is often the case with child labor, such as the lack of real fair employment contracts, such as the lack of enforcement of collective rights or freedom of association such as low Safety and workplace standards, such as inadequate health protection in the workplace, such as: The workplace is associated with dangerous chemicals. On the one hand, the textile sector makes a significant contribution to economic growth and employment. It can improve people's standard of living, but on the other hand the conditions are often inadequate for this. The Commission is in communication with our partner countries through a wide variety of channels. In development cooperation, we help partner countries by promoting gender equality, women's economic participation, the Decent Work Agenda, improving transparency and traceability in the industry itself. We intend to continue and strengthen this promotion. The Commission recently launched projects worth € 45 million on decent work, transparency, traceability, strengthening value chains in Burkina Faso and Mali and more. All in all, we have to drill a thick board - we are nowhere near where we want to be, but we are thoughtful, sustainable, and your report encourages us to continue our work through various services with various partners in the interests of human dignity, justice andwith the aim of making what we can all remember today on this fourth anniversary, avoidable in the future as far as possible.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, I speak not only as the rapporteur for opinion on employment, but also the person who chairs Parliament’s Delegation for Relations with South Asia, which includes Bangladesh. I have been to what remains of the Rana Plaza site, met survivors, seen the work of the Accord, the Alliance and the Sustainability Compact there, argued with brands and manufacturers about compensation, and with the Government about how we actually entrench and embed high labour standards. I think that is something we need to see in general, not as a niche, and we also need to recognise the important role that price has in this downward pressure on standards. I think we need to question, in fact, the model of fast fashion that we have, and the price that workers pay for that. The supply chain accountability people have spoken of is absolutely crucial, as are empowered workers in free trade unions, able to engage in genuine and constructive social dialogue to help move us forward to something where we have this as a norm, not, as I say, as a niche. We want to see the Commission and the European Union actively engaging on the international scene and, indeed, promoting such things as the UN Guiding Principles, which are often unknown in some of the countries with which we have trade relationships.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr Chairman!We live in times when the world is divided into a rich North and a poor South.In poor, developing countries, most of the production cycle in the clothing industry is located.This is very good because millions of people have a chance to work, earn money, and provide for families.It is estimated that one employee supports about eight to ten other people.The downside is that in these countries, unfortunately, very often the regulations, standards, principles concerning human rights, labor rights, health and safety at work, environmental protection, etc. are not respected.we are committed to ensuring that these values are respected in these countries, and also in the companies that produce in these countries.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Dear Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Lola Sánchez Caldentey, and everyone involved in the report, for the very, very good cooperation. I mentioned the German Textile Alliance in my first development policy speech in the European Parliament. It is a voluntary multi-stakeholding initiative for the safe and fairly paid production of textiles, which has developed positively in recent years. France has now passed a law on mandatory due diligence in the clothing supply chain. Trade policy is European policy. That is why the aim must be to anchor such legislation at the European level. The new OECD guidelines for responsible supply chains in the clothing and footwear sector from February 2017 must be made binding. That is exactly what we are calling for in this report. The EU Commission has unfortunately taken too long to bring the promised flagship initiative for the European clothing industry into being. The EU Commission's working document published today can only be a first step. With this report, the European Parliament is giving an impetus so that, four years after the Rana Plaza disaster, we can finally come up with legislation on due diligence in the clothing supply chain. That would make a necessary European fashion revolution possible. The EU institutions and member states should first set their own example and make their own public procurement sustainable and fair. In addition to the report, the EU Commission and the European Parliament should actively support IndustriALL's ACT initiative following global collective bargaining in the clothing industry. The clothing supply chain is an excellent example of the development policy goals for 2030, to connect them coherently and to make them visible, z.For example, goal 8 - good work and living wages - or goal 12 of responsible production and consumption or goal 5 of equal rights for men and women.We have made good headway with this report and now hope that the Commission will draft the legislative process as soon as possible.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, it has just been four years since the collapse of the Rana Plaza in Bangladesh: More than a thousand people died who made the clothes we wear every day. We all like to buy cheap and nice clothes. The problem is that what is cheap for us costs others their lives. For twenty years, voluntary guidelines have been developed to improve the situation in the sector, the clothing sector, and they have not worked. The situation of millions of workers remains unworthy. We need binding requirements for all European companies and third states. Only binding standards, legally binding standards can ensure that all companies - multinationals as well - guarantee the protection of human rights, in line with the United Nations Guiding Principles on business and human rights. And only a mandatory regulation will guarantee that those companies that do respect the human rights of their workers do not have a competitive disadvantage compared to those that do not. Our job is to reward companies that behave in accordance with the standards that the European Union is committed to respecting. I want to say something to the Conservatives and Popular Group deputies who oppose this report: Pope Francis compared the working conditions of the Bangladeshi victims to slavery. And slavery was not abrogated by voluntary measures. It was simply forbidden. Let's listen to Pope Francis on this.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I would like first of all to congratulate the rapporteur on her great work on this report. We are talking about a sector, that of clothing, where millions of workers - a highly feminized sector - are victims of greed and exploitation by textile multinationals. It is these companies, the big brands that we see in all television commercials, the real culprits of the terrible degradation of wages and working conditions in developing countries, who are forced to compete with each other to survive in the world. global string. The European Union must use the legal instruments that are already within its reach to oblige - and I mean well, oblige - producers to ensure compliance with basic labor standards such as the right to freedom of association, to collective bargaining, to safety at work or the prohibition of child labor. But it must go further and impose legal rules that ensure the traceability and transparency of products and that allow sanctioning companies that produce or subcontract to other companies that in turn violate labor rights.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (FI) Mr President, Commissioner, the working document on the textile initiative published today is disappointing in that, in the Lola Sánchez Caldentey report, Parliament also reiterates its call for a legally binding due diligence initiative. I'm sure that this is the only way responsible companies will receive a competitive advantage, which they deserve because the field was very much an activity that does not comply with human rights standards and labor standards and which pollute the environment. The Commission has many good voluntary initiatives in this working document, but none of them guarantees that these responsible companies will finally get the competitive situation they need, in which irresponsible companies will not try to combat them. In particular, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the Commission should also hurry to achieve full freedom of association in the producing countries, so that responsible companies also have someone with whom to negotiate decent wages.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Each purchase of clothing, regardless of the place and method of production, affects the people who created it and the environment in which it was made. The clothes we put on go a long way and are not only kilometers of transport, but most of all people and their work. Hard work, at the cost of loss of health, for a low wage, but still work that is the only source of income and survival for these people. I am opposed to violations of human rights, labor rights and environmental protection standards, therefore I support the wording on binding human rights clauses as well as social and environmental clauses. However, let us remember about the competitiveness of our companies. Thanks to their initiatives, in such places around the world as Bangladesh, we can see a real change in terms of occupational health and safety. Of course, action by companies and producing countries must go further, so that workers are guaranteed the best possible working standards and, of course, better wages. I am pleased that we tabled four compromise amendments together with the rapporteur. I hope that these amendments and the report will be adopted tomorrow by vote.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: - This report before the European Parliament today touches on a very topical and urgent discussion, namely the question of how we now finally regulate good and fair trade and who is responsible for it. The report asks the Commission for binding proposals for due diligence for European companies importing textiles and clothing. I can only applaud that enormously. But the responsibility also lies with the exporting countries. That is why I am so happy with the letter from the European Commission that was sent to the Bangladeshi government in March. I hope that we will soon also receive commitments to provide the SAP plus situation in Sri Lanka with a rock-solid evaluation mechanism. Because only when all those responsible take their responsibility, that is, the companies, the importing and the producing countries, and they commit to strict demands, can we achieve real progress for all those millions of men and women who work in the clothing industry.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: - Mister President! We all remember the terrible tragedy in Rana Plaza, and what happened there was unbearable. But what also became clear: The problem is not always “cheap” - there were also some high-priced suppliers who had their products manufactured there. After the accident, some colleagues in the European Parliament called for a complete boycott of the textile industry in Bangladesh. I am very grateful that we didn't do that back then, it would have been a disaster for the country. In the draft report of the colleague, a lot is worked with specifications, restrictions and know-it-alls. What I regret most, however, is that throughout the report and also today in the debate, the rapporteur speaks only negatively. There is no mention of how many jobs have been created in the textile sector in developing countries in recent years. It is not mentioned how many women who were previously without rights and penniless now have their own income in socially insured employment relationships, especially in these countries. It is not mentioned that in many countries development, health care, education, pension insurance and future prospects can only be created through the textile industry. And with all the guidelines that we want to set, I hope that we also keep an eye on how important good industrial development is for future opportunities in these developing countries.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, the tragedy that has taken place in Bangladesh has been a kind of late alarm for European consumers.We started studying corporate responsibility and found, for example, that the tragedy in Bangladesh had not yet been traced and that the specific culprits had not yet been identified.It is important to realize that in developing countries, there are between 50 and 60 million people in this sector, who are in appalling conditions: it is often child labor, continuous working hours, and much has been said about it.I am in favor of trying to regulate this environment in the context of fair trade, or rather to put pressure on European companies that import goods from these countries to actually meet the basic criteria.That is what this report is all about, and I am happy to support it.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the life and death of 23-year-old Taslima Aktar, a Bangladeshi garment worker, reads like something out of Charles Dickens. Yet she died on our watch last year on 13 October 2016 after collapsing exhausted at work. Paid a pittance, forced by grinding poverty and poor education to labour in a sweatshop making clothes for the western fashion market, Taslima was consistently denied a break when she felt unwell. After being pronounced dead later that day, her employer left her body outside the factory for her family to collect.  Taslima’s death sparked mass strikes, which were met with repression and punitive measures. Union organisers have subsequently been harassed and arrested and activists have been blacklisted. We must ask ourselves: what price, fashion? For Taslima’s sake, and in memory of all garment workers who suffer injury or who have died at work, I urge the Commission to do everything in its power to put people before profit.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, my first job after graduation was in the textile industry and I am a witness to the working conditions in the early 80's in the textile industry.Hard, largely women in the low-wage textile industry.However, such a textile industry also failed in Europe and moved to Asia or some other developing countries, mainly thanks to investors from the European Union, possibly others, of course.However, we did not do everything.We have ruined our textile industry, we have created new jobs, we have helped developing countries, but in the end we have not come to have the so-called"Fair trade" with these countries.And that’s why I think today we really need to take a step forward, we really need to make a sustainable chain in this trade because otherwise we will have on our conscience what happened, specifically, at Rana Plaza in Bangladesh.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I want to support this report, I consider it extremely important. The European Union is the guardian of human rights, not only in the European Union but also in third countries, and the working conditions under which workers in third countries work in the textile industry are often so appalling that we must be interested. We often debate in plenary here where political rights are being violated, in which states where the right to free speech, the right to assemble, the right to express one's political views are being violated, but we must also be interested in where the fundamental rights contained in the International Labor Organization - the right to working conditions, the right to a minimum wage, the right to breaks and so on. I believe that this report is important. On the other hand, I would like to say that, in addition to possible legislation, we should also address greater awareness among consumers, the citizens of the European Union, and strengthen, for example, the introduction of a fair clothing brand so that consumers know what they are buying.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the reality of textile production in Europe is very complex. Producers are constantly exposed on international markets to aggressive purchasing practices that depend on a multiplicity of global factors, literally impossible to deal with nationally and locally. The consequences of this situation fall on workers' skin, fueling the negative effects of social dumping and violations of human rights and labor standards. All the voluntary initiatives undertaken over the past twenty years by the private sector, while providing essential frameworks for collaboration in issues such as occupational health and safety, have not proved effective. The positive experiences of some Member States, such as Germany and France, must push Europe to move towards an organic regulation of the sector, in line with OECD guidelines. For such a complex sector you need much more than a working document, you need binding legislation and fast deadlines.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, 35 years ago there was the European textile industry, developed in Italy, Portugal, Greece. But those who wanted to make a profit, especially multinationals, essentially dismantled Europe's textile industry and relocated to developing countries, where we have cases such as Bangladesh, UNICEF, child labor, accidents at work, no protection, slavery in essence, events like Rana Plaza and others that we heard. Therefore there are specific responsibilities as to why we have reached this situation and the measures we need to take must be specific, not wishful thinking. I believe that we must support in the European Union, within the European Union, the development of clothing, the textile industry, a fair trade, a protection of processing in the European South. Only then will there be decisive solutions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: speaker. - Mr President, I am only going to give Mr Caspary a historical note, and that is that perhaps you do not know how much you have to go back in time to find a tragedy of the same caliber as that of Rana Plaza, but in European territory. Well, it's 1906. One hundred and eleven years ago. And do you know what that catastrophe led to? It's called the 'Courrières Catastrophe', in a mine in northern France, very close to here. This led the French government to develop and implement the workers' statute and to create a Ministry of Labor and Workers. These misfortunes, together with popular pressure, are what get legislation to be enacted. Without legislation, slavery will not end. And now, I go with my intervention. Because I was in Sri Lanka a week ago. There I met many people; but, among others, I met Mahida. Mahida is eighteen years old. He gets up, in his village, at five in the morning, to get to the factory where he spends at least nine hours on his feet, working tirelessly. He works for a well known European lingerie brand. He works twenty-seven days a month. They give you thirty minutes a day to eat and go to the bathroom. They have made him sign a contract in which he agrees not to unionize. If she tries, she will be fired, without compensation. Every day she has to reach a production target that, moreover, is constantly increasing. As she touches her waist, her boss threatens to follow her home if she doesn't achieve those goals. She charges eighty euros a month, which is not even close to the vital minimum. She is poor and she will remain so no matter how hard she works. If she wants to charge something more, she will have to spend twelve, fifteen, seventeen hours a day on her feet, sewing incessantly, and she will arrive at her house at night with broken fingers. No labor inspector will ever go to her factory. I don't dare tell her that with two or three garments of the hundreds that she produces per day she has already paid her salary, because I am ashamed. But she I assure, I assure Mahida that, in Europe, there are more and more people who care about her and who are not willing to allow some to dress us, and also enrich themselves, with the invisible slavery of others, especially womenlike Mahida, who live poorly so we can be fashionable.I think the Commission has a very clear message.He must urgently present a legislative initiative on binding rules on due diligence, so that cases like Mahida's, like that of Rana Plaza, like that of all the individual Rana Plaza that these people live every day, never happen again.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 27 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The textile and clothing sector is currently one of the most developed in the world, employing about 60 million people, constantly creating new jobs, especially in developing countries.But there is a huge risk these countries face.Much of the time, too rapid and aggressive economic development and fierce global competition have seriously jeopardized respect for the human rights of workers.Some of the many examples are: ridiculous wages, forced labor, unjustified dismissals, shameful health and safety conditions.The 5 Star Movement has always fought for the protection of human rights, especially of workers.For this reason I believe that the European Union must make a strong commitment to resolve this inhumane situation and put an end to the numerous human rights violations that unfortunately suffer thousands of workers.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Sanchez Caldentey, for a good report. Today, it is almost impossible for the consumer to obtain reliable information about where the clothes come from and under what conditions they are made. Another important aspect is what harmful chemicals textiles contain. Many textiles in everyday use that contain hazardous chemicals used in production are banned or regulated under REACH in Europe, such as formaldehyde or perfluorocarbons. Washing clothes releases harmful chemicals. These textiles are not only dangerous at the manufacturing stage and for workers along the supply chain, but they are also dangerous for consumers in everyday use. The chemicals in clothes are released into the water system when they are washed, which puts a strain on the environment. Consumers should be informed about the consequences of cheap clothing. The effects of brighter clothes and clothes that are easier to wash should be recognized. In particular, environmental and health issues are key. The EU should take a firm line to make textile and clothing supply chains cleaner and safer. The human rights of workers involved in manufacturing should also be respected more.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - This midday, the European Parliament will vote in favor of binding rules for textile suppliers and the clothing sector. Respect by manufacturers for workers' rights must become an obligation in order to be able to sell products in our territory. Textile workers, often young women or children, work at breakneck speed. In Bangladesh, 47.5% of workers work between 60 and 98 hours per week, 75% more than 48 hours per week. Discrimination linked to gender or age is omnipresent. More than a quarter of workers are paid less than € 50 per month, below the country's minimum wage. Europe cannot remain blind and deaf to these human rights violations. In concluding its trade treaties, it must make any trade agreement conditional on respect for workers' rights. We can sell clothes; we cannot pay off workers' rights or the human rights of those who make them!

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Maria Noichl, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the current state of agricultural land concentration in the EU: how to facilitate farmers' access to land?(2016/2141 (INI)) (A8-0080 / 2017).

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! It is a few minutes before midnight and a long working day is coming to an end. And yet there is still an important topic on the agenda. While we are thinking about various topics here, behind our backs - without us noticing it or without noticing it - the agricultural country in Europe is increasingly falling into the hands of fewer. In the hands of a few large corporations, in the hands of some non-agricultural corporations. Three percent of the farms currently control over 50 percent of the area in Europe. I think that this number alone should be enough to make the extent of this extreme situation clear. The own-initiative report on the status of the concentration of agricultural land in Europe and, quite clearly, the second part of the report - namely, how it is possible for farmers to gain access to land - has been launched. I would like to mention very briefly eight points that we achieved in the report and, first of all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs very warmly for the exceptionally good cooperation, which is truly unparalleled. The report clearly states that land is not a normal, tradable commodity. Of course we stand by the four fundamental freedoms in the EU, but land is not a normal, tradable commodity! The report also notes that we as the EU Parliament, but also as the Commission, must do everything we can to actually implement the voluntary guidelines in the Member States. We must also support the Member States in stopping the sell-off of their agricultural land. On the one hand, a sale means: a sale by other EU member states or, of course, by third countries. We are very clearly asking the Commission - and that is one of the central points - a catalog of criteria that clearly puts the criteria on the table, such as Member States in the EU can protect their country from being sold out without discrimination. We clearly state that there are major problems in the area of ​​corruption. We suggest that the EU set up an observatory for the land market that really acts jointly with clear data and thus enables an overview of how the concentration of agricultural land in the EU is continuing. We clearly state - and this is very important to me as a member of the SPD - that the aim in Europe is for the diversification of property to contribute to social stability. Scattering of property is not socialist devil stuff, but brings stability to a society. Property dispersion is good and needs to be encouraged. We repeat - and this as an important point too - the cornerstones of European agricultural policy and the cornerstones of the European agricultural model. Agricultural policy is more than the production of products - that is important and correct, but agricultural policy or the European agricultural model includes much more - from climate protection to water protection and biodiversity. If you want to support a good European agricultural model, you have to rely on and build on many players. That means we need a lot of farmers, we don't just need a few. And we clearly state the connection that the concentration of money in fewer and fewer hands has the same step as the concentration of agricultural land in fewer and fewer hands in the EU. The report also makes a clear statement about the future of the EU's agricultural policy. If we continue to believe that we can structure our main support in the agricultural sector purely through area subsidies, we will notice that the way in which area subsidies here in Europe is actually a driver in this area. Our way of subsidizing continues to lead to concentrations in the agricultural sector, in the area of ​​land. That is, have here we do our homework.The ball is now clearly with the Commission;the ball lies in the Member States, because that is an issue that concerns the Member States.We as Parliament have made our point clear;I think we will vote on the report tomorrow by a very large majority.We are seldom so in agreement that the concentration of agricultural land must finally be stopped.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, the hoarding and concentration of agricultural land is a very serious problem in the European Union, which makes it difficult for young people and people without land to settle, and which also prevents the resizing of smaller farms. The causes are multiple: speculation, expropriation of large infrastructures, mining, forestry, criteria for CAP aid ... In short, we find that the Commission and the Council look the other way while the governments allow these situations and prioritize non-agricultural land uses. I hope that the Commission will take note of this important Resolution and that it will guarantee the protection of agricultural land with measures that preserve and prioritize its social function of producing food and with mechanisms to put an end to hoarding and concentration, as well as to guarantee access to agriculture. land of young people, women, small farms and anyone who wants to settle in agriculture.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President, and thank you very much to Maria Noichl as rapporteur. She really worked very inclusive and openly, tried to work with all groups to find good compromises - I think we found her too. It is undisputed that we have land concentration here in Europe, and of course it is also undisputed that the legislation on land lies with the nation states, and we are also very aware of that. But European politics plays into this field in various areas. I just want to mention agricultural policy as an example - it has already been said -, regional development, financial and investment policy - all of these have an impact on the question of land: who has access to land, who speculates with land and who tries to use it as an investment good to use? But it must be clear to us that land is not only the basis of life for us farmers, and that we farmers produce for this domestic market. We must then all be able to sell in the same market. So it is very important that the European Union also creates guidelines here, that we have a starting point for all farmers and that we have protection for the livelihoods not only of the farmers, but for us humans as a whole.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I consider this report to be historic, which finally states that the purpose of arable land is to ensure the life and livelihood of the local population and to produce local healthy food. It also states that it is not a destination that many people think is the subject of speculation and a capital that is used to maximize profits, and which, incidentally, is also promoted by the European Union's support system. I would also like to ask Commissioner Oettinger and the rapporteur whether they can go further and draw the consequence of the need to change the chapters on the free movement of capital, so that, for example, in the accession treaty of my country, Hungary, he says that arable land is part of the free movement of capital and that is why we are forced to give our arable land to foreigners. I look forward to your reply, thank you very much!

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, I regret that this debate on access to land takes place at midnight, because it is a fundamental issue for European agricultural policy.In my country, Spain, we suffer at the same time the abandonment of many agricultural plots that are too small and fragmented to be efficient, while in other regions, mainly in the south, the land is concentrated in the hands of a few large landowners who exploit day laborers andthey are enriched with CAP.That is why I am grateful to the rapporteur for recognizing in her report the great importance of public planning policies, including land banks and public credit, and the need to combat the concentration of agricultural property.Let us not forget that the land must belong to those who work it and that living agriculture, living rural areas require maintaining the fabric of small peasant property.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to thank Mrs Noichl and her colleagues who, I believe, have carried out an important analysis of the ownership and use of agricultural land in Europe with this report and who, here too, document concerns that we as the Commission share. Because land plays an important role in our economies, but it also has a socio-political function. Ownership of land - agricultural and forestry land - as well as real estate has a stabilizing effect on our citizens, who thereby document their knowledge and responsibility for the European Union, our regions and our communities. I believe that one conclusion must be drawn from the further development of our common agricultural policy and what will then be in the budget for the next few years: How do we train farmers of the next generation to remain in this profession and to see a perspective , and how do we create prospects for smallholder agriculture despite all the concentration in the food industry? We have a trade-off here. On the one hand: freedom of investment is of course anchored in European law. Everyone, big and small, can invest in goods. As an EU citizen in your own country, in another country in the European Union, and third parties are also invited. Conversely - and this is first and foremost a matter for the Member States - they have the opportunity to take measures against land concentration and thus against land speculation, in order to preserve rural communities and also to put agricultural land under a certain protection. In doing so, they must observe European law. Over the past few years we have - and will continue to do so - advised the Member States and, with them and the regions, we also advised them tries to show how appropriate protective measures and restrictions can be brought into line with European law and how it is ensured that they are neither directly nor indirectly discriminatory.We believe that, on the basis of your report, we should continue these discussions with the Member States, and I therefore look forward to further discussions with you, but also with our Member States.I will come back to this as the Commissioner responsible for the budget in the course of the next financial framework and the reform of our common agricultural policy.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 27 April 2017.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, as the Hungarian Member of Romania, I would like to speak for the benefit of the European citizens of Hungary and the neighboring countries, who have had to wait 2.5-3 hours at the borders since the introduction of Regulation 458/2017 of the European Parliament and of the Council.as a result of stricter border controls.We consider the application of austerity to be meaningless and unnecessary.They deprive the citizens of the Member States of the blessings of freedom of movement, one of the Union's greatest achievements.It is as if others want to punish the Union's own citizens and their relatives across borders for the sins of illegal immigrants.We ask Parliament and the Council to repeal their relevant regulations or otherwise ensure that the degrading border crossing conditions reminiscent of communist times are remedied.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Mr President, the right to work in safety and protection, ensuring a decent standard of living, supporting those in need are principles that have guided social policy at European level for many years.However, the crisis period has been a difficult one for most social groups, with substantial effects especially on women or young people in the labor market.The European Union must remain a model of good practice in terms of social policies and the protection of the rights of citizens, especially the most vulnerable.The European pillar of social rights can be the general framework for defining social policies at European level and in the Member States.In other words, with the existence of this pillar, we can hope for a new social contact between the EU and its citizens, but it must be fair, solid, sound and credible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the troika and the Tsipras government are cooperating well in enforcing a fourth memorandum, which will complete the transformation of Greece into a vast social graveyard; launches mass layoffs and sells out PPC, lignite reserves and hydropower plants instead of a lentil board. So we have a fourth memorandum without even money, without even debt settlement. The government, instead of proceeding with the immediate distribution to the impoverished Greek people of the social dividend due to the blood-stained primary surplus, which was overshadowed, finally proceeds to impose new measures amounting to 3.6 billion euros. But soon the Greek people will give the troika and the government the answer they deserve, because there is another way for Greece.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr. president. We are remembering today the 80th anniversary of the Guernica bombing, claiming the right to truth, justice and reparation for all the victims of that massacre and of the Franco dictatorship because, as the UN rapporteur Pablo assured us this morning de Greiff, his suffering is a matter of the present that derives from the breach of international law, community norms and fundamental rights. This Parliament approved last December a recipe against oblivion: end impunity and objectively assess from the European Commission the situation suffered by the victims to provide them with the reparation they deserve. Thousands of Europeans search gutters and mass graves for evidence of crimes that do not prescribe; evidence that is not investigated by a judiciary, alien in this matter to international practice, an exception in the treatment of historical memory in the European Union. The victims of the Franco regime await answers from our common space of freedom and democracy. That is why we bring here your voice, your request for empathy. That is why we demand that, fulfilling the mandate of this House, the Commission attend to them.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, according to data from 2016, eucalyptus occupied more than 400,000 hectares in Galicia, almost a quarter of the Galician forest area, and continues to increase.
